summary: This paper studies the problem of multi-agent multi-task learning in the role-based setting. The authors propose a multi-level learning hierarchy, where each agent learns a set of policies and a role selector. The goal of the paper is to find the best policy for each agent in the hierarchy. To this end, the authors introduce a new benchmark, StarCraft II, to evaluate the performance of agents in different levels of the learning hierarchy. Experiments show that the proposed method outperforms the baselines.

This paper studies the stochastic subgradient descent (SSGD) method for solving nonsmooth optimization problems. In particular, the authors consider the convex and strongly-convex setting, and the interpolation setting. The authors show that under certain conditions, the proposed method can converge to the optimal solution faster than SGD.

This paper proposes a method to reduce the computation cost of transformer layers in machine translation. The main idea is to replace the standard transformer layers with a set of non-linear “reservoir” layers. The authors show that by doing so, they can reduce the computational cost of machine translation by a large margin.

This paper studies the problem of invariance and robustness of convolutional networks to transformations in the space of kernel functions. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new invariant kernel function that is invariant to transformations of the kernel function. The authors show that this invariant function can be used to prove the robustness properties of the convolution operators.

This paper proposes a new dataset for multimodal program synthesis. The dataset consists of a large number of programs that are generated by a top-down recurrent neural model. The authors show that their model is able to generate programs that satisfy the constraints provided by the input and output examples. They also show that the proposed dataset can be used to train a neural program synthesis model.

This paper presents a method for learning the specificity landscape of proteins. The method is based on a protein graph convolutional neural network (PGCN) model. The model is trained to predict the sequence motifs of proteins, which are then used for classification tasks. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms existing methods in terms of accuracy and efficiency.

This paper studies the double Q-learning problem, where the goal is to find a stationary solution to a set of Q-values. The authors propose a new algorithm, DoubleQ-learning, to solve this problem. The main contribution of this paper is to provide a theoretical analysis on the convergence rate of double Q learning. In particular, the authors show that under certain assumptions, the algorithm converges to a fixed point that is close to the optimal fixed point of the original Q-value prediction problem.

This paper proposes a two-step training framework to train deep generative models (DGMs) to generate high-resolution natural images. The first step is to train a generative model on low-resolution samples, and the second step trains a decoder network to generate the high resolution samples. The authors show that the proposed method is able to achieve state-of-the-art results on the VQVAE dataset.

This paper studies the problem of self-supervised few-shot learning (SSL). The authors propose a new loss function for SSL, which is a combination of the standard self supervised loss and the supervised loss. The authors show that this new loss can be used to improve the performance of SSL algorithms. They also show that the proposed loss is more robust to large scale labeled data.

This paper studies the first-order methods for training neural networks with two-layer teacher-student networks. In particular, the authors consider the case where the number of neurons in the teacher layer is much larger than the width of the student layer. The authors prove that the first order methods converge to the global minimum of the AD function, which is defined as the distance between the teacher and the student layers. They also show that the second order methods converges to the same global minimum.

This paper proposes a deep neural network architecture for learning knowledge representation from data. The main idea is to learn a representation of the data, and then use the learned representation for the task of visual relationship detection. The authors show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve state-of-the-art performance on the task.

This paper proposes a new regularization method for iterative recurrent neural networks (ResNets). The main idea is to add a regularization term to the normalization term of the convolutional layers of ResNets. The authors show that this regularization is effective in reducing the bias in the convergence rate of the network. They also show that the proposed regularization can reduce the bias of the model.

This paper studies the effect of different normalization techniques on the performance of deep neural networks (DNNs) on the classification and segmentation tasks. The authors analyze the mean and variance of mean, variance, and variance across different DNNs on different datasets. They also analyze the impact of different IID and identically distributed (IID) data.

This paper proposes a method to improve the sample efficiency of reinforcement learning (RL) agents in the DeepMind Control Suite (DCTS) environment. The authors propose to augment the input of the encoder of the RL agent with information that is relevant to the task at hand. To this end, the authors propose two augmentations: (1) augmenting the input with a sequence of tokens, and (2) augment the output with a set of tokens that are similar to the current state of the art in the DCTS environment. Experiments show that the proposed method outperforms the baselines in terms of sample efficiency.

This paper studies the problem of learning a network architecture for multi-task learning. In particular, the authors consider the case where the goal is to learn a network that can be used to solve a set of tasks. In this setting, the paper proposes a new method to learn the network parameters. The main contribution of the paper is to provide a theoretical analysis of the convergence of the proposed method. The authors also provide empirical results to support their theoretical analysis.

This paper studies the problem of minimizing the minimization of the geometric-distortion constraint (MGC). The authors propose two methods to solve this problem. The first method is based on the I2I translation constraint, and the second one is on the domain mapping function. Both methods are evaluated on three benchmark datasets. The results show that the proposed method outperforms the existing methods.

This paper studies the problem of sampling-sensitive point cloud GANs. In particular, the authors focus on the point cloud generation problem. The authors propose a new discriminator, PointNet-Mix, which is based on a middle-point sampling-aware baseline discriminator. They show that the proposed discriminator outperforms the existing discriminators in terms of quality and accuracy.

This paper studies the problem of adversarial robustness of Capsule Networks (CapsNets) against white-box attacks. CapsNets are a class-conditional neural network (CNN) that is trained to generate adversarial examples. The authors propose a detection-aware attack paradigm based on the class-conditioned reconstruction based detection method to detect adversarial attacks. They also propose a multi-step attack protocol to detect the adversarial perturbations.

This paper studies the problem of meta-reinforcement learning of recurrent neural networks. The authors propose a new algorithm for learning the embeddings of recurrent policies in the meta-RL setting. The main contribution of the paper is the introduction of a new objective, which is based on the idea of sharing information between the policy and the embedding. The paper also proposes a new sampling strategy to reduce the sample complexity of the learning process.

This paper proposes a method to learn a model-based policy for real-world applications. The method is based on a combination of two approaches: (1) online sampling and (2) model learning. The first approach is to use a simulator to train a policy, and the second is to learn the model from the simulator. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms the baselines in both cases.

This paper studies the problem of goal reaching in reinforcement learning (RL) algorithms. The authors propose a new goal-reaching RL objective, which aims to improve the performance of RL algorithms on a set of benchmark tasks. To achieve this goal, the authors introduce a new reward function, which encourages RL algorithms to reach the goal faster than the baseline reward. They show that this new reward can be leveraged to improve RL algorithms' ability to reach goals faster than baseline rewards. They also show that the proposed reward function can be used as a proxy for the quality of the expert demonstrations.

This paper studies the problem of speed-up in the training of speech models. The authors show that the current state-of-the-art teacher models are not able to learn to predict the duration of speech, and propose a new method to speed up the training. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a data simplification method to reduce the information loss of the teacher model.

This paper studies the problem of minimizing a probability density function over a subspace $f$ of dimension $x$ over a distribution $q(x)$ over $x$. The authors propose a two-step iterative algorithm to solve the problem. The first step is to minimize the distance between $q$ and $f$, and the second step minimizes the distance of $q'$ to $f$. The main contribution of the paper is to show that the proposed algorithm converges to the optimal solution in $O(f)$ time.

This paper studies the problem of feature contrastive learning (FCL) in the presence of noise and underrepresented patterns. In particular, the authors focus on the case where the classifier is trained on a set of examples, and the goal is to learn a classifier that can generalize to unseen patterns. To this end, they propose two methods: (1) model-based and (2) feature-based. In both cases, they show that the proposed methods outperform the baselines in terms of robustness and generalization.

This paper studies the problem of representation learning in the presence of information constraints. In particular, the authors focus on the setting where the agent has access to a shared feature space, and the goal is to learn a representation that satisfies the constraints. The authors propose an algorithm that learns a representation of the feature space that minimizes the difference between the representation learned by the agent and the one learned by an agent that does not have access to this shared representation. They show that their algorithm is able to achieve state-of-the-art performance on a variety of tasks.

This paper studies the generalization error of deep neural networks (DNNs) trained with the Lottery Ticket Hypothesis (LTH) hypothesis. The authors propose a new algorithm for training DNNs with the LTH hypothesis. In particular, the authors show that the (accelerated) stochastic gradient descent algorithm (SGD) can be used to prune weights in the hidden layer of a DNN to obtain a network that generalizes better than the original network. The paper also provides a theoretical analysis of the generalisation error of the winning ticket hypothesis.

This paper studies the problem of data augmentation in the context of adversarial robustness and generalization. In particular, the authors focus on the case where the distributional shift between clean and augmented data is small. The authors show that the clean data is more robust to adversarial perturbations than the augmented data. They also provide a theoretical analysis of the impact of the distribution shift on the robustness.

This paper studies the problem of self-supervised representation learning in the presence of proxy classifiers. The authors propose a new objective called Invariant Causal Mechanisms (RELIC) that aims to improve the robustness of the representation learning objective. The main contribution of the paper is the introduction of a new regularizer that ensures that the proxy classifier is invariant to data augmentation. Experiments are conducted on the ImageNet dataset.

This paper proposes a new method to learn a visual representation of the environment for navigation. The method is based on a transformer-based architecture that learns to predict the location of objects and regions in the environment. The authors show that the proposed method is able to achieve state-of-the-art performance on a set of tasks.

This paper studies the problem of privacy preserving federated learning. In particular, the authors consider the setting where each client has access to only a subset of its neighbors' data. In this setting, the goal is to preserve the privacy of the data. The authors propose a new approach to this problem, which is based on the topology of the graph. Theoretical results are provided to show the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

This paper studies the problem of designing a two-player game with utility functions that are compatible with the Lagrangian of the two players. The main contribution of the paper is to provide an algorithm to solve the problem in a time-independent manner. The algorithm is based on the maximization of a set of misreports, and the authors show that the algorithm is optimal in terms of the number of reports. The authors also provide a proof of convergence of the algorithm.

This paper studies the problem of fine-tuning the representations learned by a pre-trained neural network on a large-scale dataset. The authors propose a novel contrastive learning loss to improve the quality of the learned representations. They show that the proposed method outperforms the baseline methods on both supervised and unsupervised pre-training tasks. They also show that their method can improve the performance on the low-data regime.

This paper studies the problem of adversarial robustness in the presence of perturbations. The authors propose a new adversarial training method based on the norm-based distance metric. They show that the proposed method outperforms existing methods in terms of robustness and generalization.

This paper studies the problem of fairness in graph neural networks. The authors propose a new notion of fairness, which they call "dyadic fairness", which is a generalization of the concept of fairness in machine learning. In particular, they show that in the case of graph-structured data, there is a tradeoff between fairness and utility, and propose a novel algorithm to solve this tradeoff.

This paper proposes a method for disentanglement in the latent space of an autoencoder. The method is based on the idea of disentangling the representation of the latent code into a positive and negative part, and then using the positive part to generate the negative part of the code. The authors show that the proposed method is able to achieve state-of-the-art performance on the COCO dataset.

This paper proposes a Bayesian memory allocation scheme for learning a sequence of latent variable models. In particular, the authors propose to allocate blocks of latent variables in a sequential fashion, where each block corresponds to a differentiable block of the latent variable model. The authors also propose a conditional image generation scheme, where the latent variables are conditioned on the sequence of variables in the previous block. Experiments are conducted on MNIST, CIFAR-10, and ImageNet32×32.

This paper studies the loss landscape of attention mechanisms in deep learning models. The authors propose a new loss landscape, which is composed of two parts. The first part is a loss landscape for self-attention models, and the second part is an additional loss for attention models.

This paper studies the problem of active inference in reinforcement learning. In particular, the authors focus on the free energy principle, which states that the goal is to learn a model that maximizes the expected free energy (EFE) of the state-action pair. The authors propose a new reward function based on theoretical connection between EFE and preference learning. The paper also provides a theoretical analysis of the proposed reward function.

This paper studies the problem of data augmentation in the context of generalization and adversarial training. The authors propose a new dataset augmentation method for generalization, and show that it can improve the generalization performance on CIFAR-10 and Cifar-100 datasets.

This paper proposes a new meta-RL method, Fast Linearized Adaptive Policy (FLAP), that learns a linear representation of the policy and adapts it to new tasks in a continuous control setting. FLAP uses a feed-forward network to update the weights of the meta-policy, and a gradient descent network to adapt the policy. The authors show that FLAP outperforms the state-of-the-art methods on several continuous control tasks.

This paper studies the problem of communication efficient federated kernel k-means (KM) compression. The authors propose a new algorithm that achieves O(1/T) convergence rate in the federated setting. They also provide a theoretical analysis of the convergence rate of the proposed algorithm.

This paper studies the problem of model search and training in hardware and latency-constrained environments. The authors propose a new metric to measure the complexity of the search space, which is defined as the number of models that can be found in a given search space. They show that this metric can be used as a proxy for the amount of data that is needed to train a model. They also show that there is a tradeoff between the complexity and accuracy of the model space. Finally, they show that the model search space can be decomposed into two parts: a search space and a training space.

This paper studies the problem of adversarial meta-learning. In particular, the authors propose a new algorithm, Adversarial Meta-Learner (ADML), which uses adversarial samples to initialize a learning model in an adversarial manner. The authors conduct experiments on MiniImageNet and CIFAR100 datasets to show the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm.

This paper proposes a data-driven framework for self-attention-based machine learning based on Bose-Chaudhuri Hocquenghem (BCH) codes. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms the baselines in terms of error rate and decoding complexity. They also provide a theoretical analysis to support their claims.

This paper studies the problem of fine-tuning BERT on topical classification tasks. In particular, the authors focus on the task of unsupervised clustering, which is a well-studied problem in machine learning. The authors propose to fine-tune the BERT model on top of the clustering task. They show that the model is able to achieve better performance than the baseline model on this task.

This paper studies the problem of training a generative model to solve a continuous control problem. The authors propose to train the model on a mixture of density nets, where the goal is to minimize the number of trajectories that need to be traversed in order to solve the problem. To this end, the authors propose a regularizer that encourages the model to generate trajectories with high probability. They show that this regularizer can improve the performance of the model.

This paper studies the problem of disentanglement in GANs. In particular, the authors propose a new regularizer for disentangled GAN (ADIS-GAN) which is based on the regularizer introduced in InfoGAN. The authors show that the proposed regularizer is able to disentangle the representations of the original image and the transformed image. They also provide a theoretical analysis of the performance of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new contrastive learning method for self-supervised learning and object detection tasks. The proposed method is based on the ResNet-50 architecture. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms the state-of-the-art methods in both supervised and unsupervised settings.

This paper proposes a new method for de-identification of MRI scans. The method is based on a deep learning framework, where the model is trained on a large database of scans from a patient's MRI scan. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of privacy-sensitive facial features, which are used to improve the performance of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new graph pooling method based on multi-head attention for graph representation learning. In particular, the authors propose a multi head attention based global pooling layer for graph representations. The proposed method is evaluated on the Weisfeiler-Lehman graph isomorphism test and graph classification and link prediction tasks.

This paper studies the problem of long-range interaction in graph neural networks (GNNs). In particular, the authors focus on the long range interaction task, where the goal is to find the shortest path between two nodes in a graph. The authors show that GNNs are able to solve this problem in a scalable manner. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new GNN architecture that is able to address the problem.

This paper studies the problem of cross-domain generalizable classifiers for sentiment analysis. In particular, the authors focus on the domain-agnostic representation learning problem. The authors propose a novel domain adaptation method, which is based on the concept of domain adaptation. The proposed method is evaluated on three datasets, and it is shown that the proposed method outperforms existing methods.

This paper studies the problem of gender-bias in natural language understanding (NLI) models. In particular, the authors propose a new dataset and a new evaluation methodology to evaluate gender bias in NLI models. The authors show that the proposed dataset is more gender-balanced than the existing ones, and the proposed method is able to improve the performance of existing models.

This paper proposes a new algorithm for intrinsic control (IC) in the context of reinforcement learning. The algorithm is based on the Gaussian mixture model, which is an extension of the classical VAE algorithm. The authors show that the proposed algorithm outperforms the state-of-the-art VAE algorithms in a number of tasks.

This paper studies the problem of deep neural network ensembling for image classification in the low-data regime. In particular, the authors focus on the case where the dataset size is small and the number of classes is small. The authors show that the proposed method is able to outperform the state-of-the-art approaches in terms of sample efficiency.

This paper studies the problem of compressed neural networks (BNNs) in the context of training and generalization. In particular, the authors propose a new method for training BNNs with 0/1 binary weights. The authors show that the proposed method is able to achieve better generalization performance on MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets.

This paper proposes a new method for estimating the membership probabilities of classes in deep learning models. The proposed method is based on the Brier score, which is a measure of the uncertainty of class membership probabilities. The authors show that the proposed method can be used to estimate the probability of a given class in a deep learning model.

This paper studies the power of graph neural networks in machine learning problems. In particular, the authors focus on the problem of learning non-isomorphic graphs. The authors propose a new graph neural network architecture that is able to learn representations and similarities between nodes and edges of a graph. They show that the proposed architecture can achieve better performance than existing approaches.

This paper proposes a new self-supervised image-to-image contrastive learning method based on the CutMix framework. The key idea is to learn a low-level similarity between two images, which is then used to regularize the discriminator predictions. The proposed method is evaluated on two datasets, one of which is a driving video dataset and the other is a synthetic video dataset. Experiments show that the proposed method outperforms the baseline methods.

This paper studies the problem of disentanglement in the context of self-supervised generative models. In particular, the authors focus on the case where the data is generated by a generative model that is trained to generate representations that are disentangled from a set of independent causal mechanisms (ICM). The authors propose a framework to disentangle the representations from the set of causal mechanisms. The authors show that the proposed framework is able to achieve state-of-the-art results on a variety of datasets.

This paper proposes a self-labeling approach for chemical compound graph representation learning. In particular, the authors propose a graph aligning approach to learn a representation of the chemical compound graphs, which can be used for self-labelling and domain adaptation. The proposed approach is evaluated on a synthetic dataset and a real-world dataset. The results show that the proposed approach outperforms the baselines.

This paper studies the problem of energy consumption estimation in the domain knowledge based deep learning framework. In particular, the authors focus on the input-output monotonic constraint and propose a new method to solve this problem. The proposed method is based on a nonlinear model and is able to achieve state-of-the-art results on several real world physical systems.

This paper proposes a method to reduce the time complexity of the multi-head attention in the context of traffic forecasting models. The proposed method is based on the use of a causal graph fusion mechanism. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms existing methods in terms of accuracy and time complexity.

This paper proposes a multi-agent variational inference framework for the single-cell gene expression dataset. The proposed framework is based on a mixture of discrete and continuous factors of variability. The authors show that the proposed framework can be applied to a variety of datasets, and provide a theoretical analysis of the proposed method.

This paper studies equivariant convolutional networks (GCNNs) with steerable kernels. The authors show that under certain conditions, GCNNs can be steerable. In particular, the authors prove that under the steerability constraint, the kernel space of a GCNN is steerable, and also prove the equivalence between steerable and non-steerable kernel spaces.

This paper studies the trade-off between accuracy and coverage in the context of classification models. The authors propose a new metric, the margin distribution, to measure the discrepancy between the accuracy of a model and the coverage of a dataset. They show that models with high margin distributions are more accurate than models with low margin distributions.

This paper studies the problem of multi-modal document classification and topic modeling in a hierarchical structure. The authors propose a multi-layer neural network architecture for the task. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new training method to train the neural network. The paper shows that the proposed method is able to improve the performance of existing methods.

This paper studies the problem of adversarial robustness of GNNs. In particular, the authors focus on the named-entity recognition and named-node classification tasks. The authors propose a new certificate to certify the robustness against adversarial perturbations. In addition, they also propose a single-node certificate for the named entity recognition task.

This paper studies the problem of non-convergence in GANs. In particular, the authors focus on the case of the least squares GAN (LSGAN) and the Wasserstein GAN model (WGAN). The authors propose a new metric, Frechet Inception Distance (FID), to evaluate the performance of GAN models on real-world data. The authors show that in both cases, the loss functions of the GAN and WGAN models are not convergent, and that the loss function of the WGAN model does not converge to a stationary point. In addition, they show that the convergence rate of WGAN is lower than that of the LSGAN model.

This paper proposes a new metric for explaining machine learning models. The metric is based on the similarity between two sets of data points. The authors argue that this metric can be used as a way to explain the performance of a machine learning model.

This paper studies the generalization power of graph neural networks (GNNs) in the context of the dot product attention and generalization properties. The authors propose a two-layer MLP-based GNN architecture, where the first layer consists of two kernels, and the second layer is composed of a feature map and a module for generalization. Experiments on several benchmark datasets show that the proposed architecture is able to generalize better than existing GNNs.

This paper studies the problem of label smoothing in the context-dependent classification and transfer learning tasks. The authors propose a new method to improve the performance of CNN-based classification models. The proposed method is based on the idea of smoothing the labels of the objects in the training set. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new smoothing factor, which is a combination of the smoothing of the labels and the smoothness of the activations. The experiments show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new duality framework for neural network optimization. The main idea is to replace the linear filtering in the dual network with a linear combination of linear filtering and linear prediction. The authors also propose a weight decay regularization to improve the performance of neural networks. Experiments on MNIST and fastMRI datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new training framework for text-to-speech synthesis models. The main idea is to use a dynamic time warping loss to train the model to predict the length and duration of the input sequence. The authors also propose a differentiable alignment scheme to improve the quality of the generated sentences. Experiments show that the proposed framework outperforms the state-of-the-art models.

This paper proposes a new representation learning method based on the Wasserstein graph diffusion method. The main idea is to learn the representation of the nodes in the graph in a non-parametric manner. The authors show that the proposed method is able to achieve better performance than the existing methods.

This paper studies the problem of goal-conditioned reinforcement learning in the presence of extrinsic rewards. In particular, the authors propose a new objective, the “constructively adversarial” objective, to encourage the learner to achieve goals that are adversarially motivated. The authors show that the proposed objective can be used to improve the performance of RL agents in a variety of environments.

This paper studies the problem of minimizing the privacy-distortion tradeoff in the minimax minimax game. The authors propose a data-driven approach to solve this problem, which is based on the idea of generating adversarial models. They provide a theoretical analysis of the trade-off between privacy and distortion, and provide an algorithm to achieve it. They also provide experimental results on the MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets.

This paper proposes a greedy learning method for graph neural networks (GNNs) to accelerate the training of GNNs. In particular, the authors propose a greedy greedy learning algorithm for GNN layers. The proposed algorithm is based on the greedy learning framework proposed in [1]. The authors show that the proposed algorithm outperforms existing greedy learning methods on several benchmark datasets.

This paper studies the problem of knowledge graph optimization. The authors propose a differentiable objective that is end-to-end differentiable and can be used to improve the performance of existing methods. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new objective that can be applied to the knowledge graph optimisation problem.

This paper studies the robustness of feed-forward neural networks to adversarial attacks. The authors propose a method to evaluate robustness in the presence of adversarial inputs. In particular, the authors show that the proposed method is robust to p-ball attacks. They also show that their method is more robust than existing methods.

This paper presents an empirical study of the relationship between object similarity and affordance in the context of human judgements of object similarity. In particular, the authors study the relation between human judgments of affordance and the distance between objects in the space of objects. The authors show that human judgments on affordance are correlated with object similarity, and that the distance is correlated with the distance of objects in affordance space.

This paper studies the problem of multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) in the context of individualism. The authors propose a new algorithm, EOI-MARL, that aims to encourage the agents to learn to be more individualistic in the presence of other agents. The algorithm is based on the idea that agents should be able to distinguish between their own and other agents' actions in order to improve their performance. The paper shows that the proposed algorithm is able to achieve better performance than existing MARL algorithms.

This paper proposes a new adversarial robustness certification method based on the Smoothed Ensembling (SWEEN) framework. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new classifier-based adversarial training method to improve the robustness of the proposed SWEEN model. The proposed method is evaluated on several adversarial attacks on MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets.

This paper studies the problem of task decomposition in unsupervised and weakly supervised settings. The authors propose a new task hierarchy based on the ordered memory policy network (OMPN) framework. They show that it is possible to decompose the task hierarchy into sub-tasks and show that this decomposition can lead to better generalization. They also show that the decomposition of the hierarchy can help to reduce the bias in the learning process.

This paper studies the problem of domain-specific generalization error in the context of causal reasoning. In particular, the authors propose a new framework for causal reasoning based on the Bayesian invariance principle. The main contribution of the paper is to provide a theoretical analysis of the correlation between the invariance and generalization errors. The authors also provide some empirical results to support their theoretical findings.

This paper studies the problem of online multi-armed bandits in the context of stochastic Markov Decision Processes (MDPs). In particular, the authors consider the case where the reward distribution is adversarially corrupted. In this setting, they propose a new algorithm that achieves near-optimal regret in both synthetic and real-world datasets.

This paper proposes a method to improve the quality of NMT models by re-evaluating the training process of the encoder-decoder architecture. The method is based on the re-iteration of the gradient descent (PGD) algorithm. The authors show that the proposed method is able to achieve better performance on the Chinese-English and English-German translation tasks.

This paper proposes a two-stage adversarial learning framework for black-box segmentation. In the first stage, an adversarial network is used to refine the predictions, and in the second stage, a stochastic mapping is learned. Experiments are conducted on the multi-modal LIDC dataset.

This paper studies the problem of communication complexity in distributed machine learning algorithms. The authors propose a new compression method that is unbiased and can be used to reduce the communication overhead. They also provide a theoretical analysis of the proposed method.

This paper studies the problem of hyperparameter optimization (HPO) in machine learning (ML) algorithms. In particular, the authors propose a new benchmark for HPO, which is based on benchmarking the performance of existing baseline algorithms. They show that HPO is able to outperform existing benchmarks in terms of accuracy and speed. They also provide a theoretical analysis of the search space of HPO.

This paper studies the problem of adversarial attacks on the representation of high-dimensional, high-entropy labels in the context of image classification. In particular, the authors focus on the high-dimensionality of the data and the high entropy of the labels. To this end, they propose a novel adversarial attack method based on Gaussian mixture matrices.

This paper studies the problem of robustness of neural networks to log-likelihood perturbations. In particular, the authors focus on the question of how robust neural networks are to logistic perturbation. They show that models trained on CIFAR-10 and ImageNet-100 are not robust to loglikelihood variations. They also show that the robustness can be improved by adding a forward pass to the training process.

This paper studies the problem of knowledge distillation in the context of sparse representation learning. The authors propose a new method, sparse representation matching (SRM), which learns representations of the hidden features of the teacher and student networks. They show that the proposed method can improve the performance of the student network. They also show that SRM can be used to improve the accuracy of the learned representations.

This paper proposes a new policy similarity metric (PSM) based on the contrastive representation learning framework. The authors show that the proposed metric can be used to improve the generalization performance of reinforcement learning methods. Experiments are conducted on the Distracting DM Control Suite benchmark.

This paper studies the problem of representation theory in the context of distributed equivariant operators. In particular, the authors focus on topological defects in the representation space. The main contribution of this paper is to show that there exists a class of operators that are invariant to affine transformations in the topological space, and that these operators are disentangled. In addition, they show that these disentanglement operators can be seen as a special case of a generalization of the notion of topological convexity.

This paper proposes a method to estimate the functional connectivity between two neurons in a neural spike train using the Hawkes process. The method is based on the observation that neurons in the same spike train tend to interact with each other in a nonlinear Hawkes Process. The authors show that the proposed method can be applied to both synthetic and real data.

This paper studies the gradient descent (GD) algorithm for two-layer neural network models. The authors provide a theoretical analysis of the dynamics of GD in the under-parameterized regime and in the mean-field regime. In particular, the authors show that the GD dynamics can be decomposed into two stages: a quenching-activation process and a deactivation-activation phase. They also show that in both stages, the GD algorithm converges to a stationary point.

This paper studies the problem of learning a policy that satisfies a set of safety constraints in a constrained MDP. The authors propose a new threat function based on the Q-function and propose a method to solve this problem. The proposed method is shown to outperform existing methods in a number of experiments.

This paper studies the problem of cross-entropy loss and deep learning in the context of NLP and ASR. In particular, the authors focus on the hyper-parameter setting, where the number of parameters is much larger than the dimensionality of the dataset. The authors propose a new loss called cross-cross entropy loss, which is a combination of cross entropy and cross entropy loss. Experiments are conducted on two datasets, one for NLP tasks and one for ASR tasks. The results show that the proposed loss improves the performance of both tasks.

This paper proposes a new self-supervised reinforcement learning objective, named Self-Predictive Representations (SPR), which aims to improve the performance of the agent in a limited data regime. The main idea is to augment the agent’s representations with a human-normalized score, which is based on the human score. The authors show that the proposed method achieves state-of-the-art performance on the MuJoCo benchmark.

This paper proposes a new method for unsupervised representation learning for graph embeddings. The main idea is to generate a single embedding vector for each node in a graph, and then use it to train a graph embedding model on top of that vector. The authors show that the proposed method can achieve comparable performance to state-of-the-art methods.

This paper studies the problem of large-scale graph coarsening. In particular, the authors propose a new algorithm for learning large scale graphs. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new metric, which is based on the ratio between the size of the weights and the number of edges in the graph. The authors show that this metric can be used as a proxy for the quality of the resulting graph.

This paper studies the problem of learning acoustic properties of 3D objects in dynamic environments. The authors propose a deep learning based method to learn acoustic properties. The key idea is to learn the topology of the latent space, which is then used to generate the acoustic effects. Experiments show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies the problem of extreme distributional shifts in machine learning prediction systems. The authors propose a new method to mitigate distributional shift in the training data. The method is based on minimizing the risk minimization objective on a set of extrapolated domains (MMREx). The authors show that the proposed method outperforms existing methods in terms of accuracy and robustness.

This paper proposes a new method for solving PDEs in Euclidean spaces. The method is based on the use of a neural network to map functions from a finite-dimensional space to a hyperbolic space. The authors show that the proposed method can be used to solve a variety of PDE solvers.

This paper studies the convergence of linear tensor networks under the assumption that the input space is orthogonally decomposable. Under this assumption, the authors show that the global minimum can be obtained by minimizing a global minimum of a norm-like function. In particular, they show that under certain conditions, the global minimizer can be approximated by a function that minimizes the difference between the norm and the norm of the input vector.

This paper proposes a new multiobjective optimization lens for slimmable neural networks. In particular, the authors focus on the problem of slimmability in the context of mobile devices. In this context, they propose a new method to optimize the network and dataset combinations in order to achieve top-1 accuracy and reduce the memory footprint. The proposed method is evaluated on the MobileNetV2 dataset.

This paper studies the problem of federated learning and semi-supervised learning. The authors propose a new method, FedMatch, to improve the consistency between the labeled data and the unlabeled data in the federated setting. In particular, the authors show that the proposed method is able to achieve better performance than the existing methods. They also provide some theoretical analysis to support their claims.

This paper studies the problem of self-supervised learning of vector representations. The authors propose a method to learn representations that are invariant to the number of events in the input sequence. The method is based on the idea of contrastive learning, where the goal is to learn a vector representation that is similar to the representation learned by a supervised learner. The paper shows that the proposed method is able to achieve better performance than existing methods.

This paper studies the problem of dependency parsing in natural language modeling. The authors propose a new dependency parsing framework that is based on the self-constrained self-attention mechanism. They show that the proposed method outperforms the state-of-the-art supervised dependency parsing methods.

This paper proposes a framework for scene graph grounding tasks. The authors propose a framework based on the visual representation detection (VRD) dataset. The framework consists of two parts: (1) a scene graph parsing task, and (2) object bounding boxes. The proposed framework is evaluated on a set of benchmark datasets, and compared against several state-of-the-art approaches.

This paper proposes a new framework for learning the latent manifold structure of an autoencoder. The proposed framework is based on the sliced fused Gromov-Wasserstein (SFG) framework. The authors show that it is possible to learn a manifold structure that is a mixture of the von Mises-Fisher distribution and the power spherical distribution in high dimension settings. Experiments show that the proposed framework outperforms the state-of-the-art.

This paper proposes a method to reduce the training time of deep linear networks. The method is based on the idea of weight sharing, where the weights are shared across all layers of the network. The authors show that the proposed method can reduce training time by a large margin.

This paper studies the transferability of adversarial perturbations in the context of neural networks (DNNs). In particular, the authors study the correlation between adversarial transferability and negative correlation. The authors show that the negative correlation can be used to boost transferability in adversarial attacks. In addition, they propose two methods for boosting transferability. Experiments are conducted to verify the effectiveness of the proposed methods.

This paper studies the problem of forgetting in representation learning. The authors show that the forgetting problem can be decomposed into two parts: (1) forgetting in the lower layers, and (2) forgetting at the higher layers. In the first part, the authors find that the representation learned by the lower layer does not generalize well to higher layers, while in the second part, representations learned at higher layers do generalize better to higher levels. To address this problem, they propose two methods: (i) reuse the representations learned in lower layers and (ii) use the learned representations in the upper layers. Experiments show that these two methods lead to similar forgetting rates.

This paper studies the problem of reducing the training and fine-tuning time of large-scale language models for NLP tasks. In particular, the authors focus on the early-Bird Lottery Tickets (ELT) and SQuAD (SQuAD) datasets. The authors show that the training time of XLNet and XLNet-based language models can be reduced by a large margin. In addition, they show that self-attention and self-connecting sub-layers can be used to reduce the model complexity.

This paper studies the problem of learning with noisy labels in the context of stochastic gradient descent. The authors propose a new measure of robustness based on the notion of "f-divergence", which they call "robust-f divergence", which is defined as the difference between the distribution of the noise rate and the noise of the classifier’s predictions. They show that the proposed measure is robust to noisy labels. They also show that their measure is decoupled from existing measures in the sense that it does not depend on the label noise.

This paper proposes a weighted Bellman-based reinforcement learning algorithm for continuous and discrete control tasks. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms the baselines in both low-dimensional and high-dimensional environments. The paper also shows that the method is robust to noise.

This paper proposes a meta-learning framework for few-shot classification problems. The proposed framework is based on the idea of uncertainty-based meta-training, where the model is trained on a set of tasks and then fine-tuned on a subset of these tasks. The authors provide a theoretical analysis of the proposed framework, and provide empirical results to support their claims.

This paper proposes a method for learning video-text representations from videos. The method is based on contrastive learning, where the goal is to learn a representation that is similar to the video, but different from the text representation. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms existing methods in terms of performance on a number of tasks.

This paper studies the problem of multi-vocabulary pre-training in Chinese natural language processing (NLP) tasks. The authors propose a multi-vocabulary pretraining (MVP) approach to improve the expressiveness of pre-trained language models (PLMs) on the BERT and CWS tasks. MVP consists of two steps: (1) tokenization and (2) sequence labeling. Experiments show that the proposed approach improves the performance of BERT on both tasks.

This paper proposes a new method for training graph convolutional networks (GCNs) on large graphs. The method is based on the idea of partitioning the graph into subgraphs and then training GCNs on the subgraph partitions. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms existing methods in terms of accuracy and memory usage.

This paper presents a method for learning 3D molecular structure models from large-scale physics-based simulations. The method is based on a graph neural network (GNN) architecture with a message passing architecture. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of non-linear activation functions for the GNN, which allows the model to scale up to larger numbers of atoms and more complex problems.

This paper studies the problem of generalization in neural networks. The authors propose a new generalization bound based on the complexity of the search space. The main result is a new bound on the number of iterations required for generalization. The paper also proposes a new regularization method to improve the generalization performance.

This paper presents a systematic study of the hyperparameter optimization problem in the context of one-shot structured pruning. In particular, the authors focus on the problem of finding the optimal hyperparameters for a given training configuration. The authors provide a theoretical analysis of the performance of different pruning ratios, and show that the optimal pruning ratio depends on the number of training examples and the hyper-parameters. They also provide a lot of empirical evidence to support their theoretical findings.

This paper studies the problem of training and generalization of neural networks in the presence of label noise. In particular, the authors propose a new notion of coherence, which they call "coherence of per-example gradients", which is defined as the alignment of the gradients of a set of examples with respect to the labels. The authors provide a theoretical analysis of the coherence of the per example gradients, and show that it is a necessary condition for generalization. They also provide empirical evidence to support their theory.

This paper proposes a new method for learning the likelihood function of a generative model. The main idea is to use a deep neural network to estimate the likelihood of a given data point. The authors show that the proposed method can be used in conjunction with existing Bayesian likelihood methods. The method is evaluated on synthetic and real-world data.

This paper studies the problem of image-to-image translation in the supervised setting. The authors propose a new supervised model for this problem. The proposed model is based on a supervised model that is trained on a set of pseudo-pseudo-domain labels. The model is evaluated on three domains: (1) image domain, (2) image to image translation model, and (3) semi-supervised model.

This paper studies the problem of initialization of neural networks for multivariate regression. The authors propose a new regularization strength for the second derivative of the ReLU network, which is based on the cubic spline interpolation. They show that the proposed regularization can be used to improve the convergence rate of the neural network. They also provide a theoretical analysis of the bias in the function space.

This paper studies the problem of weight decay in deep neural networks. The authors propose a new regularization technique, called Stable Weight Decay (SWD), which decouples the weight decay problem from the hyperparameter optimization problem. They show that the proposed method can achieve better performance than the existing methods.

This paper studies the relationship between the quality of NMT decoders and the information flow in the language model (PLM). To this end, the authors propose a new method to retrieve the information from the PLM decoder, which is based on the similarity score. The authors also introduce a new level retrieval method to find the most relevant information. Experiments are conducted to show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a method to improve the performance of deep convolutional neural networks (DNNs) by reducing the rate of gradient ascent of learned features. In particular, the authors propose a new method to reduce the rate at which the learned features are updated. The authors show that the proposed method is able to achieve better performance than existing methods.

This paper studies the implicit acceleration of gradient flow in two-layer linear models. In particular, the authors consider the case where the number of parameters of the model is small, balanced, or spectral. The authors show that the gradient flow is invariant to the choice of the initialization of the parameters. They also show that this invariance holds for the case when the dimension of the matrices is large.

This paper proposes a framework for learning interpretable explanations of machine learning models. The framework is built on top of the LIME framework, which is a model-based framework that allows for user-defined subspaces to be sampled from the model. The authors show that the proposed framework is robust to adversarial attacks and can be used to learn interpretable models.

This paper studies the problem of fine-grained tokenization of pre-trained language models. In particular, the authors focus on the case of multi-word expressions, which is a very important problem in natural language understanding (NLU) tasks. The authors perform a thorough analysis of the performance of fine and coarse grained language models on two benchmark datasets. They show that fine grained models are able to achieve better performance than coarsegrained models on both datasets.

This paper studies the problem of understanding long-range word dependencies in natural language utterance. To this end, the authors propose a transformer-based model that learns a representation of the context of a sentence in the form of a short short-term memory (LSTM). The model is trained on the Geo and MSParS datasets. The authors show that the proposed model is able to capture the relationship between the context and the meaning of the sentence.

This paper proposes a new adversarial training method for deep neural networks (DNNs) that combines multiple adversarial perturbation models. The authors propose to use a combination of multiple perturbations to improve the robustness of DNNs. The proposed method is evaluated on several benchmark datasets.

This paper proposes a new method to learn symbolic representations for abstract rules. The proposed method is based on the idea that the learned representations can be used to guide the learning of abstract rules, which are then used to train a neural network. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms the baselines in terms of the number of rules learned and the amount of training data.

This paper studies the problem of learning task-specific discriminative classifiers in a low-resource regime. The authors propose a framework to address this problem. The proposed framework consists of three components: (1) entity and relation extraction, (2) named entity recognition, (3) relation classification, and (4) dialog state tracking. Experiments show that the proposed framework achieves state-of-the-art performance.

This paper studies the problem of unlabeled entity recognition (NER) in real-world datasets. In particular, the authors propose a new dataset for NER models. The authors show that the proposed dataset can be used to improve the accuracy of the NER model.

This paper presents a method for training acoustic word embeddings in the context of the name recognition task. The method is based on the stochastic neighbor embedding (SNE) framework, which is a technique for embedding words in a low-dimensional embedding space. The authors show that the proposed method is able to achieve state-of-the-art performance on the Name Recognition task. In addition, they show that their method can also be applied to the phonetic matching task.

This paper studies the single-agent reinforcement learning problem in the mean-field setting. The authors propose a new algorithm, called gradient-descent-based RL, to solve the single agent RL problem. The main contribution of this paper is to show that the algorithm converges to the equilibrium in a finite number of iterations.

This paper proposes a new framework for probabilistic inference in flow models. The main idea is to replace the normalizing flow model with a differentiable flow model. The authors show that this leads to better inference performance on a variety of tasks.

This paper presents a new dataset for high resolution image segmentation based on the Electron Microscopy (EM) dataset. The authors propose a new evaluation criteria based on human perception. The paper also proposes a new manual annotation method to evaluate the performance of different segmentation methods.

This paper studies the problem of forgetting in continual learning (CL) algorithms. The authors propose a new benchmark for continual learning, which is based on the Benchmark-Benchmark benchmark. They show that the forgetting problem can be alleviated by using a task-driven prior-driven learning algorithm. They also provide a theoretical analysis of the problem.

This paper proposes a meta-learning approach for few-shot classification tasks. The authors propose a new meta-task that is composed of two meta-tasks: 1) learning a generative model for a given set of classes, and 2) selecting a subset of classes from the set to be used for the next task. The proposed approach is evaluated on a few benchmark datasets and compared to several baselines.

This paper studies injectivity in generative models. In particular, the authors consider the problem of estimating the Lipschitz constants of Gaussian matrices. The main contribution of this paper is to show that for any ReLU layer and any convolutional network, there exists an injective network that can be approximated by a Gaussian matrix. The authors also show that this injectivity can be used to solve nonlinear inverse and inference problems.

This paper proposes a new continuous conditional generative adversarial network (CcGAN) model for image generation. The main idea is to train a generative model and a discriminator in a continuous manner. The authors propose two losses for the generator and discriminator. The first is a hard loss (HVDL) and the second is a soft loss (SVDL). Experiments show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies the problem of active learning and semi-supervised learning. In particular, the authors study the trade-off between sample complexity and convergence rate in the context of both active learning (AL) and semisupervised learning (SSL). The authors propose a new algorithm, ASSL, that aims to reduce the sample complexity of AL and SSL while maintaining the convergence rate of both algorithms. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms the baselines on several benchmark datasets.

This paper studies the problem of distributed training of neural networks with heterogeneous devices. The authors propose a new method that combines a global empirical loss and a local-device level regularizer. The proposed method is evaluated on both convex and non-convex settings.

This paper studies the problem of self-supervised contrastive learning. In particular, the authors focus on the task of linear classification, which is a well-studied problem in computer vision. In this paper, they propose a new loss called contrastive contrastive loss, which aims to improve the similarity between the representations learned by the different layers. The authors also propose to optimize the similarity (similarity) and dissimilarity losses. Experiments show the effectiveness of the proposed loss.

This paper studies the global optimality of the actor-critic and policy-based RL algorithms in the single-time-cale and two-times-cale settings. In particular, the authors show that the global convergence rate is O(K−1/2) and O(k-1/k) for the linear and non-linear function approximation settings, respectively. The authors also provide a lower bound for the global optimization rate in the nonlinear setting.

This paper presents a study of the relationship between transformer networks (TNs) and the embeddings of data in natural languages. In particular, the authors study the relation between the embedding of events, messages, and sequences of data. The authors show that there is a strong correlation between the number of events and the length of the sequence of data, and that the length is correlated with the length. They also show that the lengths of the sequences are correlated with their length.

This paper proposes a new architecture for deep convolutional neural networks (CNNs) based on wavelet decompositions. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new wavelet-based convolution layer, which can be viewed as a special case of the wavelet layer proposed in [1]. The paper also provides a theoretical analysis of the proposed architecture. Experiments show that the proposed method outperforms the state-of-the-art CNNs.

This paper studies the problem of multi-agent reinforcement learning in the zero-shot reinforcement learning setting, where the goal is to learn a team composition that maximizes the total number of agents in the team. The authors propose a new objective that encourages the agents to learn to communicate with each other in order to improve the performance of the overall team. To achieve this goal, the authors propose an attention mechanism that encourages each agent to focus on the other agents' attention. They also propose a communication strategy that encourages agents to communicate their attention to each other.

This paper studies the problem of improving the accuracy of the influence function estimation of deep neural networks. The authors propose a new method to estimate the influence functions in a non-convex setting. They show that the proposed method is more accurate than existing methods. They also provide some theoretical analysis to support their claims.

This paper studies the performance of language models on zero-shot usage and next-to-zero-shot text classification tasks. The authors show that language models are able to generalize well to new tasks. They also show that models can generalize better to tasks of interest.

This paper proposes a new metric for measuring the difficulty of machine learning models. The metric is defined as the difference between the score of a model's accuracy and its membership error. The authors show that the new metric can be used to evaluate the quality of a machine learning model.

This paper proposes a differentiable architecture search method based on the Dirichlet distribution. The main idea is to use a gradient-based optimizer to update the parameters of the architecture mixing weight. The proposed method is evaluated on NASBench-201 and CIFAR-10 datasets.

This paper studies the problem of approximating low-dimensional-but-complex functions. The main contribution of this paper is to show that any function approximator can be represented as a linear function approximated by a non-linear function approximating a low dimensional-but complex function. In particular, the authors show that for any low dimensional but complex function, there exists a function that approximates this function in a polynomial number of dimensions.

This paper studies the problem of long-tailed meta-learning in the context of few-shot learning. In particular, the authors focus on the case where the task-specific models of the meta-model are not available. The authors propose a new algorithm, named teacher-student, to solve this problem. The main contribution of the paper is a theoretical analysis of the convergence rate of the proposed algorithm, which shows that the algorithm converges to the optimal solution in a finite number of iterations. Empirical results are provided to support the theoretical analysis.

This paper proposes a new regularization term for offline reinforcement learning (RL) based on Lagrange multipliers. The main idea is to impose a KL divergence penalty on the gradient of the Q value in the policy evaluation objective. The authors show that the proposed regularization can improve the performance of offline RL algorithms.

This paper studies the problem of training deep neural networks in a one-shot learning paradigm. The authors propose a new training paradigm, where the network is trained on a small number of training examples, and then fine-tuned on a larger number of examples. The main idea is to train the network on a large number of small datasets, and fine-tune it on these smaller datasets. The paper shows that the proposed training paradigm is able to improve the accuracy of the networks trained on these small datasets.

This paper studies the problem of exploration in reinforcement learning (RL) algorithms. The authors propose a new algorithm for exploration based on the concept of "greedy exploration". They show that it is possible to learn a greedy exploration algorithm that is more complex than existing algorithms. They also show that their algorithm is more efficient than existing RL algorithms.

This paper studies the problem of learning a low-rank minimization algorithm. The authors propose a new regularization of gradient descent, which is based on the matrix factorization of the gradient flow. They show that this regularization improves the convergence rate of the algorithm.

This paper proposes a two-stage framework to improve the robustness of the classifier on the real-world skin cancer dataset. In the first stage, the authors propose a new robustness objective based on the idea of subgroup consistency regularizer, and in the second stage, they propose a novel bandage-based model patching method. Experiments show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new method for training a non-differentiable representation learner (RRL) on large-scale data sets. The main idea is to train the RRL on a small set of data and then train the model on a large set of larger data sets using gradient descent. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms existing methods on both small and large datasets.

This paper studies the problem of learning to predict the properties of protein sequences. The authors propose a new algorithm, RGM, which is based on the idea of risk minimization (IRM) algorithm. The main contribution of the paper is the theoretical analysis of the regret minimization of the proposed algorithm. In particular, the authors show that the regret of the RGM algorithm is equal to that of the original algorithm.

This paper studies the problem of cross-modal attentions in BERT models for the text-image retrieval and text-vision retrieval tasks. The authors propose a new method to reduce the computational cost of the BERT model. They show that the proposed method can reduce the number of attentions by a large margin.

This paper presents a model-free actor-critic algorithm for continuous state and action spaces. The algorithm is evaluated on the Box2D and MuJoCo environments. The results show that the proposed algorithm outperforms the baselines.

This paper proposes a new algorithm for federated learning from a Bayesian inference perspective. In particular, the authors propose a new method for training a global model on top of a set of local models. The proposed method is based on the idea of regularizing users’ model training. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms the baselines on a variety of datasets.

This paper studies the problem of estimating the probability that a given set of points $x_i$ has at least one point $y$ that is not in the set $y_i$. The authors show that the probability of finding a point that is at least $x$ is at most $1/\epsilon^2$ if and only if it is a convex combination of $x_{i=1}$ and $y_{i+1}$. They also show that this probability is bounded away from 1/\sqrt{1/2} by a factor that depends on the number of points.

This paper studies the problem of finite-time convergence of deep neural networks in the deterministic control theory framework. In particular, the authors consider the setting where the goal is to minimize a loss function that minimizes the distance between the input and the output of a neural network. The authors provide an upper bound on the number of iterations required to converge to the optimal solution in finite time.

This paper studies the problem of disentanglement of representations learned from synthetic and real data. The authors propose a new method to learn disentangled representations from synthetic data by using a compressed flow network (GIN). The authors show that the proposed method is able to achieve better performance than existing methods on both synthetic data and real-world data.

This paper proposes a new pooling method for image-to-image translation. The proposed method, named LiftDownPool, is based on the recent work LiftUpPool. The main difference is that instead of pooling a single image, the authors propose to pool a set of sub-bands of the original image. The authors show that the proposed method is able to achieve state-of-the-art results on ImageNet and CIFAR-10.

This paper studies the problem of quantized embedding of high-dimensional data. In particular, the authors propose a new quantized version of the well-known Johnson-Lindenstrauss embedding method. The main contribution of the paper is to show that the proposed method can be approximated by a Gaussian random matrix. The authors also provide a theoretical analysis of the distance between the embedding dimension and the quantized dimension.

This paper studies the problem of learning plasticity rules for recurrent neural nets (RNNs) in the presence of adversarial perturbations. In particular, the authors focus on the GD descent (GDGD) algorithm and propose a new method for training RNNs. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms the existing methods in terms of robustness, generalization, and robustness to adversarial attacks.

This paper studies the problem of generating referential and meaningful questions for visual question generation (VQG) models. The authors propose a new dataset, called VQA2.0, which is built on top of COCO-QA dataset. The dataset is composed of a set of visual regions of interest and human annotations, and the authors show that VQG models are able to generate meaningful questions. The paper also shows that the model is able to solve the one-to-many mapping problem.

This paper studies the double descent phenomenon in linear regression models. The authors provide a theoretical analysis of the phenomenon and propose a new regularization regularization scheme that can be used to improve the performance of existing regularization algorithms. They also propose a risk-scaling algorithm that is able to reduce the risk of double descent.

This paper proposes a new method to learn spatial dependency networks (SDNs) in deep neural networks (DNNs). The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a gating-based mechanism to learn disentangled representations. The proposed method is evaluated on a variety of datasets and compared to existing methods.

This paper studies the problem of off-policy reinforcement learning (offline RL) in the setting where the agent has access to a dataset of interactions with the environment. The authors propose a new algorithm to solve this problem. The algorithm is based on the actor-critic algorithm, which is a variant of the SAC algorithm. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new benchmark for off-line RL in the form of the Soft Actor Critic (SAC) benchmark.

This paper studies the problem of model fairness in machine learning. In particular, the authors focus on the issue of data preprocessing and model training. The authors propose a new algorithm, PyTorch, to select the best batch size for training a machine learning model. They show that the proposed algorithm can achieve better performance than existing methods. They also provide theoretical analysis to support their claims.

This paper studies the generalization bounds of deep equilibrium (DEQ) models. The main contribution of this paper is to provide a simple yet tight bounds on the Lipschitz constant of the decision boundary of a DEQ model. The authors show that their bounds are tighter than the existing bounds. They also provide an exponential depth dependence of their bounds.

This paper studies the problem of goal-conditioned reinforcement learning in the setting where the goal is to learn a value function that maximizes the expected return over time. The authors propose a method to learn the value function by estimating the density of the state-action pairs that are close to the goal state. They show that the proposed method outperforms baselines in a number of domains.

This paper proposes a variational multi-task learning framework for multi-tasks learning. The main idea is to use a mixture of variational posteriors for each task. The authors also propose a novel inductive bias to encourage task-relatedness. Experiments show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper presents a new benchmark for long-range transformer models. The benchmark is based on a combination of synthetic and real-world datasets, and is designed to be a systematic and unified benchmark. The authors show that the proposed benchmark can be used to evaluate the quality of long range transformer models in a unified manner.

This paper studies the problem of representation learning on code summarization in multilingual languages. In particular, the authors focus on the topic of source code (context) and machine learning models (machine learning models). To this end, they conduct a series of experiments to study the impact of different language-agnostic and language-agnostic features on the performance of code summarisation models.

This paper presents a method for learning a navigation policy in an unmapped 3D space from audio and visual data. The key idea is to use a combination of two components: (1) a "waypoint" and "waypoints" model, and (2) an "agent motion" model. The goal is to learn a policy that is able to navigate from one point to the next in the unmapped space. The proposed method is evaluated on a synthetic dataset and on a real world dataset.

This paper studies the problem of training neural networks with small initializations. The authors propose a new optimization method based on the concept of "lottery ticket hypothesis", which states that networks with large initializations should be able to learn faster than networks with smaller initializations, and show empirically that this is indeed the case. In addition, the authors show that this hypothesis is also true for small convolutional networks.

This paper presents a study on the problem of semi-supervised learning (SSL) in the presence of a large amount of labeled data. In particular, the authors focus on the case where the number of labeled examples is large. The authors propose two approaches to address this problem: batch-mean triplet loss and batch-triplet loss. Experiments are conducted on three benchmark datasets (CIFAR100, CIFAR-10, and ImageNet-100) to show the effectiveness of the proposed approaches.

This paper studies the problem of few-shot meta-learning in the context of sequential learning. In particular, the authors focus on the zero-shot setting, where the number of tasks is limited to a fixed number of times. The authors provide a theoretical analysis of the sample complexity and the risk minimization problem in this setting. They also provide a number of experiments to validate their theoretical findings.

This paper presents a study of the representations learned by Transformer models on NLP tasks. In particular, the authors focus on the question of how well the representations are invariant to permutations of n-grams. The authors perform a series of experiments to show that the representations of the transformer models are not invariant under permutation permutation, but rather invariant across different permutations. In addition, they show that there is a correlation between the representation invariance and the distance between the representations.

This paper proposes a new GAN architecture for the few-shot image synthesis task. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a skip-skip-layer channel-wise excitation module and a self-supervised discriminator for the feature encoder and discriminator. The proposed architecture is shown to achieve state-of-the-art performance on several benchmarks.

This paper proposes a new method to speed up the verification of neural network bounds. The main idea is to use a dual dual solver, where one of the two solvers is trained on top of the other, and the second solver is used to verify the bounds of the first solver. The authors show that this leads to a significant speedup in the verification speed-up.

This paper proposes a new pre-training framework for self-supervised learning based on commonsense knowledge. Specifically, the authors propose a new concept-aware language model (CALM) framework that leverages the generative and contrastive objectives to improve the performance of the pre-trained language models (PTLMs) on the NLU and NLG tasks. The authors also propose a framework for fine-tuning the PTLM on the text-to-text transformer and external knowledge graphs.
