This paper presents a study of object discovery in a video-to-video setting, where the goal is to discover objects that are partially occluded and interact with the camera. The paper proposes to use pixel-level and pixel-scale pixel cues for object discovery, as well as pixel-resolution cues for pixel-based object detection. The authors conduct a series of experiments to evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper presents a method for improving the robustness of deep neural networks against white-box adversarial attacks. The method is based on the idea of increasing the margin of adversarial training. The authors show that their method is able to improve the accuracy of classification accuracy and robustness to adversarial perturbations on the CT image dataset.

This paper studies the problem of knowledge distillation in deep neural networks. In particular, the authors propose a new method to distill knowledge from the teacher model to the student model. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of the mirror descent technique to improve the local optimisation of the student network. The authors also provide a theoretical analysis of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new pruning method for hyper-structured neural networks (hyper-structures). The main idea is to prune the hyper-structure of the main network by using a hyper-gradient descent. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms the state-of-the-art pruning methods on CIFAR-10 and ImageNet.

This paper presents a deep reinforcement learning framework for proving higher-order logic theorem proving. The main idea is to use reinforcement learning to learn a set of propositions that can be used for proving theorems, and then use these propositions to train a probabilistic theorem prover. The authors show that this approach is able to outperform the state-of-the-art in terms of the number of proofs.

This paper studies the problem of data augmentation in machine learning tasks. The authors propose a new approach to augmenting the input data by replacing words with image data. The main idea is to replace the words in the original input data with images. The proposed approach is evaluated on several machine learning benchmarks.

This paper studies the convergence of large-width neural networks in the nonlinear and nontrivial dynamical limit. The authors provide a global convergence result for two-layer and three-layer networks. They also provide convergence guarantees for multilayer networks.

This paper proposes a new method for performing inverse reinforcement learning (IRL) based on counterfactual reasoning. The main idea is to learn a policy that can be used to explain the behavior of an expert policy. The method is evaluated on a set of simulated and real-world medical environments. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms baselines in terms of performance and cost.

This paper proposes a new method for reinforcement learning based on graph neural networks (GNNs). The main idea is to use a message-passing scheme to pass information from the graph to the action space. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms existing methods in terms of data efficiency, robustness, and generalization.

This paper proposes a new VQA challenge for visual counting tasks. The paper presents a set of tasks that are based on the concept of "related questions" (i.e., how many objects are present in an image, and how many related questions are needed to answer a given question). The paper also presents a new benchmark for this task.

This paper studies the problem of online convex optimization in the setting of model-target poisoning attacks. In particular, the authors consider the case where the target classifier is unknown, and the goal is to find an online poisoning attack that does not change the classifier. The main contribution of this paper is to provide convergence guarantees for the attack success rate.

This paper proposes a new method for point cloud point cloud learning. The main idea is to use entropy-maximizing aggregation (EMA) to improve the feature representation capacity of point cloud models. The authors show that the proposed method is able to achieve better performance on real-world resource-constrained point cloud applications.

This paper proposes a new architecture for memory-augmented neural networks (MANNs) that uses a self-attention layer to update the global context information in the token representations. The authors show that the proposed architecture outperforms the baseline model on the GLUE benchmark.

This paper proposes a new contrastive learning method for representation learning. The main idea is to learn a low-level representation of the input data, which is then used to estimate the likelihood of the network parameters. The proposed method is evaluated on several benchmark datasets.

This paper studies the robustness of neural networks against white-box and black-box adversarial attacks. The authors first show that the OMP block is robust against white box and black box attacks. Then, they show that OMP is robust to forward learning and backward perturbations. Finally, the authors provide a theoretical analysis of OMP.

This paper studies the problem of self-supervised attention in graph neural networks. In particular, the authors focus on the attention mechanism in the context of graph attention. The authors propose a new attention mechanism based on the super-GAT framework. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new graph attention model. The proposed method is evaluated on several real-world datasets and compared with several baselines.

This paper studies the problem of medical automatic diagnosis (DSMAD) in the context of reinforcement learning. In particular, the authors focus on the setting where the agent is given a set of symptoms and is asked to make a decision on which of them to be treated. The authors propose two modules: an inquiry module and an evaluation module. In the first module, the agent makes a decision about which of the symptoms should be treated, and in the second module, it evaluates the accuracy of the decision made by the agent.

This paper studies the problem of long-tailed distribution of visual classification. The authors propose a batch-wise regularization method called batch-confusion norm (BCN) to address the problem. In particular, the authors focus on fine-grained and long-tailed properties of the natural world distribution dataset. To address the long-tail problem, they propose an energy-based framework to generate the confusion strength of the head and tail categories. They also propose a network learning strategy to improve the performance of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new method for imitation learning based on variational inference. The main idea is to estimate the posterior distribution of the reward, which is then used to learn a policy that maximizes the reward. The authors show that their method is able to outperform a number of baselines on a small tabular setting.

This paper studies the problem of belief search in the context of multi-agent reinforcement learning. In particular, the authors focus on the case where the agent has access to a model of the environment, and the goal is to find a belief distribution that maximizes the probability that the agent will be able to solve the given task. The authors propose a method for learning the distribution of the belief distribution. The method is based on an auto-regressive belief search procedure, and is evaluated on a number of benchmark datasets.

This paper studies the problem of large-scale tree search in large state spaces. The authors propose a new algorithm, called MCTS, to solve the problem. The main contribution of the paper is a theoretical analysis of the trade-off between the variance of the search space and the number of trees searched. The paper shows that the variance can be controlled by the size of the state space.

This paper studies the effect of pre-training neural networks on their ability to solve mathematical reasoning tasks. In particular, the authors focus on the problem of reducing the computational cost of training a neural network to solve a given mathematical reasoning task. To this end, they propose two approaches: (1) pre-train the network on a set of tasks, and (2) train the model on a subset of these tasks.

This paper studies the problem of learning pruned neural networks with weight normalization. The authors consider the case where the weights of the network are normalized to be close to 0. They show that the convergence rate of the pruned network is $O(1/\sqrt{\sqrt{n})$ where $n$ is the number of data points and $\sqrt(n)$ is a constant. They also provide a convergence rate for the case when the weights are not normalized to zero.

This paper studies the problem of mode collapse in generative adversarial networks (GANs) and proposes a new training procedure for GANs. The main idea is to train a generative model on a set of data generated by a GAN, and then train a discriminator on top of the generated data. The discriminator is trained to predict the classifier accuracy of each data point. The authors show that the proposed method is able to outperform the baselines.

This paper studies the problem of regularization in reinforcement learning. In particular, the authors propose a new regularization method for reinforcement learning based on the concept of importance. The authors show that this regularization can be used to improve the performance of existing regularization methods.

This paper studies the problem of transfer learning from simulators to real-world robot environments. The authors propose a framework for simulating the dynamics of a real robot and then fine-tuning the learned policy in order to transfer it to the real world. The framework is based on the Cycle-Consistency Constraint (CC) constraint, which states that trajectories of a simulated robot should be consistent with the trajectory of the real robot. To this end, the authors introduce a new constraint, the cycle-consistency constraint, and show that the proposed framework is able to transfer the learned policies from the simulated to real robot domains.

This paper studies the problem of explainability of generative models. The authors propose a new framework, Shapley explainability, which is a generalization of Shapley value function. The main idea is to use Shapley values and data imputations to explain a generative model's features. They show that the proposed framework is able to explain higher-dimensional data better than Shapley model.

This paper proposes a method for deep reinforcement learning based on the observation-based autoencoder approach. The main idea is to model the agent’s decision-making process as a combination of two parts: (1) the agent learns a policy, and (2) the action-value function. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms the baselines on a number of benchmark tasks.

This paper proposes a novel contrastive learning framework for semi-supervised visual representation learning. The proposed method is based on the ImageNet linear protocol. The main contribution of the paper is the introduction of a new regularization term for the contrastive loss. The paper also proposes a new label assignment strategy for human annotation. Experiments show that the proposed method achieves state-of-the-art performance.

This paper studies the convergence rate of the multi-plicative weight update (MWU) algorithm for convex-convex-strongly-concave functions under the assumption that the objective function is strongly convex. In particular, the authors show that the learning rate of OGDA converges linearly to the optimal solution in a polynomial time in the number of iterations. The authors also show that OGDA can converge faster than OMWU under the same assumption.

This paper proposes FedUV, a federated user verification framework that trains a user-defined linear combination of user embeddings. The authors provide a theoretical analysis of the privacy and privacy-preserving properties of FedUV. They show that FedUV can be viewed as a private and secure training of user verification models. They also provide an experimental evaluation of the effectiveness of the proposed framework.

This paper studies the problem of robustness of deep neural network classifiers. In particular, the authors study the generalization of the class manifolds (CMs) in deep neural networks (DNNs) trained with random initialization. The authors show that the CMs of DNNs can be approximated by random affine subspaces, which can be used for robustness. They also provide a theoretical analysis of the effect of the dimensionality of CMs on the robustness to data corruption.

This paper studies the problem of entropy-aware RL in the context of soft actor-critic (SAC) and exploration-exploration (exploration-exploitation) methods. The authors propose a new entropy-based RL method, called Curiosity-Aware entropy aware RL (CAT-SAC), which is based on the observation that the entropy of the environment state can be used as a proxy for the state prediction error. They show that the proposed method outperforms the existing methods in the MuJoCo benchmark.

This paper proposes a meta-reinforcement learning algorithm for out-of-distribution tasks. The proposed method is based on the idea of model identification and experience relabeling (MIER). The authors show that the proposed method outperforms the baselines on a number of benchmark tasks.

This paper studies the few-shot learning (FSL) problem, where the learner is given a set of tasks to solve, and the goal is to minimize the number of samples required to solve the task. The authors propose a new method, called Eigen-reptile, to solve this problem. In particular, the authors propose to replace the gradient noise used in the original FSL problem with a noisy label noise, which can be used to guide the learning process. Empirical results show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new adversarial training method to improve the performance of ResNet-50 and its variants. The main idea is to train a batch normalization module on top of the ResNet50 model. The authors show that the proposed method is able to improve both the mean and variance of deep image features.

This paper proposes a new metric, the Variance of Gradients (VoG) metric, to evaluate the performance of machine learning models. The metric is based on the similarity between the gradients of the model and the data distribution. The authors show that the metric can be used as a proxy metric for human-in-the-loop auditing.

This paper proposes a new approach to improve the quality of generated samples in generative models by normalizing flows. Specifically, the authors propose a new method called DGf low (DGf low) that is based on the gradient flow. The authors show that the proposed method is able to improve both the quality and the efficiency of the generated samples. Experiments on synthetic, image, and text datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

This paper proposes a new benchmark for cross-lingual understanding and generation tasks. The benchmark is based on the XTREME benchmark, which consists of three tasks: text classification, sequence labeling, question answering, and cross-sequence masked language modeling. The authors conduct extensive experiments to evaluate the performance of different model architectures on the three tasks.

This paper studies the problem of active learning in the context of the ThreeDWorld (TDW) simulator. In particular, the authors focus on the question of how to motivate the learner to explore the environment in order to learn a better understanding of the physical world. To this end, they propose a new reward function that encourages exploration in the TDW simulator. The authors evaluate the proposed reward function on the three TDW games and show that it is able to improve the performance of the RL learner.

This paper studies the problem of self-supervised representation learning in the context of cross-modal and multimodal data. The authors propose a new framework for self supervised representation learning based on contrastive learning. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of pseudo-labels and cluster assignments for the representation learning. Experiments on CIFAR-10 and ImageNet-100 show the effectiveness of the proposed framework.

This paper tackles the problem of weakly supervised segmentation. The authors propose a data-driven learning approach that learns a set of pseudo-labels for each object in the segmentation space. The proposed approach is based on the idea of contrastive learning, where the goal is to learn a low-level representation of the feature space, which is then used to train a segmentation model. Experiments show that the proposed approach outperforms existing methods.

This paper proposes a new method for self-supervised learning based on contrastive learning. The main idea is to distill the knowledge from a large scale model to a small scale model, which is then used to train a smaller scale model on top of the larger scale model. The authors evaluate their method on the ImageNet dataset and show that their method outperforms the state-of-the-art methods.

This paper proposes a new approach for high-dimensional simulation-based inference (SBI) based on generative adversarial networks (GANs). In particular, the authors propose a new variational objective for the posterior estimation of high dimensional posterior distributions. The authors show that the proposed approach can be applied to a wide range of SBI benchmark problems, and demonstrate that it is able to achieve state-of-the-art results.

This paper proposes a VAE-based method for causal inference from synthetic data. The main idea is to use the VAE as a generative model to predict the effect of a treatment on the outcome of a test subject. The authors show that the proposed method is able to outperform existing methods in terms of error bounds.

This paper proposes a new benchmark for embodied reinforcement learning (RL) on real-world environments. The benchmark is based on the well-known benchmark EARL1. The paper presents a set of experiments to evaluate the impact of different types of interventions on the performance of RL algorithms on the benchmark.

This paper proposes a knowledge-aware GNN-based QA system, OpenBookQA, which is based on Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) and Graph Neural Counter (GNCs). In particular, the authors introduce KGs (knowledge graphs) as a way to represent the knowledge in the QA question answering process. The authors conduct experiments on several benchmark datasets to show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a three-stage data compression framework for deep neural networks (DNNs). The first stage compresses the representation of a DNN model in a block-wise manner, and then compresses it in an Element-wise or Block-wise way. In the second stage, the compressed representation is used to perform inference in the third stage. The authors show that the proposed method is able to achieve near-optimal inference performance on the AlexNet and VGG-16 models.

This paper proposes a new training method for neural networks. The main idea is to train a single model on top of a large network, and then train a smaller model on the top of the larger network. The idea is that the smaller model will be able to perform better than the larger model in terms of classification accuracy. The authors evaluate their method on ImageNet and VOCOCOCO datasets, and show that the proposed method outperforms existing methods.

This paper presents a method for learning temporal coherence in point cloud sequences. The method is based on the idea of learning a generative model for point cloud representation and a masking module that maps the point cloud distribution to a shape and motion representation. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms existing methods in both quantitative and qualitative evaluation.

This paper studies the problem of training object detection and detection transformers on small-scale datasets. The authors propose a new pre-training framework, called FP-DETR, which consists of two parts: 1) a self-attention transformer and 2) an encoder-only transformer. The proposed method is evaluated on COCO dataset, where it outperforms the state-of-the-art.

This paper studies the communication complexity of federated learning algorithms for convex and nonconvex optimization problems. The authors consider the convex setting, where the number of communication rounds required to solve the problem is polynomial in the dimension of the problem. They show that the communication cost can be polynomially reduced by using local SGD steps. They also provide a lower bound on the communication costs for the nonlinear setting.

This paper studies the problem of adversarial training of deep neural networks. The authors propose a new adversarial perturbation method, which is based on minimizing the curvature of the boundary between the input and the boundary of a random subspace. They show that it is possible to train a neural network with this method. They also show that the proposed method can be used to train adversarial attacks on ANNs.

This paper proposes a new contrastive learning method for representation learning based on the idea of augmenting representations with auxiliary information. In particular, the authors propose to augment the original representation with the information from the downstream labels. The authors show that the proposed method is able to outperform existing representation learning methods in terms of the number of supervised and unsupervised representations.

This paper studies the generalization ability of iterative sparse recovery algorithms. The main contribution of this paper is the analysis of generalization properties of the iterative sparse recovery algorithm. In particular, the authors show that the algorithm can generalize to a distribution of interest. The authors also provide a theoretical analysis of the generalizability of the algorithm.

This paper proposes a new action representation space for reinforcement learning (RL) algorithms. The proposed action space is composed of discrete and continuous action embeddings. The authors show that this space can be used to improve the performance of RL algorithms.

This paper studies the energy stability property of the stochastic gradient descent (SGD) method in the nonconvex setting. In particular, the authors show that the convergence rate of SGD converges to a stationary point at a rate of $\Omega(1/\sqrt{T})$, where $\mathcal{T}$ is the number of iterations. The authors also show that in the online convex setting, SGD is energy-stable.

This paper studies the problem of training non-autoregressive (NAR) models on data without distillation and human-level accuracy. The authors propose a framework for training NAR models with distillation, which is based on the MLMC framework. The proposed framework is evaluated on three datasets: CIFAR-10, MNIST and CelebA.

This paper studies the problem of training neural networks in a low power fashion. The main contribution is to propose a new neural network architecture, called WaveNet, that can be used to train a neural network with a fixed time-constant and a fixed number of iterations. The authors show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve state-of-the-art performance on a variety of benchmarks.

This paper studies the problem of fairness in machine learning. The authors propose a new dataset of university entrance exams to study the fairness of machine learning algorithms. They provide behavioral and fairness guarantees for the proposed dataset. They also provide a new algorithm that achieves high confidence in fairness guarantees.

This paper studies the problem of solving stochastic dual dynamic programming (SDDP) problems in a low-dimensional space. The authors propose a neural model-based approach to solve the problem and provide a theoretical analysis of the complexity of solving the problem. The main result is a lower bound on the worst-case complexity of the problem, which is shown to be polynomial in the dimensionality of the low-dimension space.

This paper studies the problem of group differentially private next-token prediction in the context of language models. The authors propose a data-dependent privacy accounting mechanism that allows them to recover the privacy of the next token prediction. They also provide a theoretical analysis of their approach.

This paper proposes a new method for label smoothing based on the k-nearest neighbor (k-NN) density estimator. The authors show that the proposed method is more robust than existing methods. They also provide a theoretical analysis of their method. Finally, the authors conduct experiments on synthetic and real-world datasets to verify their claims.

This paper proposes a new denoising score matching objective for representation learning. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new score matching framework, which can be applied to a variety of existing methods. The authors show that the proposed method can achieve state-of-the-art performance on several datasets.

This paper studies the problem of goal-conditioned reinforcement learning. The authors propose a new method for goal conditioned reinforcement learning, called C-Planning, which is based on graph search. C-planning consists of two steps: (1) graph search, and (2) classifier planning. The method is evaluated on a number of goal conditioned RL tasks, and compared to several baselines.

This paper proposes a new regularization technique for training deep neural networks. The main idea is to use mixup regularization to improve the robustness against adversarial perturbations. The authors show that the proposed regularization can be applied to both global and local data structures. In particular, they show that it can improve the generalization ability of the network.

This paper studies the problem of model-efficient classifiers in deep neural networks. In particular, the authors focus on the non-linearity of the classifier in the embedding layer of the network. The authors show that the nonlinearity can lead to better performance than the linearity in the classification layer.

This paper studies the problem of data augmentation in graph neural networks (GNNs) for fairness. In particular, the authors focus on the question of how to improve the fairness of the representation learned by GNNs. To this end, this paper proposes a data-augmentation framework, which is based on the idea of contrastive learning. Experiments are conducted on a variety of datasets to show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies the problem of treatment effect estimation in two-stage regression. In particular, the authors focus on the nonlinear setting where the confounders and treatment distributions are non-convex and non-linear, respectively. Under this setting, they propose a new algorithm,CB-IV, to estimate the treatment effect under the multiplicative assumption and under the separability assumption. They also provide theoretical analysis on the bias-variance trade-off of the proposed algorithm.

This paper studies the problem of few-shot image classification in a non-adaptive learning setting. The authors propose a two-layer neural network to solve the MAML objective. The proposed method is evaluated on both easy and hard tasks.

This paper studies the problem of source separation in multispectral sensing. The authors propose a new algorithm, called LPALM, that unrolls source separation methods in a data-driven manner. They show that the proposed method can achieve state-of-the-art performance on several real-world applications. They also provide a theoretical analysis of the hyperparameters of the algorithm.

This paper proposes a new transformer-based self-attention module for the Legendre Memory Unit based model. The main idea is to learn a power-law relationship between the model size and the memory length. The authors show that the proposed model is able to achieve better performance than previous models.

This paper proposes a new method for keypoint detection in GANs. Specifically, the authors propose a two-stage GAN-based method, where the first stage generates a latent space and the second stage generates keypoints. The keypoint embeddings are then used to train the GAN. Experiments show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies the problem of normalization in fully-connected neural networks. In particular, the authors propose a new normalization scheme for deep neural networks, which they call "initialization variances", which is a modification of the standard normalization. The authors show that the proposed normalization is more robust to perturbations than existing normalization techniques. They also provide a non-perturbative analysis of signal propagation.

This paper proposes a new method for training deep learning models. The main idea is to search for the optimal update step size for each iteration of the training process. The authors show that the step size can be controlled by the number of iterations and the learning rate schedule. They also show that their method is more robust to noise in the training data.

This paper studies the noise-contrastive estimation (NCE) method. The authors propose a new loss landscape for the NCE method, which they call the "exponential loss landscape". The authors show that the loss landscape can be decomposed into two parts: (1) the flat loss landscape, and (2) the normalized gradient descent landscape. The paper also provides a theoretical analysis of the convergence rate of the proposed loss landscape.

This paper studies the problem of differential privacy (DP) in distributed machine learning. In particular, the authors study the convergence of the distributed SGD algorithm with respect to the number of data points. The main contribution of this paper is to show that under certain assumptions, the convergence rate of SGD can be bounded by a constant factor.

This paper proposes a deep learning approach to tackle the problem of code editing. The authors propose a method to measure the similarity between code snippet editing patterns and tree representations. They also propose a similarity-ranking error estimator and a sample matching method. They evaluate their approach on the C# and Python datasets.

This paper studies the problem of generating high-level and low-level coherence in a generative model. The authors propose a framework to capture high level and low level coherence of the generated sequence data. The framework is based on a program synthesis algorithm, where the goal is to generate a sequence of sequences that satisfy a set of constraints. The main contribution of the paper is to show that the proposed framework is able to achieve this goal.

This paper studies the problem of learning hypergraphs from scratch. The authors propose a new training method for hypergraph learning. The main idea is to train a hypergraph model on top of a set of hypergraph training data, and then use the learned hypergraph to solve the hypergraph prediction task. The proposed method is evaluated on several benchmark datasets, and the authors show that the proposed method can achieve state-of-the-art performance.

This paper studies the problem of gender bias in deep learning. The authors propose a method to mitigate gender bias by using the Mises-Fisher loss. In particular, the authors show that the proposed method is able to mitigate the bias in the embedding space of deep learning models. They also provide a theoretical analysis of the effect of the bias on the performance of deep embedding models.

This paper studies the problem of class-incremental learning (CIL), where the goal is to improve the performance of existing CIL methods on higher-resolution datasets. The authors propose a new benchmark for CIL, called ImageNet-1k, which is designed to evaluate existing methods on CIL. They show that existing methods are not able to achieve the state-of-the-art performance on this new benchmark. They also show that there is a trade-off between the quality of the new data and the accuracy of the old data.

This paper studies the problem of learning energy-based models (EBMs) from high dimensional discrete data. The authors propose a new algorithm, called MCMC, to learn discrete EBMs by sampling from discrete distributions. The proposed algorithm is based on the idea of sampling from a discrete distribution using a chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) algorithm. The main contribution of this paper is to provide a theoretical analysis of the proposed algorithm, which shows that it converges to the optimal solution with high probability. Empirical results are provided to support the theoretical analysis.

This paper presents a method for learning representations of video features from sequence data. The method is based on the Variational Predictive Routing (VPR) framework, which is a model-based reinforcement learning framework that learns representations of representations from sequence and event data. In particular, the proposed method learns a representation for each event in the sequence using a generative model, and then uses the learned representation to predict the next event. The proposed method is evaluated on a variety of video datasets and compared against several baselines.

This paper studies the problem of feature learning in the context of image retrieval. In particular, the authors propose a new method, called RANSAC, to learn global features and local features in a supervised manner. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a global feature matching algorithm and a local feature matching method. The proposed method is evaluated on both the Oxford and Paris datasets.

This paper studies the problem of negative transfer in multi-label classification. The authors propose a new method to solve this problem. The proposed method is based on the Pytorch framework. The main contribution of this paper is that it proposes a new gradient direction to solve the negative transfer problem. Experiments show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies the problem of model fusion in the context of dynamic programming, where the goal is to align the weights of two neural networks trained on the same dataset. The authors propose a framework to solve this problem. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new dataset, called CIFAR-10, which is composed of two datasets, one for teacher-student training and one for student-teacher training.

This paper studies the problem of generalization in deep reinforcement learning (RL) and proposes a regularization term to improve the generalization performance of deep RL methods. Specifically, the authors propose a regularizer that encourages the network to learn representations that are similar to the representations learned in the supervised learning setting. The authors show that the proposed regularizer improves the performance of several existing deep RL algorithms.

This paper studies the problem of learning hyper-model-based RL algorithms in the context of hyper-learning. In particular, the authors focus on the case where the hypermodel is a non-linear neural network. The authors propose a new hyper-algorithm, HyperDQN, which is based on a combination of the hyper-base RL algorithm and the randomized exploration method. They show that the proposed algorithm outperforms the baselines in terms of human-normalized score and exploration efficiency.

This paper studies the problem of representation learning in the presence of adversarial attacks. In particular, the authors focus on the case of causal graphs, where the causal graph is constructed from a set of data points and the goal is to learn a representation that maximizes the mutual information between the causal graphs and the data points. The authors provide a theoretical analysis of the generalization ability of the learned representation. They also provide empirical evidence that the representation learned by the proposed method is more generalizable than other representation learning methods.

This paper proposes a new training framework for federated learning. The main idea is to use gradient compression to reduce the communication cost. The authors show that the proposed method is able to achieve state-of-the-art results on medical image segmentation and classification tasks.

This paper studies the problem of training deep neural networks with adversarial attacks. The authors propose a method to train two-layer neural networks in adversarial settings. The main contribution of this paper is to show that the Rademacher complexity of the weights can be bounded by the number of adversarial examples. The paper also provides a theoretical analysis of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new method for generating synthetic data for the task of fine-tuning the entropy estimation of differential entropy. The method is based on the idea that the entropy of the data can be decomposed into two parts: the first part is the original entropy and the second part is a modified version of it. The authors show that the proposed method is able to achieve better results than existing methods.

This paper studies the problem of suboptimality gap in reinforcement learning with soft-greedy operators. In particular, the authors propose a new hyperparameter, softmax, which is defined as the ratio of the state-space to the action-value space. The authors show that the softmax can be used as a proxy for the optimal policy, and provide a theoretical analysis of the gap between softmax and softmax policy. They also provide empirical results on tabular and deep RL.

This paper studies the problem of unauthorized exploitation of deep learning models. The authors propose a novel method to attack the deep learning model by applying a class-wise adversarial invertible transformation. They show that the proposed method is more effective than existing methods. They also provide a theoretical analysis to show the effectiveness of their method.

This paper proposes a new method to solve the problem of missing features in graph neural networks (GNNs). Specifically, the authors propose to solve a differential equation based on the Dirichlet energy. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms existing methods on several benchmark datasets.

This paper studies the problem of minimizing the Wasserstein distance between two sets of data points in a supervised learning problem. The authors propose a new algorithm, called Benders Decomposition algorithm, to solve this problem. In particular, the proposed algorithm is based on the idea of discretizing the distance between the two sets. Theoretical analysis is provided to show the convergence rate of the algorithm. Empirical results are provided to support the theoretical analysis.

This paper proposes a new method for genome assembly using graph convolutional neural networks. In particular, the authors propose a new search algorithm that is based on the topology of the graph. The authors show that the proposed method is faster than the existing methods in terms of assembly speed. They also show that their method can be combined with handcrafted techniques.

This paper studies the problem of forgetting in meta-learning. The authors propose an online-aware meta learning algorithm that learns representations that are more robust to forgetting in the offline setting. In particular, the authors propose a new meta-training method that learns a representation that is more resilient to forgetting. The proposed method is evaluated on several benchmark datasets and compared with several baselines.

This paper studies the problem of multi-agent joint Q-learning in deep neural networks. In particular, the authors consider the credit assignment problem, where the goal is to assign credit to agents for solving a given task. The authors propose two methods to solve this problem. One is centralized training with centralized execution (CTDE) and the other is decentralized training with decentralized execution (CDE). The authors show that the proposed methods outperform the state-of-the-art methods.

This paper studies the problem of adversarial robustness in the context of model space attack. The authors propose a new framework, called Greedy Model Space Attack (GMSA) framework, which aims to improve the robustness of the model space against adversarial attacks. GMSA is based on the observation that models that are more robust to adversarial perturbations are more likely to be attacked. To this end, the authors introduce a new attack objective, named AutoAttack, which is a modification of the existing AutoAttack framework. Experimental results show that GMSA achieves better robustness than AutoAttack.

This paper studies the problem of training neural networks on small minibatches. The authors propose a new training procedure, which is based on a combination of normalization and batch normalization. In particular, the authors propose to train a neural network on a subset of the minibatch at each step of the training process, and then apply normalization to the entire training process. Experiments on CIFAR-10 and ImageNet show that the proposed method outperforms the baselines.

This paper studies the problem of large-scale pre-training and fine-tuning of language models in the context of low-rank classification tasks. The authors propose a new architecture, GPT-3, that can be used to train a language model on a large number of downstream tasks. They show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve state-of-the-art performance on a variety of tasks.

This paper studies the problem of regular-constrained CRF (RegCCRF) models with non-local dependencies. The authors propose a new framework for training CRF models with global constraints. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of global constraints, which is a generalization of previous work on CRFs with local constraints. In particular, the authors show that global constraints do not necessarily imply local constraints, and the authors provide a theoretical analysis of the effect of the global constraints on the performance of RegCCRF models.

This paper studies the problem of reducing the computational cost of a video-to-video model in order to improve the performance of the model. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new “endto-end” network for video models. The network consists of two components: a “normalization network” and an “encoder-decoder network,” where the encoder and decoder are trained on the same video frame, and the decoder is trained on a different video frame at each time step. The authors show that the proposed network is able to achieve comparable performance to the state-of-the-art models.

This paper studies the problem of hardware-aware latency pruning (HALP), which aims to reduce the latency of the network architecture. The authors propose a new metric, the "latency reduction potential", which is a combination of the saliency score and the accuracy drop. The paper also proposes a new pruning method to reduce latency. The experiments show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes an energy-based model for molecular graph generation. The authors propose a new energy-invariant and multi-objective molecule generation method. The main idea is to replace the standard energy function with an energy function that is invariant to permutation invariance. The proposed method is evaluated on several benchmark datasets.

This paper studies the problem of program synthesis in deep neural networks. In particular, the authors focus on the search space blowup problem. The main contribution of this paper is to provide a theoretical analysis of the space explosion problem in the deep neural network search space. The authors show that the space expansion problem can be decomposed into two parts. The first part is an optimization problem, and the second part is a program synthesis problem.

This paper proposes a new method for improving the performance of target-network based reinforcement learning methods. The main idea is to change the target Q-values in the training phase, instead of using the squared Bellman error as a regularizer. The authors show that the proposed method is more efficient than existing methods in terms of sample efficiency.

This paper studies the problem of learning graph neural networks (GNNs) from graph data. The authors propose a new task, the message-passing GNN learning task, which is a variant of the well-known Lehman test. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new graph neural network model, called GNN-SNN, which can be viewed as a generalization of GNNs. The proposed method is evaluated on several benchmark datasets, and the results show that the proposed method outperforms existing methods.

This paper proposes a new method for improving the predictive uncertainty quantification (PI) of neural networks (NNs). The main idea is to replace the standard mean squared error loss with a new loss function that is more sensitive to the hyperparameters of the neural network. The authors show that the proposed method is able to achieve better performance than existing methods.

This paper studies the problem of meta-learning in the online setting, where the goal is to solve a set of tasks in an online setting. The authors propose a new algorithm, FOML, to solve this problem. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a novel notion of task boundaries, which allows the algorithm to adapt to new tasks more efficiently. Experiments are conducted on the MNIST and CIFAR100 datasets.

This paper proposes a new method for the optimization of functional molecules based on graph neural networks (GNNs). The main idea is to use a differentiable scaffolding tree (DST) to represent the graph structure of a molecule as a set of nodes in the GNN. The authors show that the proposed method is able to achieve better results than existing methods.

This paper proposes a knowledge-augmented approach for real-world datasets to improve the accuracy of drug-lab interactions. In particular, the authors propose a knowledge augmentation approach that augments the representation of the real world data with the information from the synthetic data. The authors show that the proposed approach is able to reduce the error in the prediction error of the test responses.

This paper studies the problem of single domain generalization (SDG) in the multi-binary classifier setting. In particular, the authors focus on the cross-domain generalization setting, where the source domain is unknown and the target domain is known. The authors propose a novel data augmentation strategy, CrossMatch, to improve the generalization performance of the source and target domains. Extensive experiments are conducted to validate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes two new trust-region methods for policy optimization in reinforcement learning. The first method, Wasserstein-Sinkhorn policy optimization (WPO), is based on the duality between the policy gradient and the policy distribution. The second method, Sinkhorn-Wasserstein trust region (SPO), is a combination of WPO and SPO with a regularizer. The authors show that the proposed methods outperform the baselines on a variety of RL tasks.

This paper studies the problem of forgetting and relearning in the context of continual learning. The authors propose a framework for learning trajectories that can be used for both human and machine learning. In particular, they focus on the forgetting-and-reluarn framework, where the goal is to learn a sequence of operations that are similar to the previous one, but with the goal of avoiding forgetting undesirable information.

This paper studies the problem of data-collecting RL agents in the online setting. The authors propose a data-free RL setting, where the agent is allowed to collect data from a large number of agents in an online manner. They show that in this setting, there is a trade-off between coverage and data collection. They also provide a theoretical analysis of the tradeoff between the coverage tradeoff and the data collection tradeoff.

This paper studies the problem of domain generalization (DG) in the context of domain invariant learning. The authors propose a new generalization bound based on PAC-style generalization bounds. They show that the new bound matches the existing bounds in terms of the discrepancy between the source and target domains. They also provide a new algorithm to achieve the new bounds.

This paper studies the problem of learning a policy and value network for two-player reinforcement learning in a combinatorial search space. In particular, the authors focus on the best-first search and policy-value search algorithms. The authors show that these algorithms are heavy-tailed in the search space, and propose a new algorithm to solve the problem.

This paper presents a meta-imitation learning approach to learn from human demonstrations. The authors propose a meta learning approach that learns a policy that learns to imitate human behavior from a dataset of human demonstrations, and then uses the learned policy to solve a set of vision-based tasks. The proposed approach is evaluated on a variety of tasks, and compared to a number of baselines.

This paper studies the problem of hyper-parameter tuning in deep neural networks. In particular, the authors focus on the generalization performance of gradient-based optimizers. The authors propose a new regularization regularization term to improve the performance of the network weights. They also provide a theoretical analysis of the effect of the regularization on the performance.

This paper studies the problem of equivariant networks for natural image classification. In particular, the authors propose a method to train a network that can learn both partial and full equivariances. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new network architecture that can be used for both partial equivariance as well as full equivariancy. Experiments on MNIST and CIFAR-10 show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new method for inference of latent variables from large-scale datasets. The main idea is to use a latent variable model to approximate the distribution of the data. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms existing methods in terms of inference speed and inference accuracy. They also show that their method is faster than existing methods.

This paper proposes a method for hypergraph neural networks to improve their performance on large-scale knowledge graphs. The method is based on the idea that hypergraphs can be represented as tensors, which can be decomposed into subgraphs. The authors show that the proposed method is able to achieve better performance than existing methods on several benchmark datasets.

This paper presents a study of the top-k classification accuracy of the ImageNet classification model. The authors show that top-1 accuracy and top-5 accuracy can be achieved by differentiable sorting and ranking models. In addition, the authors also show that the classification accuracy can also be improved by using differentiable classification models.

This paper studies the problem of solving a convex optimization problem with convex regularization. In particular, the authors consider the case where the objective function is convex and the goal is to find a solution to the convex hull of the problem. The authors propose a new regularization scheme, which is based on the Douglas-Rachford splitting technique. They show that their method converges to the solution in polynomial time.

This paper studies the problem of generalization in federated learning. In particular, the authors focus on the participation gap and out-of-sample gap. The authors conduct a series of experiments on both natural and synthetic federated datasets. They also conduct a real-world simulation to verify their findings.

This paper studies the problem of fine-tuning pre-trained language models (PLMs) in the zero-shot setting. In particular, the authors focus on the few-shot learning setting, where the goal is to improve the model's generalization ability on a subset of the dataset. The authors propose two objectives: (1) self-supervised finetuning, and (2) automatically created prompts.

This paper proposes a new attention mechanism for real-world scene text recognition tasks. The proposed attention mechanism is based on a combination of soft attention and hard attention. The authors also propose a new module, called sharpener module, to improve the performance of the soft attention mechanism. Experiments show that the proposed method outperforms the baseline methods.

This paper studies the problem of vehicle routing in the presence of a limited number of vehicles. The authors propose a deep reinforcement learning-based approach to solve this problem. The main idea is to use reinforcement learning to learn to predict the number of available vehicles in the vehicle routing problem, and then use this prediction to train a reinforcement learning algorithm to solve the problem. Experiments show that the proposed approach outperforms the state-of-the-art approaches.

This paper proposes a new link prediction method based on the clustering effect. The proposed method is evaluated on several benchmark datasets and compared with several baselines. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms the baselines in terms of prediction accuracy.

This paper proposes a novel feature selection method for graph segmentation. The proposed method is based on contrastive disTillation (SOFT) model, which is a combination of self-supervised and unsupervised feature selection methods. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of the second-order covariance matrix and the attention matrix for feature selection. Experiments show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies the relationship between multimodal variational autoencoders (VAEs) and their representations. The authors propose a new metric to measure the similarity between the representations of multi-modal VAEs (MEME) and show that it can be used to evaluate the quality of the representation learned by the model. They also provide a theoretical analysis of the relation between data and representations. Finally, the authors conduct experiments to show the effectiveness of the proposed metric.

This paper studies the problem of exploration in deep reinforcement learning. In particular, the authors focus on intrinsic and extrinsic reward learning in the context of hard and easy exploration games. The authors propose a new exploration strategy for hard exploration games, and show that it outperforms the baselines in terms of reward complexity. They also show that the intrinsic reward learning algorithm can outperform the baseline in some cases.

This paper proposes a new neural network architecture for three-body problem solving. The main idea is to use a neural network to distinguish between the hard and soft parts of the problem. The authors show that the proposed architecture outperforms existing methods in terms of accuracy and time integration.

This paper presents a method for generating realistic language models for multi-step computations in computer programs. The method is based on the idea that a program can be represented as a sequence of programs, where each program is represented by a set of programs that can be solved in a given number of steps. The authors show that the proposed method can be used to generate programs that are computationally efficient.

This paper studies the problem of adversarial attacks on deep neural networks. The authors propose a new adversarial attack framework, which is based on adversarial perturbations on feature-level adversarial examples. They show that the proposed method can be used to generate adversarial images that are similar to the original image. They also show that their method is robust to adversarial misclassification attacks.

This paper studies the problem of simulated annealing (SA) in continuous variable problems. In particular, the authors focus on the stochastic global optimisation problem and propose a new method to solve it. The main contribution of the paper is the introduction of a new global optimizer for solving the problem. The authors also provide a theoretical analysis of the proposed method.

This paper studies the problem of non-stationarity in multi-agent reinforcement learning. In particular, the authors focus on the trust-region decomposition problem and propose a new algorithm to solve it. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new metric to measure the divergence between two agents' policies. The authors show that the new metric can be used to improve the convergence rate of the algorithm.

This paper proposes a self-supervised representation learning framework for audio-visual speech representation learning. The main idea is to combine audio and visual information in the video representation. The proposed method is evaluated on multi-stream video input, self-training, and automatic speech recognition. Experiments show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies the problem of learning a graph neural network (GNN) to solve the maximum cut problem in reinforcement learning (RL). The main contribution of this paper is to provide a theoretical analysis of the tradeoff between speed and scalability of RL algorithms. The authors show that the speed tradeoff depends on the number of instances in the problem, and the gap between the optimal solution and the solution of the cut problem. In addition, the authors also provide some empirical evidence to support their theoretical findings.

This paper studies the problem of zero-shot learning in VAEs. The authors propose a new approach to training VAEs that is based on discrete optimization. The main contribution of the paper is the introduction of a new variational method for training VAE models. The paper also proposes a new sampling-based approximation trick for training the model. Experiments are conducted to show the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

This paper proposes a new method for controllable reinforcement learning based on the controlled effect network (CEN) framework. The main idea is to learn an action-prediction model that can be used to predict the effect of an action. The authors also propose a new motivator to motivate the agent to learn the action. Experiments are conducted on the MuJoCo environment.

This paper proposes a new network pruning technique, called SRP, which is based on regularized pruning (SRP) to reduce the size of the weights and filters of the neural networks. The authors show that the proposed method can reduce the model size and the number of filters in the network significantly. Experiments are conducted on CIFAR-10 and ImageNet datasets to demonstrate the effectiveness of the method.

This paper studies the problem of cross-domain few-shot learning. The authors propose a new benchmark for this problem. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of novel novel category data, which allows the authors to improve the performance of existing meta-learning methods on the new benchmark.

This paper studies the generalization error of neural networks in the context of Bayesian inference. In particular, the authors focus on the case where the number of neurons in the network is infinite. In this case, they show that the test error of the network can be expressed as a function of the width of the neural network. They also show that if the width is large enough, the error can be approximated by a function that depends on the width.

This paper studies the cross-lingual representation discrepancy between multilingual representations and text understanding tasks on the X-Mixup benchmark. The authors use a large scale pre-trained multilingual representation learning model and a large-scale multilingual translation model to evaluate the performance of X-mixup and X-text-to-text transfer methods. They find that the two methods are not able to match each other in terms of performance. They also find that there is a significant discrepancy in the performance between the two models.

This paper studies the problem of distributed and federated robust learning in the presence of non-iid datasets. The authors propose a new approach to solve this problem, which they call Byzantine robust distributed or federated learning. In particular, they show that under certain assumptions, the proposed approach converges to the optimal solution with high probability. They also provide theoretical guarantees for the convergence of their approach.

This paper studies the problem of disentangled representation learning in multi-task learning. The authors propose a new metric for disentanglement based on the number of parameters shared across tasks. They show that this metric can be used to evaluate the quality of the representations learned by a neural network. They also show that the proposed metric is more robust to the amount of parameter sharing.

This paper studies the problem of robustness certification in reinforcement learning. In particular, the authors propose a new framework, called CROP, to certify the robustness of a policy to adversarial perturbations. The authors also propose a local smoothing approach to improve the performance of the policy. Empirical results show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies the problem of classifying a set of candidate candidates in a large-scale language processing task. In particular, the authors focus on the case where the number of candidates is large and the task size is large. In this setting, they show that it is possible to achieve a positive rate in terms of the amount of uncertainty in the candidate set. They also show that this is also possible in the case of a user-specified tolerance.

This paper studies the length distortion of the outputs of ReLU networks with random initialization. In particular, the authors show that the curve of the output of a ReLU network can be decomposed into two parts: the first part is the unit-length curve, and the second part is a higher-order term. The authors also provide a lower bound on the length of the curve.

This paper studies the problem of learning safety-critical robotic grasping skills in the context of reinforcement learning. In particular, the authors focus on the setting where the goal is to learn a safe and successful policy. The authors propose a method to learn safety skills using contrastive training. The method is evaluated on a set of robotic grasping tasks and compared to a number of baselines.

This paper proposes a multi-branch architecture for image restoration tasks. The main idea is to train a model with multiple branches, each of which is trained on a different set of tasks, and then fine-tune a single branch on each task. The authors show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve state-of-the-art results on a variety of tasks.

This paper studies the problem of data heterogeneity in personalized federated learning (PFL) and proposes a new approach to address it. In particular, the authors focus on the hypernetwork module and the encoder module. They provide a theoretical analysis on the privacy and generalization error of the proposed approach. They also provide empirical results on benchmark datasets to show the effectiveness of their approach.

This paper proposes a new generative model (RCDM) for self-supervised representation learning. RCDM is based on a diffusion-based model, which is able to generate representations that are more expressive than the previous state-of-the-art models. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new representation learning framework, which can be used to improve the performance of existing models. Experiments show that the proposed method can achieve better performance than existing methods.

This paper studies the problem of differential privacy in the streaming setting. The main contribution of this paper is to provide a new baseline for the well-known well-celebrated streaming algorithm (Fp sketch) in the non-private setting. In particular, the authors show that under certain assumptions on the privacy guarantee, the proposed algorithm is differentially private. In addition, they also provide a lower bound on the error of the algorithm.

This paper proposes a novel reward-switching policy optimization method for multi-agent reinforcement learning. The proposed method is based on the idea of novelty measurement, which measures the diversity of trajectories in the environment. The authors evaluate the proposed method on the MuJoCo continuous control benchmark and the StarCraftII benchmark, and show that it outperforms the baselines.

This paper proposes a new method to improve the quality of samples generated by Gaussian Diffusion Models (GGDM). The method is based on a modification of the gradient descent trick, which allows for faster sampling of samples from the diffusion model. The authors show that the proposed method is able to achieve state-of-the-art results on DDSS and DDIM datasets.

This paper studies the relationship between the embedding layer of large language models (LLMs) and human annotated data. In particular, the authors focus on the question-answering model (LLM) and the classifier (MoE) models. The authors show that the embeddings of the two models are correlated in terms of human-annotated data, and that the human annotators are more likely to answer natural language queries.

This paper proposes a new continuous classification of time series (CCTS) task. The authors propose an adaptive multi-distribution extraction policy that adaptively adapts to new data distributions. They also propose an importance-based replay policy to adapt the division rule. Experiments on real-world datasets show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies the problem of language modeling in the context of webtexts. The authors propose a new benchmark for this problem. The benchmark consists of a set of three tasks: (1) lookup lookup, (2) language modeling, (3) webtext generation, and (4) text generation. The main contribution of the paper is the introduction of the new benchmark and the evaluation of the model performance on the three tasks.

This paper proposes a new language modeling objective, called Masked Language Modeling (MLM), which aims to improve the quality of machine translation. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new sampling scheme based on the Hastings Monte Carlo algorithm. The authors show that the proposed sampling scheme is more tractable than the previous sampling scheme, which is based on open-ended unconditional generation.

This paper studies the problem of data augmentation in NLP tasks. The authors propose a new data-augmentation strategy based on data re-weighting. They show that the proposed method outperforms the baselines in the low-data and class-imbalanced regimes. They also provide a theoretical analysis of their method.

This paper studies the problem of meta-learning in the context-based reinforcement learning setting. In particular, the authors focus on the task representation learning setting, where the goal is to learn an encoder that can be used in conjunction with a task-specific encoder. The authors propose a contrastive learning objective that encourages the encoder to learn representations that are similar to the representation learned by the task encoder, while at the same time being different from the representation learnt by the decoder.

This paper proposes a framework for improving the performance of sequential sequential generative modeling methods by fine-tuning the model parameters during training. The framework is based on the idea of improving the state-of-the-art model parameters in the context of perfect-information games. The authors provide a theoretical analysis of the proposed framework and provide empirical results on several benchmark datasets.

This paper proposes a new sparsity pattern for MLP-Mixer and GPT-2 models. The proposed sparsity mask is based on a combination of block and flat butterfly matrices. The authors show that the proposed method significantly reduces the training time and improves the accuracy.

This paper proposes a new score-based generative model for image generation. The proposed model is based on a Markov chain model with a diffusion probabilistic model. The authors show that the proposed model can achieve better performance than the state-of-the-art methods on CIFAR-10 dataset.

This paper studies the problem of domain generalization (DG) in the context of domain-invariant hypothesis testing. The authors propose a set of tasks to evaluate the generalization capacity of existing DG methods. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new benchmark for domain invariant hypotheses testing, which is a combination of two existing benchmarks, one for domain generalisation and one for label prediction.

This paper studies the problem of multiquadratic convergence of the kernel thinning (KT) algorithm. In particular, the authors consider the case of non-smooth kernels and power kernels. The authors prove the maximum mean discrepancy (MMD) guarantees for the square root kernel, power kernel, and differential equation posteriors. In addition, they prove the dimension-free guarantees for both power kernels and kernels.

This paper presents a benchmark suite of open-source benchmark problems for graph neural networks (GNNs) for solving NP-hard optimization problems. The benchmark is designed to evaluate the quality of GNNs for solving these problems, as well as the performance of existing solvers for solving them. The authors show that the current state-of-the-art GNN solvers struggle to solve the benchmark problems. They also show that there is a tradeoff between the quality and efficiency of the solutions.

This paper proposes a method to reduce the bit quantization rate of convolutional neural networks (CNNs) in order to improve their accuracy and reduce the compression ratio. The authors propose to use the Haar-wavelet transformers to compress the activation map and segmentation maps. The proposed method is evaluated on several image-to-image tasks such as segmentation accuracy and depth prediction. The results show that the proposed method outperforms the baseline methods.

This paper studies the problem of learning dynamics in games. In particular, the authors focus on the case where the learner has access to a fixed point strategy, and the goal is to learn a strategy that minimizes the regret of the learned strategy. The authors consider both normal-form and coarse correlated equilibria. In the former case, they show that the learned dynamics converges to a correlated equilibrium, and in the latter case they prove that the learning dynamics converge to a coarse correlated equilibrium.

This paper proposes a new method for action-based reinforcement learning (RL) based on continuous action space exploration. The main idea is to learn the action-value function in a continuous action-space, which is then used to train a deep RL algorithm. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms existing methods on a number of benchmarks.

This paper proposes a style augmentation (AdvStyle) approach for semantic segmentation. AdvStyle augmentation is based on adversarial training, where an adversarial model is trained to generate stylized images that are more similar to the source image than the target image. Experiments show that the proposed approach improves the performance of the model on several benchmark datasets.

This paper proposes a new gesture recognition system based on the dynamic vision sensor (DVS) dataset. The main contribution of the paper is the introduction of a latent space representation of the gesture data, which can be used to train a generative model for mid-air gesture recognition systems. The proposed method is evaluated on the DVSGesture dataset, and compared against several state-of-the-art gesture recognition methods.

This paper studies the problem of deep learning on the internet of things (IoT). The authors propose a new benchmark, PyTorch, to evaluate the performance of different deep learning methods. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new framework for deep learning based on hyper-hierarchical representation learning (S-HTE). The proposed framework is based on the idea that the representation learned by a neural network can be used to guide the inference of other neural networks. The authors show that the proposed framework outperforms existing methods on both the classification and regression benchmarks.

This paper studies the problem of action Q-learning in the context of reinforcement learning (RL). The authors propose a new action-based RL method, LAQ, that learns the value function of a state-only RL agent. The main contribution of the paper is the introduction of a latent-variable future prediction model, which allows the agent to learn a value function that can be used as a proxy for the true value function. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms the state-of-the-art value function learning methods.

This paper proposes a model-parallel training algorithm for distributed training of large models. The main idea is to train a pre-emptible T4 GPU on top of a large pre-trained Transformer language model. The authors show that the proposed algorithm is able to achieve better performance than the state-of-the-art model parallelism algorithms.

This paper studies the problem of decentralized multi-agent reinforcement learning in the offline setting. In particular, the authors focus on the issue of uncoordinated and suboptimal policies. To address this problem, they propose two strategies: (1) online transition correction (OTC) and (2) rank-based prioritization. They show that these two strategies can be combined to improve the sample efficiency of offline RL.

This paper studies the problem of biased quantization in deep neural network training. The authors propose a new method to reduce the quantization footprint in the forward and backward phases of training. In particular, the authors propose an unbiased quantization (LUQ) method, which is based on the idea of minimizing the logarithmic difference between the quantized loss and the gradients of the neural network weights. Experiments on CIFAR-10 and ImageNet-50 datasets show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies the problem of meta-learning in the setting where the learner has access to a large number of features, and the goal is to select a subset of these features that are most relevant to the task at hand. The authors propose a method to identify the subset of features that have the highest importance for the task, and then use these features to train a meta-learner that is able to solve the task.

This paper studies the problem of multi-agent reinforcement learning in the context of continuous communication. In particular, the authors focus on the question of how to train agents to communicate with each other in a continuous communication environment. To this end, the paper proposes a new environment and training methodology, which is based on deep Q-learning. Experiments show that the proposed method outperforms the baselines.

This paper studies backdoor attacks on NLP models. The authors show that backdoor attacks can be used to transfer information from a pre-trained NLP model to a downstream model. They also show that the backdoor attacks are more effective than the standard backdoor attacks.

This paper studies the problem of unsupervised skill discovery in RL. In particular, the authors focus on the setting where the goal is to discover a set of skills that improve the agent's ability to solve a given task. The authors propose a framework to discover skills in both evolving and static environments. The framework is based on a combination of two existing approaches: (1) skill discovery based on reinforcement learning (RL) and (2) reward-based RL. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new framework that combines these two approaches.

This paper proposes a new convolutional neural network architecture, named LPSC, which is based on a quadrilateral convolution kernel and a single-layer receptive field. The authors show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve state-of-the-art performance on a variety of tasks.

This paper studies the information complexity of IIW compression in deep learning. In particular, the authors show that the generalization error is bounded by a non-vacuous function of the number of training examples and the batch size. The authors also provide an algorithm that compresses the weights of the posterior in the training phase.

This paper studies the problem of data poisoning attacks on feature extractors. The authors propose a new data poisoning attack that is linear separable and adversarial. They show that the proposed attack can be used to improve the performance of the feature extractor.

This paper studies the problem of overfitting in online reinforcement learning. In particular, the authors focus on the overfitting phenomenon, i.e., overfitting occurs when the number of samples is too large. The authors propose a new algorithm to address this problem. The main idea is to use the per-state-neighborhood normalization condition, which is similar to the one used in the offline RL literature. Theoretical analysis is provided to support the proposed algorithm. Empirical results are provided to show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies the problem of few-shot language embedding learning, where the goal is to learn a language model that can be used in a sequence of zero-shot learning tasks. The authors propose a new embedding function that is based on the idea that the embedding space of the language model should be similar to that of the embeddings of the target language model. The paper shows that the proposed embedding model is able to generalize well to new language models.

This paper presents a quantitative and qualitative study of the performance of visual captioning models on object captioning (NOC) datasets. The authors conduct both quantitative analysis and qualitative analysis to evaluate the quality of the models' performance on the NOC dataset. They find that the models do not significantly improve their performance on NOC datasets. They also show that the model's performance is not significantly worse than that of human baseline.

This paper studies the problem of few-shot learning in the setting where the learner only has access to a small number of training examples.
