In particular, the authors study the robustness against L_0, L_2 and L_L2 adversarial perturbations. The authors show that the adversarial attack can be used to generate adversarial examples that are adversarial in the sense that they can fool the neural network. In addition, they show that a decision-based attack can also be used as an adversarial example.

This paper proposes a new normalization method for weight matrices in GANs. The main idea is to decompose the weight matrix into two parts: the first part is the singular value decomposition and the second part is a regularizer. The authors show that the two parts can be combined to reduce the variance of the weights. Experiments on three datasets show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new method for deep Q-learning based on the Anderson Accelerated Value Iteration (A2VI) algorithm. The main idea is to accelerate the value iteration of the policy evaluation. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms the existing methods in a number of experiments.

This paper studies the problem of incremental learning in the presence of catastrophic forgetting. The authors propose a new method to solve the problem. The proposed method is based on the idea that the forgetting problem is caused by the fact that the learned model is not able to distinguish between the previous and the new tasks. To solve this problem, the authors propose two regularizers, one based on gradient descent and the other based on a vector machine (SVM). The authors show that the proposed method outperforms the baselines on several benchmark datasets.

This paper proposes a new metric for measuring the selectivity of representations in neural networks (NNs). The proposed metric is based on the activation maximization (AM) metric, which measures the difference between the top-class and top-unit selectivity. The authors show that the proposed metric can be used to evaluate the performance of RNNs and NNs.

This paper studies the community detection problem in graph neural networks (GNNs) from a learning perspective. In particular, the authors focus on the stochastic block model setting and propose a new algorithm for community detection based on the non-backtracking operator. The authors also provide a theoretical analysis of the optimization landscape of GNNs. Experiments on several real-world datasets show the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm.

This paper studies the problem of dictionary learning. The authors propose a new algorithm for dictionary learning based on a combination of linear and non-linear operations. The main contribution of the paper is to provide a theoretical analysis of the convergence rate of the proposed algorithm. In particular, the authors show that the rate of convergence is bounded by the number of words in the dictionary.

This paper studies the problem of multi-indexing and similarity search in the context of image retrieval. The authors propose a new loss function, which is based on the log likelihood loss, to improve the performance of existing methods. In particular, the authors show that the proposed loss can be used to reduce the number of queries required to solve the task.

This paper studies the problem of hypernetworks for neural network topology prediction. The authors propose a new hypernetwork architecture search method, called Graph HyperNetwork (GHN), which is based on the idea of early stopping. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new architecture search algorithm, called GHN-NAS, which can be applied to any task-specific neural networks topology. Experiments are conducted on CIFAR-10 and ImageNet datasets to show the effectiveness of GHN.

This paper proposes a new method for continual control tasks. The main idea is to use a generative adversarial imitation learning (GAN) framework to learn a policy that is able to learn from a large number of expert demonstrations. The method is evaluated on a variety of continuous control tasks, and the results show that the proposed method outperforms baselines.

This paper studies the problem of invertibility in neural networks. In particular, the authors focus on the inverse problem, i.e., how to estimate the latent variables of a neural network from a given set of observations. The authors propose a new method to solve this problem, which is based on the idea of minimizing the inverse of the output of the neural network. The main contribution of the paper is the theoretical analysis of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new mixture model approach for deep neural networks (NNs). The main idea is to use a mixture model to estimate the uncertainty of the input data, which is then used to train a neural network to predict the distribution of the weights of the mixture components. The authors show that the proposed approach is able to outperform existing approaches in terms of accuracy and uncertainty estimation.

This paper proposes a new method to reduce the memory footprint of neural networks. The main idea is to use a variational distribution to represent the weights of the neural network weights. The authors show that the proposed method can achieve better compression rates than existing methods. They also provide a theoretical lower bound on the information-theoretic lower bound.

This paper proposes a differentiable NAS algorithm for differentiating between different hyper-network architectures. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of hardware-aware neural network specialization, which aims to improve the transferability of large-scale tasks to small-scale benchmarks. The paper also proposes a new differentiable hardware objective, which is differentiable and differentiable. The experiments show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies the problem of minimizing a two-player min-max game in the dual dual setting. In this setting, the goal is to minimize the sum of the minima of the two players. The main contribution of this paper is to provide an algorithm for solving the dual problem in the non-convex setting. The algorithm is based on a second-order penalty that penalizes the first player for playing more than the second player. The authors show that the proposed algorithm is provably optimal in the convex setting and provably provable in the large-data setting.

This paper proposes a new method for sampling discrete latent variables from a generative model. The main idea is to use a continuous-continuous-relaxation (CLR) method, which is a generalization of continuous-discrete variate schemes. In particular, the authors show that the proposed method can be viewed as an extension of a previous method, RWS. The authors also provide a theoretical analysis of the convergence of their method.

This paper proposes a new reward function for training prediction energy networks (SPENs) that is non-differentiable and non-uniform. The proposed reward function is based on gradient-based search. The authors show that the proposed reward can be used to improve the performance of SPENs on the output prediction tasks.

This paper proposes a framework for active learning in multi-task learning from a policy search perspective. In particular, the authors propose a new framework called EffAcTS, which is based on an active learning framework. The authors show that the proposed framework is able to improve the sample efficiency and transferrability of the learned policies. The proposed method is evaluated on a number of continuous control tasks.

This paper studies the problem of non-linear value function approximation in reinforcement learning. The authors propose a two-timescale network (TTN) based algorithm for nonlinear Q-learning. The main contribution of the paper is a theoretical analysis of the convergence rate of the proposed algorithm.

This paper presents a method for learning semantic content for reinforcement learning agents. The method is based on the idea of planning with semantic regularities, where the agent is given a set of visual inputs and a goal-conditioned model of the environment. The goal is to learn a sub-policy that is able to navigate through the environment and reach the goal. The proposed method is evaluated on the House3D environment, where it is shown that the proposed method outperforms the baselines.

This paper studies the problem of multi-task perception-related basic knowledge in the context of driving. To this end, the authors propose a new dataset and a new method to train deep learning models on it. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms the baselines in terms of sucess rate and generalization ability.

This paper studies the problem of robustness against adversarial perturbations. The authors propose a new metric to measure robustness to adversarial attacks. The metric is based on the similarity between the feature representation of the perturbed data and that of the original data. They show that this metric can be used to evaluate the robustness of a classifier.

This paper proposes a new method for training deep neural networks. The main idea is to train a neural network with a local learning rule and a reverse-mode automatic differentiation method. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms the state-of-the-art gradient-based training methods on CIFAR-10 and ImageNet.

This paper studies the problem of black-box adversarial attacks against deep learning models. The authors propose a new method to generate adversarial examples that can be used to speed up the convergence of the gradient estimators. The method is based on the idea that the adversarial example generation process can be decomposed into two steps. The first step is to estimate the gradient of the gradients, and the second one is to compute the gradient information of gradient estimates. The proposed method is evaluated on MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets.

This paper proposes a new method for fine-tuning neural networks for deep learning applications. The proposed method is based on multi-iply accumulate (MAC) operations. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms the existing methods on CIFAR-10 and Cifar-100 datasets.

This paper studies the problem of adversarial attacks on automatic speech recognition (ASR) systems. The authors propose a new adversarial attack method based on the concept of temporal dependency. They show that the proposed method is able to generate adversarial examples that can be used to fool ASR systems. They also show that their method can be combined with existing techniques to improve the robustness of the ASR system.

This paper studies the representation learning problem of multi-object image datasets. The authors propose a generative model to learn the representation of multiple objects from a single image. The model is trained on a set of multiobject datasets, and the goal is to learn a representation that is consistent with the reference distribution of the objects in the dataset. The main contribution of this paper is to show that the representation learned by the model is similar to that of the reference dataset.

This paper proposes a new approach for disentangling representations in the context of adversarial learning. The approach is based on a variational autoencoders (VAE) model that is trained on a set of reference images. The authors show that the proposed approach is able to learn disentangled representations in a supervised manner. They also show that their approach outperforms the baselines in terms of disentanglement accuracy.

This paper presents a meta-learning approach for online reinforcement learning. The main idea is to use a model-based reinforcement learning algorithm to adapt the parameters of a neural network to new tasks. The authors show that the proposed method is able to outperform a number of baselines on a variety of tasks.

This paper studies the problem of persistent state staleness in reinforcement learning (RL) agents in the context of DQN. The authors propose a new training strategy for RL agents based on prioritized experience replay. They show that it is possible to improve the performance of RL agents by prioritizing experience replay in the training process. They also show that the proposed strategy can improve the representation drift of the agent.

This paper studies the problem of multi-agent coordination in basketball. The authors propose a generative model to model the interactions between agents in the basketball game. The proposed model is based on a combination of two existing models, one of which is an autoregressive model and the other is a hierarchical model. The main contribution of the paper is the introduction of a new framework for modeling the interactions of agents in basketball games. The model is evaluated in both quantitative and qualitative settings.

This paper presents a method for learning a game engine that is able to predict trajectories of basketball trajectories. The method is based on a combination of a vision model and a dynamical model. The model is trained on a dataset of real-world trajectories from a basketball game. The goal is to generate trajectories that can be used by an agent to predict the outcome of the game.

This paper proposes a method for end-to-end training of deep neural networks for black-box functions. The main idea is to train a deep neural network to estimate the black box function and then replace it with its non-differentiable counterpart. The authors show that the proposed method is able to outperform the state-of-the-art methods.

This paper presents a meta-learning method for few-shot regression tasks. The authors propose a data-driven inductive bias based on gradient descent. They also propose a non-parametric variant of the gradient descent method. Experiments on mini-ImageNet benchmark show that the proposed method outperforms the baselines.

This paper proposes a meta-learning method for learning sub-class hierarchies for image classification tasks. The proposed method, MAXL, is based on the idea that the sub-classes of the image classification task should be hierarchically defined. The authors also propose a multi-task evaluator to evaluate the performance of the proposed method. Extensive experiments are conducted to demonstrate the effectiveness of the method.

This paper studies the open set recognition problem in representation learning. The authors propose a new representation learning method based on neural network based representation learning, and show that it is able to achieve state-of-the-art results on several datasets.

This paper studies the problem of fine-tuning low-precision deep neural networks on the ImageNet classification benchmark. The authors propose a method to improve the accuracy and area efficiency of the network by minimizing the variance of the gradient estimates. To this end, the authors propose two techniques: (1) a new loss function based on the similarity between the input and the output of the model, and (2) an additional loss term that penalizes the variance in the gradient estimate. The proposed method is evaluated on the VGG-16bn classification benchmark and compared with several baseline methods.

This paper presents a new dataset for the physics inference module (PIM) for 3D 3D collision prediction. The dataset consists of a set of 3D trajectories collected from a pre-collision 3D physics simulation. The goal of the paper is to predict the physical properties of the trajectories, which are then used as input to a post-bounce trajectory prediction model.

This paper studies the vulnerability of neural networks to adversarial perturbations. The authors show that the network's weight distribution is not invariant to the size of the perturbation, but it is invariant only to the norm of the input image. They also show that this invariance does not hold for large networks.

This paper proposes a framework for curiosity-driven reinforcement learning, where the goal is to learn an agent model that can be used to solve a given task. The proposed framework is based on the idea that the agent model should be able to infer the state of the environment from the observation of the agent. The authors show that the proposed framework outperforms the baselines in a number of experiments.

This paper studies the activation sensitivities of artificial neural networks (ANNs) in the context of biological neural networks. The authors show that the activation function of ANNs can be decomposed into two factors: 1) the number of activations, and 2) the activation frequency. They show that these two factors are related to the activations of biological neurons. They also show that ANNs with different activation frequencies can have different activations.

This paper proposes a new framework for self-supervised speech synthesis. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new training strategy to improve the quality of the synthesized speech. The authors show that the proposed method is able to achieve state-of-the-art performance on multilingual speech synthesis datasets.

This paper studies the problem of hyperparameter optimization in the context of bilevel programming. In particular, the authors focus on the overfitting problem in the case of gradient-based algorithms. The main contribution of this paper is the analysis of the regularization terms in the outer and inner levels. The authors show that these terms are necessary and sufficient to ensure uniform stability and generalization properties.

This paper proposes a new knowledge distillation approach for the transfer of dark knowledge from teacher models to student models. The main idea is to train a student model on top of a teacher model, and then transfer the knowledge from the student model to the teacher model. The authors provide a theoretical analysis of the proposed approach, and show that the proposed method can achieve better performance than existing methods.

This paper studies the problem of generalization error bounds for OOD machine learning. The main contribution of the paper is a theoretical analysis of the invariant feature selection module of the OOD learning algorithm. The authors show that invariant features can be used to improve the generalization performance of OOD generalization algorithms. The theoretical analysis is based on the assumption that the invariance of the features is invariant to the model selection criterion.

This paper studies the problem of forgetting in dynamic Gaussian mixture models. In particular, the authors focus on the non-stationary distribution and propose a new method called Dynamic Gaussian Mixture Model (VC-BML) to address this problem. The proposed method is based on variational inference and a point estimation method. Experiments show that the proposed method outperforms the state-of-the-art methods.

This paper studies the problem of boundary value problem solvers for non-probabilistic algorithms. In particular, the authors focus on the first-order and higher-order boundary value problems. The authors provide a theoretical analysis of the convergence rate of the solver for the first order boundary value solver, and show that it converges in polynomial time to the optimal solution. In addition, they show that for the higher order problem, the algorithm converges to the optimum solution in linear time. Finally, they provide numerical experiments to support their theoretical results.

This paper studies the problem of reward-mixing in reinforcement learning, where the goal is to learn a policy that is close to the optimal policy in the state-action space. The authors propose an algorithm to solve this problem in a polynomial-time algorithm. They also provide a theoretical analysis of their algorithm.

This paper studies the problem of estimating the average treatment effect of interventions in a multi-causal setting. The authors propose a two-step procedure to estimate the effect of a single intervention on the average of all interventions. The proposed method is based on the idea that the average effect of an intervention can be decomposed into two parts: (1) the average impact of each intervention and (2) the impact of the intervention on a subset of the population. The main contribution of this paper is to provide a theoretical analysis of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new neural operator learning method based on multi-wavelet polynomial bases. The main idea is to learn the kernel of the operator by solving the korteweg-de-vries (KdV) equation, which is a time-varying version of the stochastic flow equation. The authors show that the proposed method is able to achieve state-of-the-art results on a variety of tasks.

This paper studies the problem of training a neural network to approximate the sign function in the frequency domain. The authors propose a new method that is based on the idea of backpropagation. The main contribution of this paper is to provide a theoretical analysis of the convergence rate of the proposed method. In particular, the authors show that the method converges to the optimal solution in the high-frequency domain.

This paper studies the problem of multi-area neural networks (RNNs) in the context of task-specific neural networks. The authors propose a novel architecture constraint that forces RNNs to be able to represent task-relevant information in multiple areas. They show that this constraint leads to improved performance on a variety of tasks.

This paper presents a study of the accuracy of attention graphs (SAGs) and saliency maps (SAGs) in the context of self-supervised learning. Specifically, the authors study the performance of SAGs and attention maps on a variety of datasets. The authors show that the quality of the attention maps is highly correlated with accuracy of the classifier. They also show that there is a trade-off between accuracy and quality of attention maps. Finally, they provide a set of counterfactual questions that can be used to evaluate the accuracy.

This paper studies the problem of learning invariant features of convolutional neural networks. To this end, the authors propose a set of regularizers and regularization functions to improve the accuracy of the learned representations. The authors also propose a new set of hyperparameter combinations to further improve the performance. Experiments show the effectiveness of the proposed methods.

This paper proposes a new training strategy for neural information processing systems (NIS) based on backpropagation through time (SBTT). The main idea is to train a generative model of low-dimensional population dynamics in a limited bandwidth, high-frequency time window. The authors show that the proposed method is able to improve the performance of NIS on a variety of datasets.

This paper presents a method to learn a sequence-to-sequence prediction model for small-scale machine translation tasks. The method is based on a combination of two approaches: (1) a generative model of the grammar and (2) a parameterization of the derivation rules. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms the baselines on the SCAN task.

This paper studies the problem of feature selection in high dimensional regression problems. The authors propose a new algorithm for feature selection based on the Elastic Net framework. The main contribution of the paper is a theoretical analysis of the performance of the proposed algorithm in the high dimensional setting.

This paper studies the problem of principal component analysis (PCA) for Gaussian Cox processes. The main contribution of this paper is to provide a theoretical analysis of FPCA in the case of point process data. In particular, the authors show that the principal components of a point process can be decomposed into two parts, one of which is the principal component of the input point process and the other one is that of the output point process. The authors also provide some numerical experiments to support their theoretical results.

This paper studies the problem of online meta-adaptive control (OMAC) in the context of multi-task reinforcement learning. The authors propose an algorithm that learns a representation of the environment, which is then used to train a non-linear control system. They provide convergence guarantees for their algorithm. They also provide a theoretical analysis of the convergence of the algorithm.

This paper proposes a new method for certifying robustness of neural networks. The main idea is to train a neural network with a batch normalization (BN) layer followed by a batch bound propagation (IBP) layer. The authors also propose a new initialization method for the BN layer. Experiments on CIFAR-10 and ImageNet show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies the problem of change point detection in the context of adversarial attacks. In particular, the authors focus on the $\epsilon$-contamination framework, where the goal is to detect a change point in the data distribution. The main contribution of this paper is to provide a lower bound on the probability of detection of such a change in the noise distribution. In addition, a novel algorithm is proposed to detect such change points.

This paper studies the problem of sample-based learning in the context of stochastic queries (SQ). In particular, the authors propose a new algorithm, SGD-SQ, which is based on the idea of sampling samples from a differentiable model. The authors show that the proposed algorithm is able to achieve state-of-the-art performance on a variety of datasets.

This paper studies the problem of minimizing the Wasserstein distance between a probability distribution and a data distribution. The authors propose a new algorithm based on the Lloyd-type algorithm. The main contribution of the paper is a new proof of the poliak-ojasiewicz inequality between the distance between the data distribution and the distribution over points in the space of points. The paper also provides a new error term for the proposed algorithm.

This paper proposes a new network architecture for video action recognition. The main idea is to replace the standard convolution layer with a self-attention layer. The authors show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve state-of-the-art results on the Something-Something-V1&V2 benchmarks.

This paper studies the mean field theory for large-width neural networks. In particular, the authors prove a limit theorem for the loss function in the limit of infinite-width networks. The authors also show that the limit is global optimum in the case of multilayer networks.

This paper proposes a new training strategy for learning dynamical systems from time-series data. The main idea is to use the Hamiltonian/Lagrangian structure of the flow map to encode the internal entropy of the dynamical system. The authors show that the proposed method is able to generalize the generalization of Hamiltonian and Lagrangian dynamics to non-observable states.

This paper studies the problem of data corruption and robustness in deep learning. The authors propose a sample selection-based algorithm for fair training and robust training. The main idea is to select samples based on the quality of the training data and the robustness of the model. Experiments on synthetic and real datasets show the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm.

This paper studies the problem of out-of-domain detection in deep neural networks. In particular, the authors consider the case of Gaussian process priors and Gaussian activations. They show that under certain assumptions, the neural network weights can be decomposed into two parts. The first part is based on the ReLU activation function, and the second part is on the Fourier activation function.

This paper studies the problem of classifying Markov Decision Processes (MDPs) in mouse-based games. The authors propose a new framework for this problem. The framework is based on an autoregressive model and a reward-based reward function. The paper also proposes a student-based approach to solve the problem.

This paper proposes a new objective for deep reinforcement learning (DRL) based on the information bottleneck (IB) principle. In particular, the authors propose a novel objective, the minimum description length (MDL) objective, which aims to minimize the number of traversals required for a model to reach a given state. The authors also propose a new algorithm, the Represent And Mimic (RAMi) framework, which is able to learn an IB-optimal DRL model with a large number of steps. Experiments show that the proposed algorithm outperforms the existing state-of-the-art models.

This paper studies the dynamic structure of dynamic predictions in the context of latent information flow. The authors propose a new framework to estimate the posterior probability path distributions of future binary outcomes, which can be used for time series analysis. They also propose two methods to estimate posterior probability paths. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of the new framework, which allows for a better understanding of the dynamic structures of dynamic predictive models.

This paper studies the problem of active pure exploration in stochastic bandit environments. In particular, the authors consider the Frank-Wolfe algorithm and propose a new lower bound on the sample complexity of this problem. The authors also provide a lower bound for the number of samples required to solve the problem.

This paper proposes a new method for learning combinatorial spaces in deep generative models (DGMs). The main idea is to learn a structure-coupled kernel that encodes information about the structure of the data, and then use the learned kernel to learn the space representation. The proposed method is evaluated on several real-world benchmarks.

This paper studies the regret minimization problem in low-rank MDPs. The authors consider the setting where the reward function is a linear function of the state-action value function, and the goal is to minimize the regret of the algorithm. The main contribution of this paper is to establish a regret bound of $O(\sqrt{\sqrt{T})$ under the assumption that the Bellman error is bounded by a constant factor. The regret bound is shown to be tighter than the existing regret bound in the literature.

This paper presents a framework for learning differentiable contact and system properties from a single contact model. The key idea is to use a differentiable physics simulator to learn the contact model and the system properties simultaneously, and then use a Hamiltonian or Hamiltonian neural network to solve the differential equations. The authors show that the proposed framework is able to learn a contact model that can be used to solve a variety of optimization tasks.

This paper studies the Lipschitz constant of deep neural networks (NNs) during training. The authors show that the training dynamics of NNs can be decomposed into two parts: (1) training and training dynamics, and (2) data dependent generalization bound. In the first part, the authors propose a new training procedure, which is based on the Benevolent Training Hypothesis (BTH). In the second part, they show that NNs are able to generalize well to unseen data.

This paper studies the problem of learning a half-space from a mixture of few distributions. The authors propose a polynomial-time algorithm with sample complexity $O(\sqrt{n})$ that is independent of the number of distributions. They also show that their algorithm is invariant to the noise model.

This paper studies the problem of robustness against adversarial attacks on graph classification models. The authors propose a new adversarial attack method based on Bayesian optimisation. They show that the proposed method can be applied to a variety of graph classification tasks, including biochemistry and social network analysis. They also provide a theoretical analysis on the robustness of the proposed attack.

This paper studies the problem of online label shift adaptation in the online setting. The authors propose a new algorithm called FTL, which is based on the online gradient descent (OGD) algorithm. They provide theoretical analysis on the expected test loss and the regret bounds for the proposed algorithm. Empirical results on both simulated and real-world datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies the problem of detecting and localization of gradual changes in the distribution of data generated by a data generating model. The authors propose a new method for gradual change detection and localization. They show that the proposed method can detect gradual changes with high probability. They also provide a theoretical analysis of their method.

This paper studies the problem of blind source separation (BSS) in neural networks. In particular, the authors propose a neural network (NN) architecture for solving BSS problems. The proposed architecture is based on a biologically plausible neural network. The authors show that the proposed NN is able to solve the BSS problem in a biologically plausible manner. The main contribution of this paper is the proposed neural network architecture.

This paper studies the behavior of recurrent neural networks (RNNs) in the context of machine learning. In particular, the authors study the dynamics of two-neuron networks trained on a variety of tasks. The authors show that RNNs exhibit a diversity of behavior in the space of solutions. They also show that this diversity is correlated with the number of neurons in the network.

This paper proposes a new method for learning one-dimensional conditional distributions of covariates. The proposed method is based on conditioning on the conditional likelihood of the covariates, which is a well-studied problem in machine learning. The authors show that it is possible to learn the conditional distribution of covariate covariates in a one-step manner. The main contribution of the paper is the theoretical analysis of the proposed method, and the experimental results show the effectiveness of the method.

This paper proposes a new low-level vision-driven loss function for single-image super-resolution (SISR) networks. The proposed loss is based on a weighted combination of the MSE and L1 loss functions. The authors show that the proposed loss can be used to improve the performance of SISR networks. Experiments show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies the robustness of Bayesian generalization bounds in the presence of adversarial attacks. In particular, the authors focus on the worst-case analysis and theoretically founded analysis. The main contribution of the paper is the theoretical analysis of the bounds, which is based on the Bayesian Bayesian framework.

This paper proposes a new approach to query reasoning for knowledge graph (KG) representation learning. The authors propose a new query reasoning method based on the probabilistic Entity Representation Model (PERM) framework. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of an end-to-end objective function to solve the query reasoning problem. The proposed method is evaluated on several benchmark datasets and compared with several state-of-the-art methods.

This paper studies the problem of hyperparameter optimization in the context of few-shot meta-learning. In particular, the authors focus on the forward-mode differentiation problem and the memory scaling issue. The authors provide a theoretical analysis of the convergence rate of gradient-based methods and propose a new method based on black-box methods. Theoretical guarantees are provided for the convergence of the proposed method. Empirical results are provided to support the theoretical analysis.

This paper studies the problem of learning a sequence-to-sequence model that is consistent with human reasoning. In particular, the authors focus on the task of instruction-following, where the goal is to find a sequence of instructions that can be used to solve a given task. The authors present a set of experiments on a number of tasks, and show that the proposed method is able to match human reasoning performance on these tasks.

This paper studies the problem of continual treatment learning in the off-policy evaluation (OPE) setting, where the goal is to find the optimal treatment in a continuous setting. The authors propose a new method to solve this problem. The method is based on a combination of two techniques: (1) deep learning and (2) change point detection. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of the new method, which can be used in combination with existing OPE methods.

This paper proposes a variational inference algorithm for time-series dynamical systems. The algorithm is based on variational expectation maximization (VAE) and is applied to the Markov jump process (MJP) framework. The authors show that the proposed algorithm can be applied to a variety of real-world problems.

This paper studies the problem of recovering the spectrum of the sensing matrices from the compressed sensing problem. The authors propose two methods to recover the spectrum. The first method is based on the nonlinear inverse problem, while the second method uses the phase retrieval method. Theoretical analysis is provided to show the convergence of the proposed methods. Empirical results are provided to support the theoretical results.

This paper studies the problem of domain transferability in zero-shot learning. The authors propose a novel framework to address this problem. The proposed framework is based on the dual progressive prototype network (DPPN) framework, which is an extension of the existing Zero-Shot Learning (GZSL) framework. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of the concept of attribute-region correspondence, which can be used to improve the cross-domain transferability. Experiments show the effectiveness of the proposed framework.

This paper proposes a deep neural network-based deblurring method, GKMNet, to remove defocus blur. The proposed method is based on a scale-reconstruction-based attention module. The authors show that the proposed method achieves state-of-the-art performance on a number of vision tasks.

This paper proposes a new method for video-to-text learning based on a multi-instance InfoNCE loss. In particular, the authors propose a new loss function that is based on the cross-cross guidance contrastive learning algorithm. The authors show that the proposed method is able to outperform existing methods in terms of accuracy, storage and computation efficiency.

This paper studies the problem of overconfidence in Bayesian neural networks (BNNs) trained with ReLU features. The authors consider the case where the width of the feature space is infinite and the number of neurons in the network is infinite. They show that under certain conditions, the overconfidence of a BNN can be bounded by the ratio of its width to its depth. In particular, they show that if the width is bounded by a constant factor, then the model is overconfident.

This paper studies the problem of best-arm-identification in the bandit setting, where the goal is to identify the best arm from a set of arms. In this setting, the authors study the sample complexity and variance of the algorithm. The main contribution of the paper is a new upper bound on the variance for the best-armed bandit algorithm.

This paper provides a theoretical analysis of the convergence rate of stochastic gradient descent (SGD) algorithms with compressed gradient descent. The authors show that the rate of convergence is $O(1/\sqrt{T})$, where $T$ is the number of iterations and $\tilde{T}$ is a constant. They also provide a lower bound of $\Omega(T)$ for the rate at which the algorithm converges to the optimal solution.

This paper studies the problem of explainability in graph neural networks. The authors propose a framework to improve the explainability of graph classification models. The framework is based on the idea of multi-grained explainability, which is an important aspect of graph neural network (GNN) models. To this end, the authors propose two different approaches: pre-training and fine-tuning. The first approach is to train a GNN model on both synthetic and real-world datasets, and the second one is to fine-tune the model on the synthetic dataset. Experiments show that the proposed approach can improve the performance of GNN models.

This paper presents a study of the relationship between graph neural networks (GNNs) and human intuition. In particular, the authors focus on the question of whether GNNs can be used to provide counterfactual explanations to decision boundaries. The authors show that GNN can provide explanations that are consistent with human intuition, but that they are not always consistent with the decision boundary. They also show that there is a correlation between human intuition and decision boundaries, and that human intuition is not always aligned with the boundary of the GNN.

This paper studies the problem of self-supervised representation learning in the context of audio-to-text translation. The authors propose a new approach to tackle this problem, which is based on the use of adversarial feedback. In particular, the authors propose to use adversarial training to improve the quality of the representation learned by the speaker and the speaker-discriminator. Experiments show that the proposed approach outperforms the existing approaches.

This paper proposes a novel 3D shape-aware feature learning network for 3D object tracking in point clouds. The key idea is to learn a voxel-to-bev target localization network, which maps the 3D point cloud to a set of 3D feature maps. The proposed method is evaluated on the KITTI and nuScenes datasets, and compared with state-of-the-art methods.

This paper proposes a multi-layer perceptron-based encoding method for multi-dimensional position encoding. The proposed method is based on the Fourier feature mapping and the attention mechanism. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms the existing methods in terms of accuracy and convergence.

This paper studies the problem of verifying the independence of two sets of variables in a graph. The main contribution of this paper is to propose a new constraint-based method for this problem. The authors show that their method can achieve a lower bound on the number of variables required to satisfy the constraint. They also provide a proof of the correctness of their method.

This paper studies the problem of online multi-armed bandit in the context of information parallelism. In particular, the authors focus on the Thompson Sampling framework, where the goal is to maximize the total number of arms that can be exploited in a given batch. The authors provide a regret bound of $O(\sqrt{T})$ for this problem, where $\tilde{T}$ is the number of samples. They also provide an exponential reduction of the regret bound.

This paper studies the problem of domain adaptation (DA) and domain generalization (DG) in the context of domain invariant representation learning. In particular, the authors focus on the case where the representation is invariant to the source domain and the target domain. In this setting, they propose a new lower bound on the generalization loss that is based on the representation invariance of the source and target domains.

This paper proposes a structured structured sparsity learning (ASSL) method to reduce the model size and compute resources in neural architecture search (NASSLN) and model compression techniques. The authors propose a new regularization term for the soft mask gram matrix and pruned filter locations in the normalization layer to align the sparsity structure alignment penalty term. The proposed method achieves state-of-the-art model compression results on CIFAR-10 and ImageNet datasets.

This paper proposes a method for multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) based on a combination of exploration and exploration-based reinforcement learning. The main idea is to replace the individual Q-value function with a set of utility functions that can be used to guide exploration. The authors evaluate their method on the StarCraft II micromanagement benchmark and show that it outperforms existing MARL baselines.

This paper studies the problem of linear regression with Gaussian covariates. In particular, the authors propose a new lower bound for the stochastic query (SQ) lower bound. The authors show that the proposed lower bound is tighter than the existing lower bound in the literature. They also show that their lower bound matches the upper bound.

This paper studies the problem of learning machine-learned neural ODEs from data. The authors propose a hybrid model (LHM) approach that combines expert domain knowledge and machine learning (ML) approaches. The main contribution of the paper is the introduction of the LHM approach, which is a combination of the two approaches. Experiments show that the proposed approach outperforms the existing approaches.

This paper studies the problem of representation learning in the meta-learning setting, where the goal is to learn a representation that can be used to adapt to new tasks. The authors propose a new representation learning objective, which they call the “frozen representation learning” objective. They show that this objective can be viewed as a generalization of the MAML objective, and that it can be applied to both regression and neural network settings. They also provide a theoretical analysis of the proposed objective.

This paper presents a method for learning the compositional and grounded meaning representation of language. The main idea is to learn a compositional space of words and embed them into an embedding space, and then use the embeddings to train an algorithm to execute a symbolic program in this space. The authors show that the proposed method is able to achieve better performance than previous approaches.

This paper studies distributed stochastic convex optimization with Hessian-vector products. In particular, the authors study the convexity of the Hessian vector products objective and provide convergence guarantees for convex convex minimax problems. In addition, they also provide a convergence result for the Newton algorithm.

This paper proposes a new density-aware Chamfer Distance (DCD) metric for the point cloud completion task. The proposed metric is a generalization of the existing Chamfer distance (CD) and EMD metrics. The main contribution of the paper is the introduction of a discriminator module to improve the performance of the proposed metric. The paper also proposes a downsampling step to reduce the number of points.

This paper studies the problem of knowledge distillation and generalization in the context of networks. The authors study the problem from the perspective of a small student network and a large teacher network. They show that the student network is able to generalize better than the teacher network in terms of generalization error. They also provide a theoretical analysis of the performance of the student networks and the teacher networks.

This paper studies the problem of training a machine learning algorithm on real-world data-sets. The authors propose to use k-tree trees and parallel rectangles to train the algorithm. The main contribution is to provide a theoretical analysis of the trade-off between the number of trees and the amount of time needed to train. The paper also provides a number of experiments to verify the theoretical results.

This paper studies the problem of top-m identification in linearity and linear bandit models. The authors consider both synthetic and real-world data, and provide a lower bound on the number of samples required to solve the problem. They also provide a new algorithm that achieves the same lower bound.

This paper proposes a novel self-supervised learning method for disentangled graph representation learning. The proposed method is based on the contrastive learning framework, where the goal is to disentangle the latent factors of the graph representation. The method is evaluated on both synthetic and real-world datasets. Experiments show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies the problem of estimating the robustness of a network. The authors propose a new method to estimate the risk of a given network, which is based on the idea of splitting the network into two subsets, one for each of which is more robust than the other. They provide theoretical guarantees for their method, and show that their method can be applied to a variety of networks.

This paper proposes a framework for unsupervised image generation using deep polynomial neural networks (PNNs). In particular, the authors focus on the problem of image-to-image translation, which is a well-studied problem in machine learning. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new dataset for this problem. The dataset consists of a set of multi-variate inputs, where each variable corresponds to a different class. The authors show that the proposed framework is able to achieve state-of-the-art performance on the task.

This paper studies the two-sample test power of NTK-MMD statistic and its relation to the NTK tangent kernel (NTK) and type-I error-I test statistic. The authors provide a theoretical analysis of the power and computational complexity of the proposed statistic. They also provide empirical results on both synthetic and real-world datasets.

This paper studies the problem of adversarial detection and defense. The authors propose a new method to detect adversarial images. The key idea is to use the autoencoder G(x) to extract the class-dependent information from the adversarial perturbations. They show that the proposed method is more robust to adversarial attacks than existing methods.

This paper studies the privacy-utility trade-off in the federated Thompson sampling (FTS) algorithm. In particular, the authors study the problem of differentially private hyperparameter tuning (DP) and distributed exploration (DE) in the context of federated learning. The authors provide theoretical guarantees for the privacy and utility trade-offs of the FTS algorithm. Theoretical guarantees for DP and DE are also provided. Empirical results are provided to support the theoretical results.

This paper studies the problem of multi-label classification (MLC), where the goal is to predict the covariance matrix of a set of labels. The authors propose a variational inference algorithm for this problem, which is based on the Bernoulli mixture of label clusters. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a novel variational variational posterior inference algorithm to solve the problem. The proposed algorithm is evaluated on several real-world datasets, and the results show that the proposed algorithm outperforms the baselines.

This paper proposes a new method for non-streaming point cloud based point cloud representation learning. The proposed method is based on a polar convolutional architecture, which can be viewed as an extension of the polar coordinate system. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms existing methods in terms of latency and accuracy.

This paper studies the problem of differentiable learning in the context of latent variable models. In particular, the authors focus on the case where the latent variables are assumed to be invariant to different domains. The authors propose a new approach to learn a differentiable surrogate for the latent variable model, which is based on the Gumbel-Max trick. The main contribution of this paper is to provide a theoretical analysis of the convergence rate of the proposed approach. Experiments on synthetic and real-world datasets validate the effectiveness of the approach.

This paper studies the problem of overfitting in deep convolutional neural networks (CNNs) trained on image denoising datasets. The authors show that the overfitting problem can be alleviated by tuning the scaling parameter of the convolution layer. They show that this can be achieved by training CNNs on a small number of samples with high signal-to-noise ratios. They also show that overfitting can be mitigated by training on larger datasets.

This paper proposes a method to solve the multi-way cut optimization problem for semantic and instance segmentation (COPS) in the panoptic learning setting. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new method for solving the multiway cut problem. The method is based on a neural network architecture that is differentiable and differentiable in the sense that it is able to learn a differentiable architecture for both semantic and instances segmentation. Experiments on the Cityscapes and COCO datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new generative model for probabilistic context-free grammars (PCFGs). The main idea is to model the data as a sequence of continuous latent variables, which can be either discrete or continuous. The authors show that the proposed model is able to approximate the posterior distribution of the data likelihood (evidence) and the posterior of the probability of a point in the sequence. The paper also shows that the model is robust to the number of possible structures.

This paper studies the problem of training deep neural networks with two-bit shift weights. The authors propose a new training method, called backpropagation-based posttraining (CBP), which is based on backward propagation of errors. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of two-bits shift weights to the training process, which allows the authors to achieve better performance than previous methods.

This paper studies the problem of active learning in the context of Gaussian Process Classification (GPC). The authors propose a new active learning algorithm, EER-based active learning, which aims to improve the efficiency of the acquisition function and reduce the number of queries in the instance space. The proposed algorithm is based on gradient-based optimization techniques, and achieves state-of-the-art performance on both synthetic and real-world datasets. Experiments are conducted on both pool-based and query synthesis scenarios.

This paper studies the effect of variational autoencoder (VAE) regularization on the energy function of VAE models. The authors show that under-regularized models tend to collapse and under-bounded gradients. On the other hand, under-constrained models tend not to collapse, but instead to have large gradients, which can lead to instability. To address this issue, the authors propose a new regularization term that encourages the energy functions to be close to the original energy function, and show that this regularization leads to a more stable energy function. Experiments on MNIST and CIFAR-10 show that the proposed regularization is effective.

This paper studies the problem of convex programming with bounded integrality gap. In particular, the authors consider the following problem: given a directed graph $G$ and a set of vertices $x_i$, the goal is to find a linear program $p(x,y)$ that minimizes the sum of the integrality gaps between $g$ and $y_i$. The main result of the paper is an upper bound of $O(1/\sqrt{T})$ for this problem, where $T$ is the number of edges in $G$, and $\Omega(T)$ is a lower bound on the regret.

This paper studies the problem of explainability and robustness of feature attributions in the context of model agnostic classifiers. The authors propose a self-normalised importance sampling estimator based on Shapley values, which is a variant of the Shapley value estimator. They show that the proposed estimator is robust and explainable.

This paper studies the problem of feature representation learning in deep reinforcement learning (RL). The authors propose a new constraint on the number of state-action trajectories that need to be learned in order to ensure that the learned representation is consistent with the dynamics of the environment. In particular, the authors propose to enforce the constraint that the state representation should be consistent with that of the dynamics model. They show that this constraint leads to better performance on the Atari and DeepMind Control Suite benchmarks.

This paper studies the robustness of neural networks against noisy labels. The authors propose a framework for training neural networks with noisy labels, and show that it is possible to improve robustness by training the network with clean labels. In addition, the authors propose two methods to train neural networks that are robust to noise.

This paper proposes a data-driven Bellman equation-driven algorithm for reinforcement learning (RL) algorithms. In particular, the authors propose a two-stage algorithm, where the first stage computes the reward function, and the second stage updates the value function. The authors show that the proposed algorithm converges to the optimal solution with high probability.

This paper studies the problem of differentially private stochastic optimization in the weakly convex and non-convex setting. The main result of the paper is a lower bound on the excess population risk of the algorithm. The lower bound is based on the convexity of the loss function. The authors also provide an algorithm that achieves the same lower bound.

This paper studies the problem of cooperative bandit learning in the presence of adversarial corruptions. In particular, the authors consider the case where the reward is adversarially corrupted. In this setting, the goal is to minimize the group regret. The authors propose a new algorithm that achieves near-optimal guarantees on the regret. They also provide a network-dependent minimax lower bound for the regret of their algorithm.

This paper proposes a new quantization algorithm for vision transformers. The main idea is to replace the standard low-bit quantization with mixed-precision quantization. The authors show that the proposed method can achieve better performance than the baseline quantization algorithms. The proposed method is evaluated on the ImageNet dataset.

This paper studies the problem of double Q-learning, where the goal is to learn a sequence of Q-values in a synchronous manner. In this paper, the authors study the convergence rate of the double Q learning problem and provide a global optimum. The authors also provide a theoretical analysis of the convergence of the learning rate.

This paper studies the problem of out-of-distribution (OOD) detection in SSL settings. The authors propose a new method for OOD detection based on the idea of unzipping the labeled data in the distribution space. The proposed method is evaluated on several SSL benchmarks.

This paper proposes a multi-task training framework for visual grounding and visual reasoning tasks. The proposed framework consists of two stages: 1) a one-stage framework that trains the model on a single dataset, and 2) a two-stage setup that trains a model on multiple datasets. The authors show that the proposed framework is able to achieve state-of-the-art results on both tasks.

This paper studies the problem of weakly-supervised learning, where the learner is given a set of hypotheses, and the goal is to find the best hypothesis for each hypothesis. The authors propose a new algorithm, called Boosting algorithm, to improve the performance of weak learners. In particular, the authors show that the proposed algorithm can be applied to both weak and moderately inaccurate hypotheses. Experiments are conducted to show the effectiveness of the algorithm.

This paper presents a method for object-centric scene generation. The main idea is to use a pre-trained object segmentation model to generate a set of object representations for each object in the scene. The authors show that the proposed method is able to achieve state-of-the-art results on both simulated and real-world datasets.

This paper studies the problem of distribution shift in real-world datasets. The authors propose a new method to address this problem. The main idea is to use a conformal inference framework to infer the distribution of the data generated by the data generating process, and then use a black box method to make predictions about the distribution. The proposed method is evaluated on three real world datasets.

This paper proposes a new method for multi-person pose estimation in the presence of crowding. The method is based on two modules: (1) Pose Refinement module and (2) Part-based Pose Generation (PGPPG). The proposed method is evaluated on the OCHuman dataset. The results show that the proposed method outperforms the state-of-the-art methods.

This paper studies the problem of learning robust Markov decision processes (RMDPs) in the presence of rectangular ambiguity sets. The authors propose a general linear programming method for solving RMDPs with rectangular ambiguity. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of the Bellman operator operator, which is a generalization of the bellman operator to rectangular ambiguity set. In particular, the authors show that this operator can be solved in linear time and rectangular time. They also provide a practical implementation of the proposed method.

This paper studies the problem of online knapsack trading in a one-way trading setting, where the goal is to maximize the ratio between the total number of items and the number of rounds of trading. The authors propose a two-stage algorithm to solve this problem. The first stage consists of learning a machine-learned algorithm to predict the optimal amount of items for each round of trading, and the second stage consists in learning an algorithm to decide which items to send to which round. The paper provides a lower bound and upper bound for the ratio of the total amount of item to the total length of the arms.

This paper proposes a hybrid control-model-based approach for episodic and non-Markovian reinforcement learning. The main idea is to learn an episodic memory of trajectories, which is then used to guide the learning of a continuous control model. The authors show that the proposed approach outperforms the baselines in a variety of settings.

This paper proposes a new data programming (DP) scheme for semi-supervised learning (SSL) based on pseudo-pseudo-labels. The main idea is to replace the initial labeling functions (LFs) used in standard SSL methods with a set of pseudo-labeled data. The authors show that the proposed DP-SSL method outperforms existing SSL methods on the CIFAR-10 benchmark.

This paper proposes a multi-view Pose Transformer (MvP) model for multi-person 3D pose estimation. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a novel cross-view attention mechanism to improve the performance of the proposed model. The proposed method is evaluated on the panoptic dataset and compared with state-of-the-art methods.

This paper studies the problem of learning a vector-based sensing model that is error-free. The authors consider the case where the vectors are unknown, and the goal is to learn a vector that can be used to solve a recovery problem. The main contribution of this paper is to show that it is possible to learn such a vector with low query complexity.

This paper studies the problem of detecting abrupt changes in temporal behavior patterns. The authors propose a novel lower bound on the expected delay between the changepoint detection problem and the false alarm rate detection problem. The lower bound is based on the information theoretic lower bound of the probability distribution of probability distributions of the changepoints. They also propose a new sensing scheme based on this lower bound.

This paper studies the problem of stochastic nested optimization in the context of machine learning. The authors propose a new algorithm for solving nested nested optimization problems. The main contribution of the paper is a theoretical analysis of the convergence rate of the proposed algorithm. In particular, the authors show that the algorithm converges to the optimal solution at a rate of O(1/sqrt(n)^2/n). The authors also provide some numerical experiments to verify the theoretical results.

This paper proposes a new knowledge reasoning framework for multi-modal reasoning in the context of self-supervised learning. In particular, the authors propose a new sampling and reasoning strategy for knowledge generation and reasoning. The proposed method is evaluated on three benchmark datasets: MSRVTT-QA, MSCQA and TGIF. The results show that the proposed method outperforms the baselines.

This paper proposes a probabilistic context-free generative model (PCFG) based on the framework of hidden Markov models (HMMs). The main idea is to use a low-rank constraint on the state space of the model, which allows the model to learn a low rank representation of the latent space. The authors show that the proposed model is able to learn low rank representations with high accuracy and memory complexity.

This paper studies the exploration-exploitation trade-off in Bayesian bandits. The authors propose a novel exploration strategy based on the average average uncertainty (SAU) measure. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of the SAU-based exploration strategy, which is a new exploration strategy for Bayesian bandit. The paper also provides a theoretical analysis of the trade-offs between exploration and exploitation in the context of deep neural network models.

This paper presents a method for learning a dynamic autoencoder that decodes dynamic behavior embeddings from videos. The key idea is to use an end-to-end approach to decode behavior representations from video frames. The method is evaluated on a set of video datasets, and is shown to outperform existing methods.

This paper proposes a new method for 3D shape synthesis based on a 3D conditional generative model. The main idea is to use a signed distance function to represent the 3D surface and a differentiable marching tetrahedra layer to generate the hierarchy of subdivisions. The proposed method is evaluated on a variety of datasets.

This paper proposes a new measure of dependence between two data points, called SMI (SMI), which is a generalization of mutual information (MI) between two sets of data points. SMI can be used to test the independence of two data sets. The paper also provides a theoretical analysis of the scalability of SMI. Experiments on synthetic and real-world datasets show that SMI outperforms other measures of dependence.

This paper proposes a new unbiased unbiased estimator for Bayesian optimization (BO) problems with tight constraints. In particular, the authors propose a multi-step lookahead constrained BO method, which can be applied to both sequential and batch settings. The authors also provide a perturbation analysis of the acquisition function surface, which shows that the proposed method is more robust to perturbations than existing methods.

This paper studies the problem of multi-dimensional reinforcement learning, where the goal is to maximize the maximum mean discrepancy between the return distribution and the Bellman operator. The authors propose a new reward function, called Multi-Dimensional Distributional Distributional DQN (MD3QN), which is composed of two components: a source-specific value function and a return distribution. The main contribution of this paper is to provide a theoretical analysis of the performance of the proposed reward function. In particular, the authors show that under certain assumptions, the reward function can be approximated by a weighted sum of the source and the return distributions. They also provide an algorithm that achieves the best performance in terms of the mean discrepancy.

This paper proposes a new deep learning model for generating anatomically plausible surfaces. The main idea is to use the ODE framework to learn the topological properties of the generated surface. The authors show that the proposed method is able to generate surfaces that are topologically similar to the original surface in terms of topological errors.

This paper studies the problem of data deletion in the non-convex setting. In particular, the authors consider non-adaptive deletion algorithms, where the goal is to delete a subset of the data while preserving the privacy of the remaining data. The main contribution of this paper is to provide provable deletion guarantees in this setting.

This paper studies the risk-averse Bayes-adaptive reinforcement learning (BARL) problem in two-player stochastic games. The authors propose a new algorithm, CVaR, to learn a policy that maximizes the value at risk (CVaR) in the presence of uncertainty in the distribution of MDPs. In particular, the authors show that the optimal policy can be obtained by minimizing the risk of the MDP distribution. They also provide a theoretical analysis of the proposed algorithm.

This paper studies the problem of minimizing the population misclassification rate in deep ReLU networks. In particular, the authors consider the case where the network width is much larger than the number of classes. In this case, they show that it is possible to minimize the population risk by minimizing the multiplicative error property and the logistic risk property. The authors also provide a theoretical analysis of the convergence rate of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new method for group detection in social media. The proposed method is based on a variational inference approach, where the goal is to infer the distribution of group assignment. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms the state-of-the-art methods in both supervised and semi-supervised settings.

This paper studies the problem of generalization in deep neural networks with nonlinear data. In particular, the authors focus on the neural tangent kernel (NTK) regime, which is a special case of the generalization problem. The main contribution of this paper is to provide a generalization guarantee for deep networks in the NTK regime. The authors also provide a theoretical analysis of the properties of the network depth and width.

This paper proposes a new GAN framework for generating adversarial examples with differentiable augmentations. The main idea is to replace the softmax cross-entropy loss (ACGAN) in the original GAN with a softmax loss (CGAN). The authors show that the proposed method outperforms the original ACGAN on the Tiny-ImageNet and CUB200 datasets.

This paper studies the problem of two-player zero-sum games in which the goal is to find a Nash equilibrium in a multidimensional continuous action sequential game. In this setting, the authors propose a deep reinforcement learning algorithm that is able to converge to Nash equilibria in a finite number of iterations. The main contribution of this paper is to show that the proposed algorithm can converge faster than the state-of-the-art deep RL algorithms.

This paper proposes a variational autoencoder for graph-level unsupervised representation learning. The main idea is to learn a graph-based representation for each node in the graph, and then use this representation for classification and regression. The paper shows that the proposed method outperforms the baselines on a variety of datasets.

This paper studies the expressive power of graph neural networks (GNNs) in the context of graph signal processing (GCN) and graph topological learning (GIN). The authors show that GNNs are limited in their expressive power due to their limited scalability. To address this limitation, the authors propose a new GNN architecture, GNN-SAGE, which is able to achieve better expressive power than GCN and GIN. The authors also provide a theoretical analysis of GNN's expressive power.

This paper studies the problem of training affine-coupling flows for generative models. In particular, the authors focus on the case where the input distribution is a log-concave distribution and the goal is to minimize the likelihood of the output distribution. To this end, they propose to train a Jacobian-conditioned affine coupling flow, which is a modification of the Jacobian of the original distribution. The authors show that the proposed method can be used to train the generative model in a scalable manner.

This paper studies the problem of policy learning in the online e-commerce market. In particular, the authors propose a generalization method based on the BCORLE(λ) framework. The main contribution of this paper is the theoretical analysis of the generalization problem. The authors show that the problem can be formulated as a convex optimization problem, which can be solved efficiently. Empirical results show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies the problem of domain adaptation (DA) in the context of image and 3D point cloud recognition. In particular, the authors propose a new regularization loss to improve the consistency between the domain classifier and the target domain. The proposed method is evaluated on both image and point cloud datasets. The results show that the proposed method outperforms existing DA methods.

This paper proposes a new pooling method for learning representations from sets. The proposed method is based on the sliced-Wasserstein distance between two sets of points. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms existing pooling methods in terms of accuracy and interpretability.

This paper studies the stability of recurrent neural networks (RNNs) trained with stochastic gradient descent (SGD) and backpropagation. The authors show that RNNs trained with SGD are unstable to exploding gradients, hyperparameters exploding or exploding gradient, and that training with back-propagated SGD is more stable than SGD. To address these issues, the authors propose a new training method, RNN-SBO-RNN, which combines SGD and RNN training. Experiments are conducted on CIFAR-10 and ImageNet datasets to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies the problem of online ski rental, where the goal is to minimize the power consumption incurred by the agent. The authors consider the setting where the agent has access to a finite number of idle time slots and has to decide whether to wait for the next slot to be filled or not. In this setting, the authors propose a new algorithm for the problem and provide a worst-case guarantee. They also provide a theoretical analysis of the error of the algorithm.

This paper studies the problem of multi-source transfer learning in the context of deep neural networks. The authors propose a novel quantifiable transferability measure based on the similarity between the model complexity and the sample complexity of the source and the target tasks. They show that the proposed measure can be used to evaluate the transferability of the model. They also provide a theoretical analysis of the proposed method.

This paper studies the effect of top-down and bottom-up cues on the performance of a neural network model on the visual search task. The authors show that the model is able to generalize well to unseen images. They also show that human behavior can be used to improve the model's performance.

This paper studies the problem of training robust models in the presence of adversarial examples. In particular, the authors propose a new training method, IBP, that aims to improve the tightness of the upper bound on the worst-case loss landscape. The main contribution of the paper is the introduction of a new loss landscape, which is a generalization of the well-known loss landscape of [1] and [2].

This paper studies the problem of online ridge regression under the boundedness assumption. Under this assumption, the authors propose two algorithms that achieve high probability regret bounds. The first algorithm is based on ridge regression, and the second algorithm uses a regularization parameter to ensure robustness. Both algorithms are based on linear regression.

This paper proposes a new two-time-scale variant of the Extragradient (EG) method for solving nonconvex-concave adversarial training problems. In particular, the authors show that the proposed method achieves O(1/k) convergence rate in the convex convex nonconcex setting and O(O(1 / k) in the unconvex setting. The authors also show that their method can be combined with the existing two time-scale variants of the EG method to obtain FEG+EAG+EG.

This paper studies the problem of uniformity testing in the context of DP. The authors propose a new algorithm for the problem. The main idea is to rank the data according to the similarity between the distribution of the source and the target distribution. They show that the proposed algorithm can be used to test whether the source distribution is uniform or not. They also provide a theoretical analysis of their algorithm.

This paper studies the problem of learning directed acyclic graphs (DAGs) with sparse structure. The authors propose a score-based algorithm for learning DAGs. The main contribution of the paper is a theoretical analysis of the performance of the proposed algorithm, which is based on the GES and hill-climbing algorithms.

This paper studies the problem of adversarial robustness of convolutional neural networks (CNNs) against adversarial attacks. In particular, the authors propose a new adversarial training method to train CNNs to be robust to adversarial perturbations. The authors also propose a dilation algorithm to reduce the computational cost of training CNNs. Experiments on real-world datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies model-based reward-free reinforcement learning in continuous MDPs. In particular, the authors consider the case where the MDP is a mixture MDP, and the goal is to learn a policy that maximizes the transition probability between two states. The authors propose a new algorithm, UCRL-RFE, that achieves a lower bound of $O(1/\sqrt{T})$ and an upper bound of $\Omega(T)$ in the exploration phase and $O(\sqrt{\frac{T}{T}}(T+1/T))$ for the planning phase. In addition, they show that the algorithm can be extended to the Mixture MDP setting.

This paper proposes a new algorithm to compress the data stream of events in real-world data streams. The proposed algorithm is based on the shifting seasonal matrix factorization (SSMF) approach. The authors show that the proposed method is able to achieve better performance than the baseline methods.

This paper studies the problem of assignment learning in the setting of NP-hard and incomplete input. The authors propose a new method based on a neural network architecture to solve the problem. The main idea is to add a feature-weaving layer to the top of the neural network, which is designed to be able to handle non-linear and non-convex problems. The proposed method is evaluated on several real-world problems.

This paper studies the adversarial robustness of 3D point cloud models. The authors propose a new adversarial training baseline for self-supervised point cloud recognition. They show that the proposed baseline is robust to adversarial attacks. They also propose a proxy task to improve the robustness.

This paper studies the regret bounds of the Frank-Wolfe algorithm for submodular convex optimization problems.
