The authors show that the regret bound is $O(T^2/\sqrt{T})$, where $T$ is the dimension of the problem and $\tilde{T}$ is a constant. They also show that this regret bound matches the best known regret bound of $O(\sqrt{\frac{T}{T})$ in the continuous case.

This paper studies the problem of estimating the likelihood of a distribution over a set of points. The authors consider the case where the distribution is parameterized by an exponential family. They show that the sample complexity of the estimator is polynomial in the number of parameters. In particular, they show that for any $k$-parameter minimal exponential family, there exists a sample complexity polynomially smaller than $O(1/\sqrt{k})$ for estimating the probability of a point $x$. They also show that if $x_i$ is a probability distribution over the set $y$ of points $y$, then $O(\sqrt{\frac{k}{1/2})$ is sufficient to estimate the likelihood.

This paper presents a new differentiable renderer, DIB-R++, which combines differentiable rendering and physics-based rendering. The main contribution of the paper is the introduction of a new renderer for differentiable geometry, reflectance and lighting prediction. The paper also proposes a new method for differentiating between synthetic and real data, which is based on a differentiable framework. Experiments show that the proposed method outperforms the state-of-the-art approaches.

This paper proposes a differentiable training method for soft-argmax-based localization tasks. The main idea is to train a neural network to generate a probability map of the localization error, which is then used to guide the sampling process. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms existing methods in terms of the average error.

This paper proposes a novel contrastive learning framework based on directed graph data augmentation. In particular, the authors propose a new contrastive view augmentation method for directed graphs. The proposed method is based on the idea of perturbing the directed graph structure of the target graph. Experiments show that the proposed method outperforms state-of-the-art approaches.

This paper presents a multi-world environment learning framework for multi-task learning. The authors propose a new multi-objective multi-language learning benchmark, called ALFWorld, which is designed to compare the performance of different language learning models on different environments. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new benchmark, ALFworld, which aims to compare different language models on the same environment.

This paper proposes a new vision transformer architecture, V-MoE (V-V-E), which is a combination of vision transformer and transformer-based vision models. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new per-image routing algorithm for vision transformer. The proposed algorithm is based on the idea of multi-head convolutional neural networks. Experiments show the effectiveness of the proposed architecture.

This paper studies the optimization landscape of neural networks trained with zero training loss. In particular, the authors focus on the case where the number of neurons in the network is much larger than the sample size of the network. In this case, they show that the gradient descent descent method converges to saddle points and local minima in the landscape. They also show that if the network size is large enough, saddle points can be found.

This paper studies the problem of risk-aware multi-armed bandits in online decision making. The authors propose a novel risk minimization framework, which is based on covariance minimization and covariance decomposition. In addition, the authors provide a lower bound for the regret in the full-information feedback and feedback-feedback settings.

This paper studies the nonnegative matrix factorization (NMF) problem, which is an extension of the PSD factorization problem. In particular, the authors propose a new algorithm, MMU, to solve the NMF problem. The main contribution of this paper is to show that the MMU algorithm is a non-convex extension of Lee-Seung’s algorithm (MMU) and propose a minimization framework based on the majorization-minimization framework. Experiments on both real and synthetic data show the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm.

This paper proposes a meta-learning framework for domain generalization (DG) that combines domain-invariant and domain-specific features. The authors show that the proposed framework can learn domain invariant and domainspecific features in a unified framework. The proposed framework is evaluated on the background-colored and MNIST datasets.

This paper proposes a new method to improve the quality of the generated images in a generative model. The method is based on the idea of using a classifier to guide the generation of the samples. The authors show that the proposed method is able to achieve better quality than existing methods.

This paper studies the problem of few-shot learning in the context of generative models. The authors propose a method to train a generative model on a large number of samples from the out-of-distribution (OOD) dataset. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of the concept of "prototypes" and "feature extractors", which is a generalization of previous work in the field. The proposed method is evaluated on both inductive and transductive settings.

This paper studies the problem of prioritization in reinforcement learning. The authors propose a new prioritization strategy, which is based on the Bellman update, to improve the quality of the feedback provided to the learner. The paper also proposes a new regret minimization objective, which aims to minimize the TD error. Experiments show that the proposed strategy outperforms the baselines.

This paper studies the problem of weight sharing in a nonstationary optimization problem. The authors propose a new algorithm for weight sharing based on the idea of entropy projection step. They show that the proposed algorithm is memory-constrained and has provable long-term memory guarantees.

This paper studies the problem of finding a linear bandit in a convex geometry. The main contribution of this paper is a new algorithm for solving this problem. The algorithm is based on the cutting-plane algorithm proposed by Steiner, and it is shown that it has a regret of O(d log d) regret. The authors also show that their algorithm is tight.

This paper proposes a library of hyperparameter schemas for machine learning (AutoML) optimizers. The authors show that the hyperparameters can be translated into compositional code, which can be used to improve the performance of AutoML. They also propose a new translation scheme for AutoML optimizers, which is based on the idea of compositional programming.

This paper studies the problem of meta-learning in the context of few-shot and continual learning problems. The authors propose a new problem-by-problem basis, which allows them to study the effect of sparsity on the generalization error. They show that sparsity can lead to a bias in the learning rate, and propose a method to mitigate this bias.

This paper studies the multi-view multi-correlation analysis (MCTS) problem. The authors propose a new method, called ShICA-ML, which is based on the maximum likelihood method. The main contribution of this paper is the proposed method, which can be viewed as a variant of the Maximum-Fluid Maximum-Likelihood (MCLI) method.

This paper proposes a new multi-agent reinforcement learning framework for collaborative multi-player reinforcement learning. The proposed framework is based on the idea that agents should be aware of their human partners' preferences. The authors show that the proposed method is able to improve the performance of agents in a two-player collaborative cooking simulator.

This paper presents a novel multi-agent actor-critic method for multi-agents reinforcement learning. The authors propose a new policy gradient estimator and a factored critic for the agent Q-learning algorithm. The main contribution of the paper is the introduction of a new algorithm for the multi agent RL problem. The proposed method is evaluated on the MuJoCo benchmark.

This paper proposes a new model of biological long-term memory based on a three-factor plasticity rule. The key-value mechanism is replaced by a sequence of three factors, and the plasticity rules are replaced by two factors, one for each of the three factors. The authors show that the proposed model is able to outperform the baselines on the task of auto-associative memory.

This paper studies the problem of differentially private online gradient descent (OGD) algorithms for pairwise learning. In particular, the authors study the generalization error bounds of OGD and OGD-SGD algorithms for both smooth and nonsmooth problems. The authors also provide a theoretical analysis on the storage and computational complexity of the problem.

This paper proposes a new framework for learning dynamic objects from video data. The proposed framework is based on the 3D implicit function. The authors show that the proposed framework can be applied to both real-world video data 3DPW and calibrated videos. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new transformation module for dynamic objects.

This paper studies the problem of computing high probability bounds for linear stochastic approximation (LSA) algorithms with fixed stepsize. In particular, the authors focus on the case where the number of stepsize is polynomial in the dimension of the input matrix. The main result of the paper is an upper bound on the probability that the algorithm converges to the optimal solution. The authors also provide a lower bound for the probability of convergence of the algorithm.

This paper studies the problem of sample-based MDP learning in the four-room domain. In particular, the authors focus on the average-reward MDP setting, where the goal is to minimize the average reward over all possible trajectories. In this setting, they propose a new algorithm based on the idea of option-interrupting behavior. They also provide convergence proofs for the proposed algorithm.

This paper studies the problem of training visual transformer models for self-supervised and supervised learning. The authors propose a new training set for selfsupervised learning, where the goal is to improve the model's robustness to adversarial attacks. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of an inductive bias that encourages the model to learn local properties rather than global relations between image elements. Experiments show that the proposed method can improve the performance of the model.

This paper proposes a new method for label-free hyperbolic procrustes analysis (HPA) of hierarchical data. The method is based on the Lorentz model of the hyperboloid geometry. The authors show that the proposed method can be applied to a variety of tasks, such as batch correction and unsupervised batch effect removal.

This paper studies the problem of differentially private query answering systems. In particular, the authors consider the setting where the query is composed of a set of queries, and the goal is to answer the queries in a way that does not violate differential privacy. In this setting, the main contribution of the paper is to provide a new lower bound on the number of queries that can be answered in a differentially privacy-preserving manner. The lower bound is based on the assumption that the queries are generated from the same distribution as the query data. The authors also provide an algorithm to solve this problem.

This paper proposes a goal-conditioned reinforcement learning (RL) algorithm that learns a tree-structured curriculum of sub-tasks to solve long-horizon tasks. The main idea is to train an RL agent to solve a set of tasks that are easy to solve and hard to solve at the same time. The authors evaluate their algorithm on a variety of tasks, including navigation and continuous control tasks. They show that their algorithm outperforms baselines in terms of success rate and sample efficiency.

This paper proposes a framework for generating local explanations for black box explanations. The framework is based on the idea that the black box explanation can be viewed as a hyperparameter tuning procedure. The authors show that the hyperparameters can be tuned in such a way that the proposed framework can be applied to a variety of real-world datasets.

This paper studies the problem of energy-efficient training of deep neural networks. The authors propose a new method to improve the energy efficiency of neural networks by reducing the number of heavy tails in the feature space. Specifically, the authors propose to use the Skew Laplace distribution instead of the standard Skew-Laplace distribution for the weights of the feature distributions. They also introduce a new constraint to encourage the diversity of the weights. Experiments are conducted on CIFAR-10 and ImageNet to show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies the problem of feature imbalances in neural networks. The authors propose a new regularization method, gradient starvation, to improve the performance of feature learning dynamics. The main contribution of this paper is to provide a theoretical analysis of the gradient descent phenomenon in the context of dynamical systems theory. In particular, the authors show that under certain assumptions, the gradient starvation phenomenon can be understood as a result of the regularization of the weights of the neural network.

This paper presents a study of the performance of human-AI teaming in the cooperative card games Hanabi and StarCraft. In particular, the authors focus on the question of how well human and AI teams perform on different metrics of trust and trust-based measures. They find that the human team performs better than the AI team on a variety of metrics. They also find that rule-based and learning-based agents perform better than human agents on some metrics.

This paper proposes a new method for visual question generation (VQG) based on double visual and answer hints. The main idea is to use a similarity matching method to predict the visual region of interest for each question. The authors evaluate the quality of predicted visual hints on both formative and non-formative questions. They also evaluate the performance of the proposed method on two benchmark datasets.

This paper studies the problem of data weighting in the presence of label noise. In particular, the authors study the effect of the gradient descent step on the class-level weights. The authors propose a new algorithm, GDW, to address this problem. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of the GDW algorithm, which can be viewed as an extension of GDW. Experiments on several real-world datasets show that the proposed method outperforms existing methods.

This paper studies the problem of language grounding in the context of Transformer-based embodied agents. The authors propose a new language grounding task in which the agent is given a set of behavioral traces and is asked to learn a language model that is grounded in the behavioral traces. They show that the proposed task is able to improve the agent's generalization ability.

This paper proposes a cross-attention network (PCAN) for video instance tracking and segmentation. The main idea is to use a cross attention module to capture both foreground and background information from the video frames. The proposed method is evaluated on two datasets: Youtube-VIS and BDD100K. The results show that the proposed method outperforms the baselines.

This paper studies the problem of gradient flow in deep neural networks. The authors show that the initial value problem of the gradient flow problem can be solved in a finite number of iterations. They also provide an approximate solution for the global minimum of the problem.

This paper studies the problem of multi-armed bandits in which the goal is to minimize the regret of the agent. The authors consider both delayed and long-term impacts of historical actions. They provide a regret lower bound for both cases. They also provide an algorithm that matches the lower bound.

This paper presents a new video instance segmentation solution for video clips. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new benchmark set for video clip segmentation. The benchmark set is built on top of the YouTube-VIS 2019 dataset, and the authors show that the proposed method is able to outperform the state-of-the-art methods on the benchmark set.

This paper studies the bias in the embedding of graphs. The authors propose a new sampling method based on random walks. They show that random walks are biased in the sense that they tend to sample nodes that are closer to the edges of the graph than the edges that are further away from the edges. They also show that this bias is more pronounced when the number of nodes in the graph is large.

This paper studies the problem of estimating non-linear functionals of discrete distributions under differential privacy constraints. In particular, the authors consider the non-interactive case and the sequential interactive case. In both cases, they show that there exists a two-step procedure that can be used to estimate the functionals in both cases. In addition, they also show that under certain assumptions, there exists an upper bound on the risk of the estimator.

This paper studies the problem of multiclass classification with feedback graphs. In particular, the authors consider the case where the feedback graph is a directed graph and the goal is to minimize the regret of a multiclass algorithm. In this case, they show a regret bound of $O(\sqrt{T})$ and a lower bound of $\tilde{O}(T^{-1/2})$ on the number of classes. They also show that the regret bound can be improved to $\Omega(1/T)$.

This paper studies the problem of clustering a set of points in a space of dimension $k$ with probability at most $O(k)$. The goal is to find a clustering algorithm that minimizes the distance between any two points in the set $x_i$ and any point in $y_i$, where $y$ is the dimensionality of the set.   The authors consider the setting where $x_{i=1,2}$ points are drawn from a set $\mathcal{O}(\log k)$ and $y_{i,j}$ is a single dimension (feature).    In this setting, the authors provide lower and upper bounds on the number of points that need to be clustered in order to achieve a given clustering objective. In particular, the lower bound is $O(\sqrt{log k})$ and the upper bound is $\O(log k^2)$.

This paper studies the problem of universal dependency parsing in multilingual natural language processing tasks. The authors propose to use a pre-trained language model (PrLM) and a multilingual language modeling model (BERT) for the task. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new dataset for dependency parsing. The dataset is designed to be universal in the sense that it can be used in any language. The paper also provides a theoretical analysis of the performance of the proposed dataset.

This paper proposes a new method for improving the performance of a transformer-based method for solving vehicle routing problems (VRPs). The proposed method is based on the dual-aspect collaborativeative transformer (DACT) framework. DACT learns to encode node and positional features of a vehicle routing problem (VRP) into a sequence of cyclic sequences, which is then used to train a policy optimizer. The paper shows that the proposed method outperforms existing methods on both synthetic and benchmark instances.

This paper studies the problem of data-driven classification in the context of normalizing flows. In particular, the authors propose a new method to train a generative model that can be trained on a large number of datasets. The proposed method is based on an invertible transformation of the data distribution. The authors provide a theoretical analysis of the error of the proposed method, which shows that the error can be expressed as a sum of two quantities: the Bayes error and the log-likelihood of the distribution.

This paper studies the effect of hyperparameter choices in the initialization of neural networks on the performance of machine translation models. In particular, the authors study the impact of different initialization schemes and hyperparameters on the final performance of the model. The authors find that the hyperparametrization of the network parameters can have a significant impact on the quality of the final model.

This paper studies the problem of learning mixed-effect models in the Hilbert space. The authors propose a new approach to solve the TADPOLE challenge, which is a well-known problem in machine learning. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new framework for learning mixed effect models. The framework is based on the idea of discretizing the kernel Hilbert space into a discretization of the Euclidean space, which can be used as a basis for learning the mixed effect model. Experiments are conducted on both synthetic and real-world data.

This paper proposes a new training strategy to improve the accuracies of CNNs. The main idea is to train CNNs with a four-step training strategy. In particular, the authors propose to train the CNNs in two stages: first, the network is trained on a single image, and then, the CNN is trained with a sequence of different procedures. The authors show that the proposed training strategy improves the accuracy of the network on the CIFAR-100 benchmark.

This paper proposes a new method for enforcing symmetries in physical laws. The main idea is to introduce a new symmetrized representation of the space of physical laws, which is a product of a set of contractions and an arbitrary set of products. The authors show that this new representation can be used to enforce constraints on high-order tensor objects. They also show that their method can be applied to the Lorentz, Poincaré groups.

This paper proposes a new loss function for bbox regression. The main idea is to replace the IoU term in the regularization term of the loss function with a new term that preserves the preservingness of the original loss function. The authors show that the proposed loss function can achieve better performance than IoU-based losses.

This paper proposes a new method for reinforcement learning based on distributionally robust imitation learning (DROIL). The main idea is to use the concept of entropy in reinforcement learning to learn a policy that maximizes the entropy of the state space and action space. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms existing methods in a number of experiments.

This paper studies the individual fairness problem in post-processing algorithms. The authors propose a new algorithm based on the Laplacian regularization to solve this problem. They show that the proposed algorithm achieves better individual fairness than existing algorithms. They also provide a theoretical analysis of their algorithm.

This paper proposes a new method for cross-domain text-to-SQL query generation. The proposed method is based on the dual graph linking mechanism, where the query is represented as a graph and the query as a question. The authors show that the proposed method achieves state-of-the-art performance on the Spider benchmark.

This paper studies the relationship between discrete-stochastic models and their discrete-continuous counterparts in the context of reinforcement learning. In particular, the authors focus on the case where the discrete components of the model are discrete and the continuous components are continuous. The authors show that, in this case, the discrete component can be viewed as a discrete version of the continuous component of the discrete model. In addition, they provide a theoretical analysis of the trade-off between the size of the gradients and the number of residual connections in the discrete and continuous components.

This paper studies the problem of training Bayesian neural networks (BNNs) with high-fidelity approximate inference. In particular, the authors focus on the case of MAP training, i.e., training BNNs with a large number of training examples. They show that MAP training leads to a shift in the Bayesian model average, and propose a method to mitigate this shift.

This paper studies the problem of meta-learning in the few-shot classification setting. In particular, the authors compare the performance of different meta learning methods in the ID vs. out-of-distribution (OOD) setting. The authors show that there is a significant gap in the performance between ID and OOD settings. They also provide a theoretical analysis of the differences between the two settings.

This paper studies the open rule induction problem in the context of open knowledge base (KB) based methods. The authors propose a new method, called Orion, that learns a language model (LM-based rule generation) to generate a set of open rules that can be automatically inducted into the knowledge base. The main contribution of the paper is the proposed method, which is based on a combination of two existing methods: (1) a KB-based method, and (2) an LM-based approach. The proposed method is evaluated on several datasets and compared with the existing methods.

This paper studies the problem of multi-agent reinforcement learning in the context of constraint Q-learning. In particular, the authors consider the case where there are multiple agents, and the goal is to minimize the extrapolation error between the agents' state and action space. The authors propose a new algorithm, called ICQ, to solve this problem. The main contribution of the paper is the theoretical analysis of the proposed algorithm.

This paper studies the problem of non-uniform norm-bounded perturbation bounds for real-world adversarial examples (AEs) in machine learning models. In particular, the authors focus on the case where the data distribution is not uniform. In this case, it is assumed that the perturbations are not uniform in the sense that the norm of the perturbed data distribution does not match the uniform distribution of the original data distribution. To address this problem, the paper proposes a new method to certify the robustness of a model against adversarial attacks. Experiments are conducted to validate the effectiveness of the method.

This paper studies the convergence of self-concordant loss functions (SCFs) in the context of learning with kernels. The authors propose a new regularization scheme, called Tikhonov regularization, which is a generalization of the well-known regularization schemes. They provide a convergence analysis for the proposed method, and show that it converges to the optimal solution at a rate of $O(1/\sqrt{T})$ in the worst case.

This paper studies the problem of reducing the dimensionality of neural networks. The authors propose a new layer called Deformable Butterfly (DeBut) that can be decomposed into two parts: the connected and convolutional layers. They show that this layer can reduce the complexity of the network by a factor of $O(\sqrt{input-output dimensions})$ while maintaining the accuracy of the neural network. They also show that the complexity-accuracy tradeoff can be improved to $O(1/n^2)$, where $n$ is the number of neurons.

This paper proposes a new approach to reusability of knowledge base (KB) weights. In particular, the authors propose a new method, called Catastrophic Forgetting (CF), which is based on the idea of catastrophic forgetting. The authors show that the proposed method is able to improve the performance of KB-based knowledge base weights on the 20-split-mini-ImageNet dataset.

This paper proposes a data-driven framework for scheduling heuristics in mixed integer programming (MIP) solvers. In particular, the authors propose a heuristic-based algorithm to schedule the heuristic steps in the MIP solver. The authors show that the proposed heuristic schedule can be used in real-world applications.

This paper studies the regret minimization problem in reinforcement learning (RL) and self-driving cars. In particular, the authors consider the case where the learner has access to a parametric model of the environment, and the goal is to minimize the regret of the agent. They show that the regret is sublinear in the number of steps, and that it can be bounded by a constant factor that depends on the dimensionality of the dataset. They also provide an algorithm that achieves sublinear regret. Finally, they show that their algorithm can be applied to real-world applications.

This paper proposes a dual hypergraph transformation (DHT) method for hypergraph representation learning and graph pooling. The main idea is to learn a hypergraph embedding for each node in the hypergraph and a pooling method for the edges. The authors also propose a new message-passing technique for the graph representation learning. Experiments show that the proposed method outperforms the state-of-the-art methods.

This paper studies the problem of learning representations of data from high-dimensional observations in reinforcement learning. The authors propose a new objective that maximizes the mutual information (MI) maximization between the state representation and the action representation. They show that this objective can be used to improve the performance of RL agents in a variety of environments.

This paper proposes a new method for 6D pose and size estimation and semantic analysis for 3D objects. The proposed method is based on the idea of steerable convolution (SS-Conv) which is an extension of the previous work on 3D pose estimation. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new feature learning module, called Steering module, to improve the accuracy and efficiency of 3D object pose estimation and pose tracking. The authors show that the proposed method achieves state-of-the-art performance on both synthetic and real-world datasets.

This paper proposes a dynamic token sparsification framework for dynamic ViT models. The main idea is to prune the tokens in each layer of the model by masking the attention tokens. The authors show that the proposed method is able to achieve state-of-the-art performance on ImageNet.

This paper studies the distribution-free and distribution-distribution-free confidence intervals for data analysis problems. In particular, the authors focus on the non-vanishing-width confidence intervals in the continuous setting. The authors show that under certain assumptions, the confidence intervals can be bounded by a function of the sample size and the mean of the data distribution. They also provide some theoretical guarantees for the distribution free confidence intervals.

This paper proposes a new representation neutralization for fairness (RNF) framework to mitigate the discrimination of DNN models on task-specific classification head. Specifically, the authors propose a new method to remove biased representations and attribute annotations from the model head. The proposed method is evaluated on three benchmark datasets. The results show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new convolutional neural network (CNN) layer called Bessel-CNNs (B- CNNs) for image analysis. The main idea is to decompose the CNN layer into two parts: a convolution layer and a rotation layer. The authors show that the convolution layers can be decomposed into two components: the first component is the convolutions and the second one is the rotation layers. Experiments are conducted to show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a method for solving ridge regression on large-scale datasets. The main idea is to partition the feature space into two parts: feature space and input space, and then use ridge regression to estimate the effective dimension of each part. The authors show that the proposed method can achieve better accuracy and computational efficiency than existing methods.

This paper proposes a new method for zero-shot communication in RL. The key idea is to use one-hot communication, where the agent is given a set of tokens and the goal is to send a message to another agent that is able to decode the token. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms the baselines in terms of accuracy and communication efficiency.

This paper studies the capacity of convolutional neural networks to generalize to unseen images. The authors show that top-1 accuracy can be achieved on ImageNet-21 and COCO-3B models. They also show that the number of attention layers in the convolution layers can be reduced by reducing the size of the input image.

This paper studies the Chebyshev-Cantelli inequality in the context of Bayesian optimization. In particular, the authors show that (one-sided) versions of the inequality can be expressed in the form of a (parametric form) of the Bayes-Bayes-Bernstein inequality. In addition, they show that this form of inequality is equivalent to the second-order oracle bound of Markov's inequality. Finally, they provide an empirical estimation of the oracle bounds.

This paper presents a method for weakly supervised audio-visual video parsing. The method is based on the idea of cross-modality co-occurrence, where the goal is to provide a unified view of the two modalities in a unified way. The authors show that the proposed method is able to achieve better performance than existing approaches.

This paper studies the problem of federated learning (FL) in the presence of heterogeneous data. In particular, the authors focus on the case where the clients have different model dimensions/structures and the goal is to minimize the knowledge distillation loss. The authors propose a new personalization loss, which is a combination of the KD loss and the compressed model loss. They show that the proposed loss can be used to improve the performance of the federated FL algorithms.

This paper proposes a new framework for constrained clustering based on generative models. The proposed method, DC-GMM, leverages a generative model to learn a set of constraints on the clustering of the data. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms existing methods on a variety of real-world datasets.

This paper proposes a new neural network architecture for large-scale regression and classification tasks. The proposed architecture is based on the Neural Tangent Kernel (NTK) architecture. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of the CNTK (CNTK is a convolutional version of NTK) and the theoretical analysis of the convergence rate of the proposed method.

This paper presents a multi-person 3D motion trajectory prediction framework for long-term 3D human motion prediction. The proposed framework is composed of two parts: a global-range encoder and a local-range decoder. The global range encoder is trained to predict the human pose trajectory, while the local range decoder predicts the individual motion. The authors evaluate the performance of the proposed framework on a set of benchmark datasets.

This paper proposes a framework for reinforcement learning in a Minecraft-inspired environment. The framework is based on a model predictive program synthesis (MPPS) framework. The authors show that the proposed framework is able to solve a variety of tasks in the environment, and that it outperforms a number of baselines.

This paper studies the problem of causal imitation learning, i.e., learning to imitate the behavior of another agent in a sequential setting. The authors propose a novel criterion for the success of imitation learning. The criterion is based on the fact that the agent should be able to learn to imitate a behavior that is similar to the agent’s behavior in the sequential setting, while being able to generalize well to the continuous setting. In particular, the authors show that if the agent is able to mimic the agent's behavior in both sequential and continuous settings, then the agent can generalize better than the agent in the discrete setting.

This paper studies the problem of learning object-centric representation learning. The authors propose a new loss function for object-structured representation learning, which is based on the idea of object-level alignment. They show that this new loss can be used to improve the performance of existing object-based representation learning methods.

This paper studies the convergence of the importance sampling weighted ERM algorithm in the context of the contextual bandit algorithm. The authors provide a convergence rate of $O(1/\sqrt{T})$ for the proposed algorithm, where $T$ is the number of data points and $\tilde{T}$ is a function of $T$. The authors also provide a lower bound on the squared error of the algorithm.

This paper studies the problem of reweighting the regression model in machine learning problems. The authors propose a new approach to reweight the model, which is based on minimizing the Bures-Wasserstein distance between the regression matrix and a non-negative matrix. The main contribution of the paper is to show that the proposed approach can be used in combination with the first-order methods.

This paper studies the problem of gradient estimators for categorical variables. In particular, the authors focus on the case where the variables are categorical, i.e., the categorical gradient estimator does not depend on the latent variables. The main contribution of the paper is a theoretical analysis of the convergence of the estimators in this setting. The authors show that the leave-one-out-baseline estimator and the stick-breaking coupling estimator converge to the optimal estimator in this case.

This paper studies the problem of architectural search in NAS. The authors propose a new architecture search space, called WeakNAS, which is composed of two sub-spaces: strong and weak predictors. The strong predictor is a predictor that predicts the performance of a given architecture, while the weak predictor predicts the accuracy of the architecture. The weak predictor is an accuracy predictor, which predicts the similarity between the architecture and the prediction.

This paper proposes a new method for learning a global coordinate system that can be used for exploration in reinforcement learning. The method is based on the idea of additive latent dynamics, where the goal is to learn a latent space that is consistent with the current state and the next state. The authors show that the proposed method is able to outperform a number of baselines in a variety of environments.

This paper studies the problem of designing pharmacologically realistic and pharmacochemically acceptable molecules. To this end, the authors propose a new framework for solving the docking score optimization problem in the framework of reinforcement learning (RL). The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new scoring function for the optimization of the scoring function. The authors also introduce a new method for improving the quality of the generated molecules. Experiments are conducted on both de novo and scaffold-based schemes.

This paper studies the problem of learning directed acyclic graphical models. The authors propose a greedy greedy search algorithm to find the Markov boundary of a directed graphical model. The main contribution of this paper is to provide a finite-sample guarantee for the search procedure. The algorithm is based on the greedy search procedure proposed in [1] and is shown to converge to the boundary in polynomial time.

This paper studies the problem of differential privacy learning with differential privacy (DP) algorithms. In particular, the authors consider the setting where the learner has access to a local model and a global model, and the goal is to learn the representation of the local model. The authors provide a lower bound on the privacy of the learned representation dimension, and show that it matches the lower bound of [1] and [2]. They also provide an upper bound for the global stability of their algorithm.

This paper studies the problem of estimating the per-state expected cumulative rewards of a Markov decision process (MDP) in the context of deep neural network function approximation methods. The authors focus on the case of value iteration networks, where the value function is assumed to be a linear function of the state-action pairs. They show that SGD and its SGD-based counterpart can be used to estimate the expected cumulative reward of the MDP in this setting. They also provide a theoretical analysis of the convergence rate of SGD.

This paper proposes a method to refine knowledge graph embeddings (KGs) in the context of question answering. The method is based on the idea of learning a set of rules that can be used to refine the embedding of a KG. The authors show that the proposed method is able to improve the performance of KG-based question answering models on several benchmark datasets.

This paper studies the problem of knowledge base completion (KBC) in the context of real-world entities. The authors propose two methods to evaluate the quality of KB embedding models, one based on ranking and the other based on classification. Both methods are evaluated on a dataset of real world entities, where the goal is to find a set of entities that have the highest F1 score.

This paper studies the problem of training a language model to generate human-like responses to dialogs. To this end, the authors propose an extension of the ARDM framework, which is a pre-trained language model for dialog generation. The main contribution of the paper is the introduction of a new dataset for dialog datasets. The authors show that the proposed dataset is able to improve the performance of the language model on a variety of tasks.

This paper proposes a new loss-based confidence measure for deep neural networks. The proposed loss is based on a combination of softmax and hardmax values. The authors show that the proposed loss can be used to improve the performance of deep neural nets.

This paper studies the training dynamics of neural networks in the hyperparameter space. In particular, the authors consider the NTK kernel (NTK) and the NNGP kernel (NNGP) kernel (NNGP) in the context of deep learning. The authors show that NTK and NTNGP kernels can be used to train deep neural networks with different hyperparameters. In addition, they show that FCNs and CNNs can be trained in the same way.

This paper studies the problem of representation learning in the context of protein folding. In particular, the authors study the relationship between sequential and 3D structure in protein folding, and propose a method to learn a representation of the 3D representation of a protein. The proposed method is based on a hand-engineered representation learning approach. The authors evaluate the proposed method on a number of datasets, and show that it outperforms existing representation learning approaches.

This paper studies the functional space of linear neural networks. In particular, the authors consider non-filling and non-smooth convex convex losses. The main result of the paper is to show that the functional spaces of linear networks can be decomposed into two subspaces, one of which is a pure critical point space, and the other is a non-pure critical points space. The authors also show that for non-convex loss functions, there exists a critical point in the non-definite functional space.

This paper proposes a framework for unsupervised graph learning based on subgraph isomorphism. The authors propose a new loss function, called SEED, which is based on the embedding of the subgraph vector distribution into the output vector representation. Experiments show that the proposed method outperforms the baselines on several benchmark datasets.

This paper studies the counterfactual regret minimization (CFR) algorithm in the context of large-scale extensive games. In particular, the authors propose two variants of the CFR algorithm. The first one, called the lazy-CFR algorithm, is a variant of the classic CFR algorithm, while the second one is called the cFR algorithm. Both algorithms are shown to converge to the optimal regret minimizer.

This paper studies the problem of unsupervised domain adaptation (UDA) in the presence of domain discrepancy. In particular, the authors propose a new method for UDA based on the distribution matching network (DMPN) framework. DMPN consists of two main components: (1) feature distribution modeling and (2) domain invariant features. The authors conduct hyper-parameter sensitivity analysis to show that the proposed method is more sensitive to domain discrepancy than existing methods.

This paper proposes a method to train a generative model that is able to generate high-dimensional latent codes that can be used for a variety of downstream tasks. The main contribution of the paper is the introduction of a new metric to measure the likelihood of the output of the model. The metric is based on the similarity between the latent codes generated by the model and the corresponding supervised code. The authors show that this metric is a good proxy for the quality of the generated latent codes.

This paper studies the problem of non-lazy TD learning in the context of nonlinear functions. In particular, the authors focus on the case where the value function is non-linear. In this case, they provide a theoretical analysis of the convergence rate of the TD learning algorithm. They also provide some empirical results to support their theoretical analysis.

This paper studies the problem of hypothesis verification in reinforcement learning, where the goal is to verify whether a given hypothesis is correct or not. The authors consider the setting where the agent has access to a set of hypotheses, and is given access to an action sequence that satisfies the hypothesis. They show that, in this setting, it is possible to prove that the hypothesis is true if and only if the action sequence satisfies a certain condition.

This paper presents a method for reasoning in latent spaces. The main idea is to learn a set of latent representations for a given set of statements in a fixed dimensional latent space. These representations are then used to solve the problem of reasoning in the latent space of a given statement. The authors show that the learned embeddings can be used for reasoning.

This paper proposes a method for learning depth estimation from multi-view geometry. The key idea is to use a global-local network architecture to estimate the depth of an agent, which is then used to guide the agent to the ground truth. The authors show that the proposed method can be applied to both natural and artificial agents.

This paper studies the problem of large vocabulary size in natural language models. In particular, the authors propose a method to reduce the size of the vocabulary in a multi-layer Transformer model by using hash functions. The authors show that this reduces the number of tokens in the output of the model by a large margin. They also show that the proposed method outperforms the existing methods in terms of accuracy.

This paper proposes a novel method for 3D shape segmentation based on the contextual bandit problem. The authors propose a novel clustering approach to learn the embeddings of 3D parts from a large dataset. The proposed method is evaluated on a variety of benchmark datasets.

This paper studies the problem of generating images of black-hired men and white-haired women with different gender-related characteristics. To this end, the authors propose to use GANs trained on the same dataset, but with different transformations. The main idea is to train a GAN model on the original dataset, and then use it to generate the transformed data. The authors show that the generated images are more diverse than the original data.

This paper studies the problem of few-shot image classification and semantic segmentation in the context of first-order meta-learning. The authors propose a new benchmark dataset, FSS-1000, to evaluate the performance of several meta-learner algorithms on the task. They show that the performance on the new dataset is competitive with the state-of-the-art methods. They also show that a few models are able to outperform the state of the art methods on the benchmark dataset.

This paper proposes a new approach for few-shot learning based on Prototypical Random Walk Networks (PRWN). The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new semi-supervised loss function for prototypical networks. The proposed loss is based on the random walk notion, which aims to encourage compact and well-separated class representations. Experiments on mini-imagenet and 5-shot classification tasks demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new self-supervised learning framework for remote sensing. The proposed framework is based on the contrastive sensor fusion framework. The authors propose to fuse multi-sensor representations from different channels to improve the classification performance. The experimental results show the effectiveness of the proposed framework.

This paper studies the problem of fine-tuning the learning rate schedule for neural network pruning. In particular, the authors focus on the case of network-agnostic pruning and network-autoregressive pruning, where the weights of the network are pruned at the same time. The authors propose a new rewinding technique, which rewinds the weights at the beginning of training and rewinds them at the end of training. They also propose a network-agnostic pruning algorithm, which prunes weights at a fixed rate.

This paper studies the problem of training deep neural networks with adversarial robustness. The authors propose a new training algorithm based on theoretically inspired training algorithm. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new metric, the output margin, which is defined as the difference between the norm of the output and the margin of the hidden layer norms. The paper also provides a theoretical analysis of this metric.

This paper studies the problem of knowledge-grounded dialog generation in the context of out-of-domain knowledge. In particular, the authors focus on the question of how to train a dialog generation model to generate dialogs that are grounded in knowledge. To this end, they propose to use a combination of disentangled response decoder, a generative model, and a dialogue generation model.

This paper proposes a unified architecture for non-parallel machine translation models (NMT) that unifies the source to target and target to source translation models. The proposed approach is based on the idea of unifying the source and target NMT models in a unified semantic space. The authors show that the proposed approach outperforms the existing approaches in both resource-rich and low-resource settings.

This paper studies the problem of training reinforcement learning algorithms for continuous control tasks. The authors propose a non-uniform sampling scheme to improve the sample efficiency of the reinforcement learning algorithm. They also propose a new benchmark to evaluate the performance of the algorithm. The proposed method is evaluated on the Mujoco benchmark.

This paper studies the problem of adversarial attacks on audio-to-text content identification systems. In particular, the authors focus on YouTube's content identification system. The authors propose a new adversarial attack method based on gradient-based attacks. They show that the proposed method is able to fool the existing systems.

This paper studies the problem of cross-view pattern discovery in the context of point-to-point learning. In particular, the authors focus on the activation map, representation learning, and metric learning. To this end, the paper proposes a new framework for cross view pattern discovery. The proposed method is evaluated on a number of benchmark datasets. The results show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies the problem of continual learning in the online setting, where the goal is to learn a policy that is able to adapt to changes in the world. The authors propose a new method, called Adaptive Online Planning (AOP), to address this problem. AOP consists of two components: a planner and a reinforcement learning agent. The planner is a model-free policy learning agent that learns a policy in a continual learning setting, and the reinforcement learner is a network that learns the policy in an online learning setting.

This paper proposes a new attention mechanism for text captioning models. The key idea is to replace the softmax attention mechanism with a sparsity-promoting attention mechanism. The authors conduct experiments on COCO and Flickr30k datasets to show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies the problem of predicting the evolution of dynamic graphs in real-world datasets. The authors propose a new model for dynamic graphs, which is based on a neural network with a recurrent architecture. They show that the proposed model is able to predict the evolution patterns of the dynamic graphs with high accuracy.

This paper studies the problem of missing data imputation techniques for tabular classification. The authors propose a new method for imputing missing features to complete datasets. They show that the proposed method is able to improve the performance of the model on CIFAR-10 dataset.

This paper studies the problem of off-policy estimation in high-fidelity simulation. The authors propose a new method based on Kernel Hilbert Spaces (KKHSs) to address this problem. The main contribution of the paper is the introduction of the RKHSs, which is a kernel-based representation of the state-action space. Theoretical guarantees are provided for the convergence of the proposed method. Empirical results are provided to demonstrate the effectiveness of the method.

This paper proposes a generative adversarial network (GAN) framework to learn a mixture model (MM) for unsupervised data. The proposed framework is based on the Gaussian mixture model. The authors show that the proposed GAN framework is able to achieve good performance on a variety of datasets.

This paper proposes a new method for training large capacity neural networks for image classification and semantic segmentation. The main idea is to aggregate the posteriors of features in a fine-grained manner, rather than using a pre-specified prior distribution. The proposed method is evaluated on the CIFAR-10 and ImageNet datasets, and achieves state-of-the-art performance.

This paper proposes a new scoring test to evaluate the quality of the outputs of deep neural networks (DNNs). The proposed test is based on the importance of each neuron in a neural network. The authors show that the proposed scoring test is more accurate than other scoring tests, and that it is more efficient than existing scoring tests.

This paper proposes a new method for hierarchical reinforcement learning that compresses the action trajectories in a hierarchical manner. The method is based on compressing the action primitives into a set of sub-goal trajectories, which are then used to train the agent. The authors show that their method is able to outperform a number of baselines on a variety of tasks.

This paper proposes a new generative model, called Hierarchical Bayesian Bayes Autoencoder (HBAE), which is a multimodal decoder for generating complex image sets. HBAE is based on the energy-based model (EBM) framework. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new multi-modal Gaussian decoder, which can be applied to both single image and set cases. Experiments are conducted on synthetic and real-world datasets to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed model.

This paper studies the problem of normalization in off-policy reinforcement learning (off-policy TD) algorithms. The authors propose a new normalization technique, cross-normalization, which is a mixture of on-policy normalization and batch normalization. They show that the proposed technique can improve the performance of TD algorithms on MuJoCo benchmark tasks.

This paper studies the problem of identifying confounding variables in deep learning models. The authors propose a new adversarial training strategy to identify confounding variables. The proposed method is based on the observation that confounding variables are often associated with the training data. The paper also proposes a new loss function to mitigate this problem. Experiments on medical image datasets show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper proposes a new benchmark for character-level language modeling based on transformer-based language models. The benchmark consists of two tasks: 1) learning a group of linear operators, and 2) finding the shortest path from a given input to a given output. The authors show that the proposed benchmark outperforms existing benchmarks on both tasks.

This paper studies the problem of generative autoencoders with deep latent variables. The authors propose a new framework for generative models based on deep latent variable hierarchies. The main contribution of the paper is a theoretical analysis of the divergence between the mean and mean-discrepancy divergences between deep latent hierarchies and a generative model.

This paper proposes a three-dimensional self-attention mechanism for video generation models. The key idea is to train a video-specific neural network architecture to generate a sequence of video frames, which is then used to train an adversarial video generation model. The proposed method is evaluated on a large scale action recognition dataset. The results show that the proposed method outperforms the baselines.

This paper proposes a novel zero-shot learning framework for the multi-label text classification task. In particular, the authors propose to use a generative model to generate a sequence of codes for each label in the dataset. The proposed method is evaluated on the MIMIC-III dataset.

This paper studies the problem of self-supervised representation learning (SSL) and reinforcement learning (RL) in low-dimensional states and action embeddings. In particular, the authors focus on the goal-conditioned continuous control setting, where the goal is to learn a high-quality policy that is able to perform well in a low-resource environment. The authors propose to learn the embedding of state and action sequences from pixel observations, and then use this embedding to improve the sample efficiency of RL.

This paper studies the problem of meta-learning in the context of knowledge graph design. The authors propose a framework for learning a knowledge graph that can be shared across different tasks. The framework is based on the idea that the knowledge graph can be viewed as a representation of a set of tasks, and that the task-specific knowledge can be represented as a graph. The proposed framework is evaluated on a toy task classification task and a few-shot image classification task.

This paper studies the problem of fine-tuning differentiable attribute models for text generation. The authors propose a new approach to fine-tune the model architecture and the activations of the PPLM language model. They show that the proposed approach is able to improve the performance of the model on a variety of datasets. They also show that it is possible to train the model in an unsupervised manner.

This paper studies the problem of robust representation learning in the presence of single-scale corruption in the domain knowledge. The authors propose two approaches to address this problem: (1) clean data, and (2) self-supervised representation learning. The clean data approach is based on the idea that the representation learned by a neural network should be invariant to noise in the input data. The proposed approach is evaluated on a variety of datasets, and the results show that the proposed approach outperforms the baselines.

This paper studies the problem of under-sensitivity in natural language processing (NLP) training. In particular, the authors propose a new training method based on bound propagation (IBP) to address this problem. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of the IBP framework, which is based on the idea of bound propagation. Experiments are conducted on both the SNLI and MNLI datasets to show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

This paper studies the problem of Q-learning in the Markov Decision Process (MDP) setting, where the goal is to learn a Q-value function that maximizes the return of the current state and action. The authors propose a new algorithm, QGRAPH, to solve this problem. They also provide a lower bound on the number of iterations needed to learn the Q-values.

This paper studies the problem of unsupervised domain adaptation. In particular, the authors propose a new method to learn domain invariant embeddings. The authors also provide a theoretical analysis on the trade-off between the complexity of domain adaptation and the number of layers.

This paper studies the generalization error bounds for stochastic gradient Langevin dynamics (SGLD) methods. In particular, the authors provide data-dependent generalization bounds based on the Bayes-stochastic stability method. The authors show that the out-of-sample error bounds are tighter than the existing ones. They also provide a data-independent generalization bound.

This paper studies the problem of continual learning in the context of spatial navigation. In particular, the authors focus on the task of goal-directed spatial navigation, where the goal is to navigate from one location to another in a goal-conditioned manner. The authors propose a new method for continual learning based on mixed principal component analysis (dPCA) and show that it outperforms existing methods in terms of performance on both allocentric and egocentric spatial tasks.

This paper proposes a new policy optimization method based on the Monte Carlo Tree Search (MCTS) algorithm. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new branching factor for the policy optimization algorithm, which is a combination of the existing tree search and bootstrapping methods. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms the state-of-the-art policy optimization algorithms on several benchmarks.

This paper studies the ticket hypothesis in the context of neural networks. In particular, the authors propose to use the Ticket Ticket Hypothesis to explain the success of the TicketNet dataset. The ticket hypothesis is based on the observation that a neural network trained on a large dataset can generate a large number of tickets. The authors show empirically that this hypothesis can explain the performance of TicketNet.

This paper studies the problem of adversarial training and adversarial attacks on neural reading comprehension models. In particular, the authors focus on the data augmentation/distribution mismatch problem, which is a common problem in adversarial learning. To address this problem, they propose two strategies: (1) adversarial augmentation and (2) adversarially selected input perturbations. Experiments show that the proposed strategies outperform the baseline models.

This paper studies the problem of safety in reinforcement learning. The authors propose a model-based approach to address this problem. The proposed approach is based on the idea of a graph-directed RL algorithm, where the goal is to minimize the distance between the current state and the next state in the action space. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a safety penalty that encourages the agent to visit states that are more likely to be safe.

This paper studies the problem of learning the physics equations of physical systems from sparse data. The authors propose a deep learning model based on the DGND framework. The main contribution of the paper is the introduction of the concept of "dynamical relations" between physical systems, which is a generalization of the well-known notion of "spatial and temporal differences" in physical systems. The paper also provides a theoretical analysis of the error of the proposed model.

This paper studies the problem of training neural networks with nonsmooth regularization and nonconvex constraints. In particular, the authors propose a new regularization function, called 1-norm regularization (1-norm-regularization), which is a combination of the regularization term and the constraint term. The authors show that this regularization can be used to improve the learning rates of the ProxSGD algorithm.

This paper proposes a differentiable end-to-end differentiable compression framework for image compression. In particular, the authors propose a non-deterministic encoder-decoder framework that is able to compress images in a compressed manner. The authors show that the proposed framework can achieve comparable bitrates to the state-of-the-art methods on the CLIC 2018 dataset.

This paper proposes a new method to generate high-quality super resolution (SR) images from compressed C-JPG images. The main idea is to use a new loss function, called Cycle Loss, to improve the quality of the generated SR images. Experiments show that the proposed method outperforms existing methods.

This paper proposes a deep learning architecture for soccer match prediction. The main idea is to use a convolutional neural network to predict the probability of each pass in a soccer match. The authors show that the proposed architecture is able to learn the probability map of the pass probabilities at different levels of the feature hierarchy. They also show that their method can be used to improve the quality of the prediction.

This paper studies the problem of long-range dependencies in recommender systems. In particular, the authors propose a method to learn embeddings and matrix completion models for the MovieLens dataset. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new graph neural network (GNN) model that is able to learn a latent embedding and a matrix completion model. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms existing baselines in terms of both accuracy and efficiency.

This paper studies the problem of learning to solve continuous control tasks in a stochastic setting. The authors propose a new algorithm for this problem, named SMTP, which is based on the heavy ball momentum method. The main contribution of this paper is to provide a theoretical analysis of the convergence rate of the proposed algorithm, which shows that SMTP converges to the optimal solution faster than existing algorithms.

This paper studies the action semantics network (ASN) architecture for multi-agent reinforcement learning (DRL) in the context of reinforcement learning. The authors show that the ASN architecture is able to achieve state-of-the-art performance on the StarCraft II micromanagement environment. The paper also shows that the proposed architecture can be extended to other environments.

This paper studies the low-rank structure of the Q function in the context of value-based methods and deep reinforcement learning (RL). The authors show that the high-rank Q function can be decomposed into two sub-structures: the state-action value function and the action-value function. Then, the authors propose two algorithms to solve these sub-tasks. The first algorithm is based on the matrix estimation method, while the second algorithm is a combination of the two methods. The authors also provide a theoretical analysis of the proposed algorithms.

This paper studies the problem of sample-efficient reinforcement learning (DRL) in the context of imitation learning. The authors propose a new algorithm called Best-Action Imitation Learning (BAIL) that learns a policy network that maximizes the Q function in the action space. The algorithm is evaluated on the Mujoco benchmark.

This paper studies the problem of extreme multi-label learning in the context of embeddings. The authors propose a new algorithm, DeepXML-CNN, which is based on the deep embedding architecture of the CNN model. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of negative training data to improve the performance of the proposed algorithm. Experiments show that the proposed method outperforms the state-of-the-art methods.

This paper proposes a new method to reduce the overhead of hashing-based collaborative filtering. The proposed method is based on the idea of self-masking the vector representation of the hash code. The authors show that the proposed method can significantly reduce the computation of the distance between the hash codes. The paper also provides a theoretical analysis of the proposed approach.

This paper proposes a new metric to evaluate the quality of generated images generated by GANs. The metric is based on the similarity of the generated images to the original images. The authors show that the proposed metric can be used to evaluate GAN learned distribution and model parameters. Experiments are conducted to show the effectiveness of the metric.

This paper studies the Taylor expansion of neural networks in the NTK regime. In particular, the authors show that the Taylor series of NTKs can be expressed in terms of higher-order terms. The authors also provide a sample complexity bound for the randomized two-layer networks.

This paper proposes a new method for assessing the quality of graph convolutional filters in GNNs. The method is based on the GFD score (GFD) score, which is a metric that measures the similarity between the scores of different filters. The authors show that GFD is a good metric to evaluate the quality and robustness of the filters. They also show that the proposed method can be applied to real-world datasets such as CIFAR-10.

This paper studies distributionally robust optimization (DRO) in the overparameterized regime. The authors show that the worst-case training loss can be reduced by stopping the regularization step at a certain point in the training process. They also provide a theoretical analysis of the effect of stopping the stopping step on the generalization error. Finally, the authors provide a stochastic optimization algorithm for DRO models.

This paper studies the problem of explaining black-box classifiers. In particular, the authors focus on the question of how to explain black box classifiers in the presence of hyperparameters. The authors propose a new method that is based on the concept of local explanation methods. They show that the proposed method is able to explain the performance of a black box classification model in terms of the number of explanations provided by the black box model.

This paper studies the problem of top-k selection in the context of image reconstruction and classification problems. The authors propose a new top-K selection variable that can be used to train a network to select a subset of instances to be used for the task at hand. The paper also proposes a new method to train the network to learn the top-kl selection variable. Experiments show that the proposed method outperforms existing methods.

This paper studies the problem of self-learning reinforcement learning in the context of inductive program synthesis. In particular, the authors focus on the case where the agent has access to a large code space, and the goal is to generate a set of programs that can be executed in a given number of steps. The authors propose a new algorithm, AutoAssemble, that is based on the multi-entropy policy sampling technique. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new policy network architecture that allows the agent to sample from a large set of policy networks, which is then used to generate program synthesis instructions.

This paper studies the convergence of first-order ODEs in the neural network architecture design space. In particular, the authors analyze the convergence rate of ODE's coefficient matrix H, which is the ratio of the number of parameters of the network to the total number of training iterations. The authors show that ODE converges faster than first order ODE, and provide a theoretical analysis of the rate of convergence of H. They also provide empirical evidence to support their theoretical findings.

This paper studies the generalization bounds of neural networks (NNs) trained with gradient descent and interpolating kernel methods. In particular, the authors consider the case of ReLU-NNs, where the number of parameters of the network is large. The authors show that the error bounds are tight for wide ReLU networks, and also provide a lower bound on the variance of the gradient descent method.

This paper proposes a new loss function for depth estimation of faraway objects in the 3D LiDAR framework. The proposed loss function is based on depthpropagation algorithm. The authors show that the proposed loss can be used to improve the accuracy of 3D object detection on the KITTI benchmark.

This paper proposes a method for detecting adversarial examples in deep neural networks. The method is based on a generative adversarial training approach, where the model is trained to distinguish between one-vs-the-rest classification and adversarial samples. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms existing methods in terms of detection accuracy and defense against white-box attacks.

This paper proposes a model-free reinforcement learning method for exploration in MiniGrid environments. The main idea is to learn a state representation of the environment, which is then used as a reward for exploration. The authors show that the proposed method outperforms the baselines on a number of tasks.

This paper proposes a new set of pre-training tasks for Transformer models for document retrieval. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of a new ICT-style task, which is a subset of the body first selection (BFS) task. The paper also introduces a new query-document retrieval (IDF) problem, which aims to reduce the size of the document corpus. Experiments show that the proposed tasks improve the performance of the model on the ICT task.

This paper proposes a new graph neural network architecture for multi-graph aggregation and pooling based on bipartite graph convolutional networks. The main contribution of this paper is the introduction of strided and transpose convolution operations, which are parametrized strided convolution operators and non-parameterized pooling or expansion layers, respectively. The authors also propose a novel graph autoencoder based on the biGraphNet formalism. Experiments show the effectiveness of the proposed architecture.

This paper studies the problem of few-shot classification in the context of domain generalization. In particular, the authors study the impact of hyper-parameters on the performance of few shot classification algorithms in the presence of domain shifts. The authors show that the hyperparameters affect the performance in two ways: (1) the number of classes, and (2) the amount of training data used to train the models. In the first case, they show that hyperparameter-based methods are able to generalize well to new domains, while in the second case, the performance deteriorates with increasing number of training examples.

This paper studies the problem of learning a convolutional network for fluid simulation. In particular, the authors propose a new network architecture that can be used to solve a class of collision geometries. The authors show that the proposed network is able to converge faster than existing methods.

This paper proposes a method to reduce the memory and computational cost of batch ensembles for sequential learning tasks. The main idea is to use a single neural network for each task, and then use a batch ensemble for the next task. The authors evaluate the proposed method on CIFAR-10 and split-ImageNet, and show that it outperforms the baselines.

This paper proposes a new method for solving PDEs that is both shape-free and shape-invariant. The key idea is to use a network-based partial differential equation solver to solve the PDE problem. The authors show that the proposed method can be used to solve both forward and inverse problems. They also show that their method is robust to boundary conditions.

This paper presents a method for training deep neural networks (BNNs) to solve probabilistic and existential queries. The main idea is to train BNNs on a large number of examples and then train a solver to solve the queries. This is done by training the solver on a set of examples, and then training the BNN on a subset of these examples. The authors show that the proposed method is able to improve the performance of the trained BNN by a large margin.

This paper studies the expressive power of graph neural networks (GNNs) in the message-passing framework. The main contribution of this paper is to provide bounds on the expressiveness of GNNs. In particular, the authors show that for any graph GNN, there exists a graph G that satisfies all expressiveness conditions. The authors also provide a lower bound on expressiveness.

This paper proposes a new generative flow-based method for density estimation. The main idea is to use normalising flows to approximate the likelihoods of bijections. The authors show that the proposed method can be applied to a wide range of density estimation tasks.

This paper presents a study of the impact of re-splitting the visual appearance of the agent model on the agent's ability to solve a given task. Specifically, the authors perform a series of experiments in which the agent is given a set of instructions in a language other than English, followed by a sequence of tasks in a different language. The authors show that, for a given set of tasks, the agent can learn to solve the given task in a manner that is similar to that of a human. They also show that this can be used to train the agent to solve tasks that are difficult to solve.

This paper studies the impact of human feedback on RL agent’s learning in Atari-type environments. In particular, the authors focus on the case where the agent has access to a reward function that encourages the agent to perform well in the environment. To this end, they introduce a new reward function for RL agents that encourages them to perform better than the agent without human feedback. They show that the proposed reward function is able to improve the agent's performance in both synthetic and real-world environments.

This paper studies the problem of reducing the quality of human and machine classifiers in the context of minimal-entropy positive images. In particular, the authors study the effect of resolution reduction and colour reduction on the performance of both humans and machine models on the VRC test-set. The authors show that the human classifier performs worse than the machine classifier when the resolution is reduced. In addition, the paper shows that the colour reduction is more important than the resolution reduction in the case of human classifiers.
